I have an idea... while the Civil War era guns would (most likely?) have had rifling, given that they're from opposite sides, they most likely had different manufacturing sources, and the rifling may have been in opposite directions as well. What would happen if one of your barrels imparted a rotation counter to the other one? You'd end up with the bullets meeting with matching rotation instead of opposing, and that would eliminate one source of motion that could prevent a fusing event.

A few things that I think affect the results: -You may need to cast your own lead bullets. Most manufacturers today will add a bit of tin to make them harder, so eliminating that tin should help stop the bullet from fragmenting. -The Minie ball fired from the Springfield rifled muskets had a concave base in order to expand to meet the rifling in the musket.  -The minie balls fired from Springfields were .58 caliber opposed to the .45 used in your tests which means there are some additional factors needed to replicate what you had seen in the museum. -The .58 caliber balls weighed 500 grains opposed to the 200 grains of the .45 LC. There is a 600ish grain difference in mass transfer between the two bullet types colliding. -The typical .58 traveled at about  944 FPS from a 40in barrel as opposed to the 900 FPS from the .45, usually in a 5 3/4 in barrel.  - the combat range which the bullets fired against each other could have also affected the result for the museumâ€™s example, as the muzzle energy of the rounds could have dissipated a little bit if both muskets were fired at their maximum effective range of 300yds, intercepting around 150 yards.  If I had to guess, going with a soft lead .58 traveling around 600-750 FPS would probably yield the result you are looking for while staying generally true to what happened.

The problems that your running into this experiment are a number of things. so when it comes to aiming you cant just aim in a straight line with two lasers and call it good. You have to make mathematical calculations when dealing with external ballistics and ballistic coefficient of each particular round of ammo. this includes projectile weight, type of powder,  type of casing, length of casing, and primer. because of physics the bullet starts to travel at an arc even at short distances. But projectiles this close are still technically climbing in their arc of travel.        with the rifling part. that comes down to case length and the head spacing. like you mention why the bullet jump or like you said the fire ball comes out before the projectile comes out is because a seal wasn't formed to create the needed back pressure behind the projectile as it travels through the rifling. You said that you friend reloads as a hobby??? he should know all of this if that's what he does, or what he's  doing for this project.   You two need to have firearm experts to help you with experiment because you said you'll two are having inconsistences which you seems like two me you haven't figured it out yet because of the complex math that's involved with this but not only that, using an actual firearm would work out ore in your favor as they are design with that indented purpose already and they are much more safer than the Jerry rigged nonsense of barrels and rifling.

A major issue that you touched upon is the metal (lead) of the bullets is modern metal. My assumption is that it is formulated to be rather brittle. This would, from a gun manufacturer perspective, normally be very advantageous to improve fragmentation creating a higher lethality.  The assumption could also be made that civil war era bullets were not as advanced in metallurgy. It may be possible to acquire samples (civil war bullets can be purchased from collectors) even ones from that exact battlefield. Then have a few samples tested for the exact properties of the lead that was in use in that battlefield. It may be important to match not only the same hardness but also the chemical composition to assure the same performance properties.

Not all musket balls were pure led, and soldiers would often melt whatever metal they had available and forge new musket balls. Chances are that piece in the museum contains some sort of tin, nickel, or are just composed of a softer/weaker lead.   Speed likely has something to do with it but I think it was really the addition of the softer metal into the mix that provided the catalyst for a fusion.

My advice: ADD TIN. Tin/lead, aka solder, has a lower melting point than lead. 63%Sn and 37%Pb is eutectic (lowest melting point) is readily available in bar-stock form (from Kester, for example) and is much lower in melting point and much more malleable than pure lead. Also: the Civil War slugs had been tamped in, which probably knocked off the film of lead oxide prior to firing. So polish the bullet tips prior to loading.

I propose it was a couple issues that may have caused your non-fusing problem and lead composition is not one of them.  The issue may have been the bullet shape.  Shooting two shapes that are essentially cylinders at each other, in addition to a little of the velocity problem was probably the issue.  A ball hitting a ball has a completely different reaction as the center of mass is different than a "bullet" shaped bullet.  Modern bullets as you know are made to flare out when they hit something and shrapnel to do more damage.  It's one of the fundamental reason we changed their shape over the years.   I propose a follow up video and use a physics simulation software to see what the actual differences are. I am willing to bet you will be surprised.

As someone who hates guns, bullets, and weapons in general, even I was immediately taken by this little YouTube experiment of yours.   To me, this is one of those "totally useless" but THEORETICALLY perfect little "easily doable" things... that is darn hard to accomplish, in the real world... especially by yourself... because it is a pure engineering issue. Not as difficult as smashing, heads-on, two tiny particles at the Large Hadron Collider or the ITER or the dozen or so other similar & different fusion engineering projects... but it still is very difficult to do, because it also is quite potentially dangerous, in terms of personal & equipment safety issues.    The PHYSICS part of it is over in nano seconds; but the safety and engineering issues... they take weeks and months, at least, to be thought over and to be constructed... so those two bullets could meet ever so precisely, so a super fast camera could take a good shot at the nano second they hit each other, like those particles do, at the LHC at CERN...

Without reading other comments, may I offer this. 1. The Civil War guns were not as powerful so bullet impact would have been less forceful. 2. Distance between guns would also lower impact. 3. Modern bullets, though strictly controlled, do have a slight variance in power resulting in a variable that is uncontrolled, which gives you the misses. Also temp of the barrels may cause an up, down or sideways miss. All in all, the hits you were getting were almost as reliant on chance as the engineering. Great video.

The bullets/mini-balls seem to be fragmenting rather than deforming like the Fredericksburg Minie balls in the display exhibit.   If you haven't done so already, you may want to considering doing a metallurgical analysis of civil war era Minie balls to make sure they have the same ductile characteristics.  Temperature may also be a factor.  Are you cold firing the bullets using cold compressed air or are you also simulating live black powder fire and long rifled barrel friction to get the Minie balls up to temperature?  Another consideration is that if the Fredericksburg Minie balls were fired at a considerable distance apart, that their velocities may have been a lot less than in your demonstration tests which could allow for more time for them to deform and fuse.  Have you also tried reducing the relative velocities of the Minnie balls?  For a more controlled sampling of the fragments, have you considered laying some type of clean substrate under the test apparatus, such as a clean white drop cloth, canvas or just a blue or green tarp so that you have a better chance to collect all the fragments?  If you're using lead, then all the lead fragments flying about are likely to contaminate the soil.

When I was a kid having a snowball fight with friends, two snowballs collided in mid-air and we all stopped and marveled at the wonderous thing that we just witnessed.

A Civil War "bullet" was a lead ball jammed down on top of gun powder, and the bullets of today are a cartridge, with a harder mix and casing. It is all the more amazing because the Civil War balls had to hit exactly at a very small area on both balls, or there would have been deflection, given the small area of contact on 2 circles and a much longer distance. So the 2 balls had to hit so perfectly head on in order to fuse together. For this to happen, they most likely were shooting at each other.

It's not going to fuse because the temperature is not high enough. If you make the bullets out of silver you might have better luck. The silver doesn't store as much kinetic energy as lead. That's what's why winchester silver tips kill better at lower velocity than lead. They mushroom better and stay together without fragmented therefore they expend a larger amount of energy in the path of the bullet. SHOCK!!! Fragmenteing causes more bleeding but much less shock. At infantry ranges you don't get shock therefore you want fragmentation to insure the target is more likely to be taken out of the fight. Therefore, multiple small caliber rounds emulated fragmentation even if the individual bullets don't fragment. That's why we train fore the 3 or 5 shot burst at distance. Of course it also adds to the potential for a hit at conventional I pantry engagement ranges. Naturally that goes out the window inurban or sniper engagements. But try silver or a silver lead mix and get rid of the antimony in your lead mix. A longer barrel and 45 70 may allow you to reach near melting heat increasing the chances of vision. 45 LC with max loads out of a longer barrel might be worth a try before going to 45 70. The greater recoil may become an issue for your hardware. Though, it did look like you could have fired a locomotive down that I-beam.

I know this is old, and that some people already pointed out these two facts (both were partially discovered by the makers of this film)....but as SOON as I saw the first impact, and how the bullets completely shattered, I knew right away that they did not use pure lead in their bullets.  Civil war miniballs would have been PURE lead, but these modern cast bullets USUALLY have a certain percentage of tin, and antimony mixed in, and thus the relative hardness can be customized  to whatever parameters the shooter wants to achieve.  Tin and Antimony both make modern bullets MUCH more harder (and LIGHTER), and so would have a tendancy to shatter more easily.  The other obvious factor is that these civil war miniballs would have been going MUCH slower...for three reasons:  1)  The solid lead miniballs of between 52-69 caliber would have been MUCH heavier than these 45 cal bullets used...at least 2-3 times as heavy; 2) The black powder charges would have produced much less pressure, thus having slower speeds (even with long barrels)...not to mention the blow-by from using patches and imperfectly round projectiles; and 3) The two miniballs that met on that day in the civil war were fired across a battlefield, presumably up to 100 yards apart...both miniballs had slowed down DRASTICALLY by then.  The other thing I will point out, is those fused miniballs in the museum are almost certainly NOT the full weight of the two original miniballs!  There most certainly was a fair amount of lead splattered on that impact...and what was eventually discovered was only the part that fused together.  Finally....the thoughts that went into designing this experiment (especially from a safety standpoint), was nothing less than BRILLIANT!!!

If you haven't done so already, you may want to considering doing a metallurgical analysis of civil war era Minie balls to make sure they have the same ductile characteristics.  Temperature may also be a factor.  Are you cold firing the bullets using cold compressed air or are you also simulating live black powder fire and long rifled barrel friction to get the Minie balls up to temperature?  Another consideration is that if the Fredericksburg Minie balls were fired at a considerable distance apart, that their velocities may have been a lot less than in your demonstration tests which could allow for more time for them to deform and fuse.  Have you also tried reducing the relative velocities of the Minnie balls?  For a more controlled sampling of the fragments, have you considered laying some type of clean substrate under the test apparatus, such as a clean white drop cloth, canvas or just a blue or green tarp so that you have a better chance to collect all the fragments?  If you're using lead, then all the lead fragments flying about are likely to contaminate the soil.

I believe it comes down to two main factors: 	1.	Speed: Due to the short distance, the bullets fired from both guns are traveling at extremely high speeds. In contrast, during the Civil War, the distances between opposing forces were likely greater, giving bullets more time to lose some of their velocity. 	2.	Ballistics: If my assumption about the shorter distance is correct, the ballistic properties of the bullets play a role as well. The rapid spinning (caused by rifling) of the bullets would be less pronounced over longer distances as the spin slows down. With two bullets spinning at such high speeds and colliding head-on, they are more likely to shatter or collapse rather than fuse together.

Well I watched until you picked the bullets youâ€™re going to use and the distance the barrels were set apart on the beam. THIS WILL NEVER WORK! I think you came up with an interesting idea but the civil war mini-balls were propelled by black powder and the armies were at greater distance, at least when the battle began. So you need to use black powder (type 1, 2, or 3 since they used any powder available). The most common mini-ball was 58 cal. but the weight varied since they made many of them over a camp fire with crude molds.  The mini-balls must be pure lead, todayâ€™s lead substitute is to brittle. Increase the distance between barrels to at least 75 - 50 yards; or reduce the black powder charge to get a working velocity (FPI). Once the bullets are hitting each other adjust the amount of black powder (not a BP substitute) until they melt together on impact. You accounted for many variables but the most important for making these bullet weld together is in the civil war ammunition and distance = bullet speed at impact. (Remember during the civil war most Black Powder used by the confederate army was hand made in mines right below the Union troops. This means the flash point of the ingredients, and moisture content, is a big variable. For this reason they frequently scavenged munitions and powders from the Union troops after winning a battle. Cannon grade powder was frequently mixed with lower ignition point powders to reduce chamber pressure in the muskets, this makes reproducing the actual mini-ball speed a variable that you may never find). You may need to do some homework to see if the powder quality is known to historians. If it is you can experiment with powder charges of mixtures of BP 1, 2, and 3.  You have a-lot of rework to do. The starting distance of the battle is a matter of record, but troops charged to close the gap frequently, and just as frequently needed to retreat to find cover.  This is what makes reproducing the fused bullets so hard, hitting two bullets together has been done before, itâ€™s just geometry and fixed barrel positions which you have done. Good luck with the rest.

As mentioned below, the fused bullets were going a lot slower and were softer. I'm not sure it was mentioned but I think your rifling twist is also faster. This were try to tear the bullet fragments apart more. Another factor that might have prevented fusion is the fact that on impact they are actually spinning in different directions. They would have to stop spinning relative to each other to fuse. The waller probably helped to stop the spinning of the first bullet enough so that the second bullet had a better chance to fuse. It goes back to the more energy that has to be dissipated the smaller the fragments. You have the rotational energy from the spinning bullets and the kinetic energy from the speeds of the bullets. You had solid lead bullets and the miniÃ© balls had very hollow bases. This may have helped the miniÃ© balls hold together because the hollow bases would have less total rotational energy and could have expanded around the solid noses keeping them together. You have to repeat this using shotgun slugs. The Forster style slugs. You should be able to get low velocity without any spinning, or if you have to use very slow rifling twist. Then create a clear housing to place at the point of impact to hold them, with some holes to vent the displaced gel. This should reduce the chance of the bullets being deflected, control where any possible cast-off goes, and give you a clearer image. I suspect the composition of the bullet was softer and more susceptible to melting. If the bullets are heated more before the explosion propels them out of the barrels, I think a fusion would be more likely. Run a test melting two bullets to see what temperature they fuse at. Then, run another test measuring the temperature of a bullet as it's firing. Try letting the bullets hit each other within a more dense medium than air. Like a water bottle. I think that would count. Slow it down without adding any material to the mix. You might even need to ADD powder again to have enough force to merge. These are all just layman guesses. I just know that you can't really shoot a person that is only a few feet under water, because the energy would quickly disperse. Maybe I'm wrong about that too. Another interesting experiment. When I see a movie, and somebody is shot at 6 feet underwater from a guy standing on shore or the side of a pool. I am very skeptical that the bullet would make it that far with any force. One small thing that might help with getting two bullets to fuse is the direction in which they rotate. If I understand correctly the barrels are made to give the bullet some angular momentum for a more stable flight path (gyroscope effect). If I saw it correctly (and based on the assumption that both guns are made identical) the bullets spin in a different direction. The angular momentum in different directions should mean they are slightly less likely to fuse into one, as the impact zone has to deal with both the frontal impact (deformations caused by that and a bounce back) and that rotation difference.  Awesome video :)  I could also be completely wrong and having them rotate in different directions (both counterclockwise in the flight direction) might be better.  Might be worth trying both.

I imagine you've figured this out but it looks to me like you're using a hardened lead antimony alloy bullet, thus the shattering.  Try pure lead bullets.  The bullets you're using look like a Lee TL452-230-2R, easy enough to drop your own.  Consider the 452-230-TC for the flatter nose.

Very interesting.  I did a lot of cast lead experimentation many years ago and still have some of the expanded bullets.  Probably the most interesting are the duplex bullets with wheel weight lead at the base and pure lead at the nose.  The softer pure lead seems to stick together more than the harder wheel weight alloy.  My guess is the Civil War bullets were of a pure lead and fired from a greater distance so they lost velocity by the time they met. As a weldor who have taken extra classes in metallurgy I think that they might be using like "cast lead" to make bullets. Fusing cast metal is harder because there are added more carbon and junk in there, to save on steel and make it easy to pour. I saw in one of Jonathan Ferguson videos that old muskets fire with a lower muzzle velocity than most modern pistols, so I would guess that with the low gunpowder bullets you guys made, that this should be in the ballpark, however I think factors like shape of the round and distance could be factors as well. I think the issue is the fact that the bullets are spinning in opposite directions. The war shot fusion bullets were from muskets without rifled barrels, so not spinning. Now if the opposing barrels are rifled, they would need to be rifled opposite...one clockwise, the other counter clockwise to have them spinning the same way when they meet. If they are both rifled clockwise, and shot from opposing sides, then they spin in opposing directions in relation to each other.

Hey Destin I'm a little late to this video haha but I'm a metallurgist here in the US. You mentioned in the video that the composition of the Pb might be to blame for lack of fusion... that could be but I'd also suggest that it could be related to the hardness of the lead itself. Like you mentioned composition can affect the hardness. I'd guess increased hardness may result in a higher propensity for fracture upon impact. If different composition lead isn't an option I'd suggest annealing the bullets prior loading them. Annealing the material may result in decreased hardness and increased toughness. Just a very rough rule of thumb but I'd try annealing a batch at 70-80% melting temp for whatever amount of time is reasonable. Increased time at temperature will result in increased softening of the material. Of course at those crazy strain rates all bets are off but just a suggestion in case lead with different composition proves difficult to come by. God Bless.

First of all, it's .45 Colt, not Long Colt. There have never been a .45 Short Cort or .45 Long Colt, just a .45 Colt. Some people say it was called .45 Long Colt by army supply officers so people didn't get mixed up with .45 Schofield, also known as .45 Smith & Wesson. Neither of those sounds anything like ".45 Colt", so I don't know how people would get confused and think they were the same thing. Secondly, as soon as you got 2 bullets to hit but not fuse I thought, you need to use soft lead bullets, not typical hard alloys (or jacketed bullets), and you need to load them to a lower velocity. Almost 26 minutes into the video, you came to the same conclusion I did in that instant, proving great minds think alike. Some are just faster on occasion. Sometimes I think slowly, but usually not when it comes to bullets.

Three things to consider: 1.  The Minnie ball was a hollow core bullet, the bullets you are using in this test are solid cast. 2.  The muzzle velocity of the muzzle loading weapons used in the Civil War were probably much lower than the velocities of the bullets you are firing in your experiment. 3.  The lead used for the Civil War bullets was probably much softer than the more modern cast lead bullets you are using. Too bad you couldn't build a couple of electronically fired muzzle loading guns and use black powder and get a reenactor to supply you with a few period correct Minnie balls.

Also, Using Modern bullets + Gun Barrels, the Gunpowder burns more efficiently + the better engineering tollerances between the Modern Barrels + the Bullets, thus resulting in less energy losses when Compared to Civil War Era Bullet and Barrlel Engineering Tolerances which where worse, compounding the loss of Inertia of both the Civil War Bullets, so they hit with a Lot less force. I have seen one example in a museum in Turkey from WWI and the battle of Gallipoli. One bullet hit another from the side, pierced it through, and stacked.

In planning your demonstration, you have assumed the fused bullets shown in the museum collided head-on,  but have you considered the fused bullets shown in the museum did not collide head-on but at an angle. Ya can't assume head-on collision from inspection of the museum bullets. The head-on impact will produce shattering regardless of what you use (conservation of energy b/c experiment bullets colliding head-on produce a symmetrical dissipation of energy and fragments move away symmetrically after impact).  Two bullets colliding at an angle would have a better chance of fusing.

16:12 if I had to guess at this point I would say the bullets used are of a harder more brittle material, and the powder or energy may be stronger than the event in the civil war that lead to the fused rounds...  There are a ton of factors from that time period that may have lead to different elements like maybe lower grain counts, wet powder, soldier made rounds from a mix of metals at hand or dirty lead.  Then there are factors like distance between firing points... I mean the soldiers may not have been firing at each other of one missed and collided with a round from a different soldier... In that case that may have been a round that spent a lot of energy, may have gone through clothing, brush, etc and then collided with a round with more energy.  You may get an idea of the material used if there are other rounds from that conflict, check to see if the military records for the arms and munitions supplied to the units is available, maybe even the time of the conflict in light of the full war may give insight to just how respectful the soldiers had to be if they were leading their own bullets... Things like metal buttons, silverware, recovered rounds...  Do many factors and variables.

Filling a cartridge half way or less than full is quite dangerous, if you think about how the powder will burn normally in a "full" cartridge, it burns from the rear of the casing forward. Half full cartridges burn along the top down essentially burning all at once.  It can cause the gun to blow apart. @smartereveryday, it's possible the test stand guns' shorter barrels result in less heat transfer to the bullets compared to Civil War muskets. The longer barrels of that era likely caused more heat buildup from friction, bringing the bullets closer to their melting point and therefore make them more malleable. This could make fusion more likely upon a direct collision.

Fire them from period weapons, and loading to civil war period specs, black powder etc.. CHRONOGRAPH the speeds. Then melt the same bullets or other period bullets and cast them in the test barrel caliber you have. Load powder to MATCH the velocity of civil war weapons as close as possible. a very small amount of polyester pillow fill pushed up against the powder charge in the longer case will help consistent velocities. the rifling twist might be too fast also. the 1854 En field had a 1 in 32 twist (1 in 36?) as did the Springfield 1861. i used imr 4756 with small bits of pillow fill pressed on top of the charge to get sub-sonic vel. and superb accuracy out to 50 yds in 30-06 130 grain flatbase. also worked very well in 243 win and remington 22-250 (52 gr match hollow pt.). these loads were deadly on squirrels and highly illegal and dangerous if you miss with the 130 gr and 70 gr 243.

2 things to consider. Modern lead bullets have other metals added to make them harder then normal lead. May try getting pure lead and casting your own bullets. Also try using actual black powder or black powder substitute instead of smokeless powder. Black powder has a significantly slower burner time which will reduce velocity while still having enough gas expansion to get the projectile to clear the barrel. These are 2 things worth considering and experimenting with

Black powder has a much faster burn rate when confined, it has higher peak pressures so you can't load as much without blowing up the gun, smokeless powder is slower, allowing for lower peak pressures while maintaining higher average pressures. This is the reason black powder loads are slower than smokeless. You would be correct that black powder should be used not not on the reason.

Excellent work and I'm glad nobody got hurt thanks to all of the safety procedures put in place. Judging from how each of the projectiles shatter on impact,  it appears to be a matter of material hardness. More specifically the projectiles disintegrate from being too hard and brittle vs the Civil War example fusing together due to it being softer and more ductile. There's a channel called Crazy Hydraulic Press that puts various objects and materials in a 100 ton Hydraulic Press to see how they compare, such as an old sledgehammer vs a new chinese one. SPOILERS The chinese hammer deforms and presses down like play dough in a rather linear, consistent manner. The old hammer doesn't budge until around 300 tons, then it explodes violently. They have high speed cameras on it to show a slowed-down replay to better examine how it happens too. Softer materials will have smoother deformation, which is the desired result here.  For a simple comparison, try shearing the head off of a class 4.8 bolt vs a class 10.9 one of the same size and examining them under the microscope. The 4.8 bolt's distortion at the separation point will be longer and smoother, while the 10.9 will look considerably more "gritty".

I really like the beauty of the collisions when they are aligned, and the copper jacket splits into symmetrically-oriented ribbons that eject outward.  The lack of fusion got me thinking about velocities, temperature, and material properties. Now that I think about it, temperature might just be related to velocity at impact.  More velocity is more energy to convert into deformation, sound, heat.  To make them fuse, we need not so much rebound upon contact, so a softer material might work better, like you said.  I also thought about impact mechanics during a meteorite impact.  You never seem to see the impactor because the energy is so high that everything melts and gets distributed as ejecta, etc.  So I guess we want a happy medium in the materials and velocities.  THANKS for getting me thinking about this!!  It is super fun!!

It might not be the metallurgy that's preventing the bonding of the two bullets. Due to the rifling, they are each spinning in opposite directions which is creating shear forces at the interface. The fused balls in the museum were likely shot without rifling and therefore were not rotating against each other at the interface when they met. Suggest you reverse the rifling in one of the guns so that the bullets are rotating the same way when they meet. This would presumably remove the shearing force at the interface?

You need to get your terminology correct. Saying the primer is on the back of the bullet is incorrect. The primer is on the back of the cartridge. The bullet is only the projectile. A cartridge is composed of a case that holds all the components ready to fire. When you have a case with a primer in the back, powder inside and a bullet in the front ready to be loaded into your firearm you have a cartridge.  Your reloading "expert" should have corrected your terminology before you made the video. I don't think much of your expert. I think the rifling might be part of the problem: it creates breaking points - seen when the bullets colliding create perfect flower-petal-like structures. Also: is your rifling the same in both barrels or do the bullets rotate in opposite directions relative to one another? When rotating against each other, a film of fluid metal forms (like with ice skating - just not linearly but rotating). This is also kept fluid as long as the bullets keep rotating. This could be a good thing like with friction welding - but there the two parts are kept aligned firmly by holders. I could not see one case of the bullets stopping their counter rotation in any of the slowmo footage - so if they never stop rotating, the film is alwys there, allowing for easy low friction sliding and never freezing solid. Combined with the introduced breaking points from the rifling (what about polygonal or no rifling?) this might create conditions which are different from the miniÃ© ball situation. Also: are the bullets coated with lubricant?

It's fascinating, also, to see the "football spiral" - that is, the actual rotation of the bullet about the axis-of-travel. This is of course what Minie was trying to achieve, in order to stabilize the bullet during flight (gyroscopically) in order to ensure the bullet maintained a particular front-to-back orientation. I've never seen a recording of it before this. Not to say there aren't any, just I don't recall seeing it. I've seen it in real life, with sufficiently large and slow projectiles (M433 HEDP), but that's a very different experience, and indeed almost the opposite angle.

Guys, two solids, of any materials, like or not, will NEVER fuse from impact alone. For two solids of like materials to fuse, they need to be in an altered state of matter, being either gaseous or liquid at the moment of impact. Then return to solids while the two non solids are still impacting, in order to fuse two solids impacting each other. This is why it's never happened. The closest you can get is if one ballistic shaped solid impacted an oblique solid, they could possibly become lodged under high enough pressure, to SEEM fused... but will actually just be lodged under high pressure, which is what you see with the wallet shot. The material added to the slug can be payed off, without melting, using a razor blade and magnifying glass... because fusion did not occur.

How pure is the lead in bullets? The lead core of jacketed bullets are usually pure lead also, they can be a harder alloy. Cast bullets are usually an alloy. They usually have some tin and antimony for hardness. The amount of tin and antimony depend on how hard the bullets are. Copper jacket would interfere with the merge. The Civil War era bullet perhaps was pure lead produced in a shot tower. Soft lead would be more malleable. cleanliness would also be important.

A few thoughts, The musket balls probably weren't spinning, as muskets did not have rifling in the barrel, so that is another factor in collision dynamics. Black powder loads were typically lower velocity I think than modern smokeless powder generally is. The barrels you are using look pretty beefy, but heat buildup might be a factor in shifting the aim over time as well. It not clear how much time there is between shots so I really have no idea if this has any impact either way. I am assuming your reloading expert is confident in the consistency of the loads, but that should also be ruled out. This whole experiment is fantastic regardless of the misses.

Incredible effort and results. Whole system is working very well. The only issues i could point out are: to much velocity and unfavorable type of lead alloy.  MiniÃ© bullets do compress some, thus they increase their diameter to engage the rifling (muzzle loading), while modern bullets don't do that, because they fly through the throat of the chamber to engage the rifling (breach loading). So my point is that, the lead alloy used for MiniÃ© balls must have more plasticity than today bullets. To reduce the velocities of the bullets, powder burning guns could be replaced by the PCP airgun alikes.

When casting bullets for modern firearms we add tin and antimony to increase hardness.  The principal reason is to minimize lead deposits in the barrel. You might have better luck with softer lead.  Lead flashing is pretty soft.  Cast a few bullets and give them a try.  MiniÃ© ball bullets were also probably a lot heavier than what you're shooting.  At a guess, they were close 450 grains. Your bullets are probably half that size.  Muzzle velocities for MiniÃ© balls were low - on the order of 900fps.

A mini-ball was 58 caliper and about 480 grains, a 45 Colt is 255 grains, the mini-ball is almost twice as much lead. I'm glad the algorithm sent me this video because I'm an easy to please man! I like slow mo shots! Always have, ever since Mythbusters. And this was an additional nice surprise, to hear the term "intellectual humility" within the first five minutes of the video. And you talk about your credentials, and name-drop your colleagues, and the focus on safety designing the experiment. I went "oooOO!" out loud when the little shield slid up on command at 7:20, that's when I was sold! I'm really grateful to see responsible gun owners describing best practices, especially in the context of doing something really cool! It helps reframe the 'safety' debate as less of a "grumpy fun-hating instructor" thing and more of a "strap on your parachute so we can go SKYDIVING, YO!" kind of vibe :)

It's awfully petty of me, I know, but I have to admit I feel a significant amount of vindication seeing you succeed at this. When the Mythbusters called this one "busted," I was absolutely positive at the time they had only demonstrated it was improbable/difficult, not that it couldn't be.

First if you are trying to reproduce the shot and the results that you saw at the Smithsonian; you have to remember that the rifles at the time were 58 or .577 caliber they even had a .69 caliber  muskets. they used Triple Seven FFg loose powder, 90 grains in the .577 caliber muskets. What I have found out that the .577 minie bullet traveled at 950 fps and had a range of approx. 1000 yards, but the ballistic trajectories was a high arch 1000 yards. Most shots were within 50 to 100 yards of there target. As an experiment you could never reproduce these 2 bullets joining head to head like that again in a thousand years. To many variables to predict, like where in the trajectory path did they meet and was it at equal distances from point of origin, were they both the same caliber?  Those straight shots you did with the test equipment you built, could never produce the same results as the Smithsonian bullets on display.

This is one of the coolest videos I think I have seen in a while.  The attention to detail and time you put into your content is amazing.  Keep up the good work.  Civil war era bullets were formed of pure soft lead and some toxic red lead.  Furthermore the variable still remains as to powder load.  Since muskets or black powder rifles were loaded in such a hurry either by powder bag or even what was a prefilled paper cartridge they were never the same as it wasn't always measured or some was spilled.  The velocity of that era's rifle was also significantly lower.  So depending on the range at which each rifle was fired, they could have been at maximum range when they hit.  Most bullets of that era were smaller than the bore for easier, faster loading and very inconsistent.  Some regiments had arms masters and crews that made bullets, buck ball bags etc.  Supply wagons would often bring armory made munitions.  Many soldiers and even rebels had molding kits in their ruck.  They would repurpose lead they found.  Field medics and doctors would often collect lead from wounded and dead soldiers to reuse.  Another variable may be the type of gun used.  The North being made up of mostly organized military regiments would have had government issued equipment.  The South on the other hand was made up up of some organized military but also many settlers, farmers, northern deserters, etc. with their own guns.  Some dating back to the Revolutionary war.  Due to the economic conditions in the South, cheaper guns or even handmade guns were used.  Rifles could be rifled or even smooth bore barrels.  Interestingly enough one of the worst wartime and even post wartime injuries to come from the Civil War was....you guessed it...lead poisoning.  This came from not only wounds but the just the sheer volume soldiers handled on a day to day basis.  FYI.  We have another tractor pull coming up in Lexington, Alabama on August 11 & 12, 2023.  I know the McDaniels you have interviewed on one of your videos.  Hope to see you there.

You are likely looking at four (though some are connected) variables that are causing them not to fuse and only three of them are somewhat easy to solve. 1. Longer barrel in the original meaning more friction for longer and longer exposure to possibly higher temperatures (full loads vs you partial loads mean more heat as well as more velocity) which could have heated up the lead more making it softer. This can't be solved by just making longer barrel. 2. As stated before stronger/hotter load as stated in the point before this could have led to more heat longer causing softer lead. This can be fixed by loading more gun powder into the round. 3. Modern lead is different then old lead. Not only in alloy but also in production a lot of modern rounds are made by pressing metal powder into molds (sometimes with external heat but other times just with the heat of the conpression). Where as old lead was melted and poured into molds. This makes modern lead fragment more. Well more like practicalize. Where as old lead stays together more. This can be fixed by mak8 g your own rounds and trying to get as close as you can to the lead alloy they used back then. 4. Distance. Those rounds likely started out a lot faster but slowed down before meeting this is how you can have a longer barrel abd the needed load to still get the round out of the barrel which also allows for 1 and 2 and the corresponding side effects. This one may be impossible to fix at least on a practical side of things not a technical side of things. First you would have to try and find what the distance was. This is more trial and error after you fix the other issues. And doing this would introduce a bunch of issues that would mean you had to be even more precise in aiming (a nanometer off over 1,000 means a bigger miss then over 5 meters).   All that be8ng said I would start with the lead and go from there. Actually soeak8ng of the lead and back then I just thought of another possible variable. Reuse. They often reused rounds. If these ro7nds had been used more then once in a short time frame they may not have fully cooled from the last use when shoot meaning the outside may have been cool but the inside may have been warm making them softer.   Thinking about it there are really only two variables lead alloy and lead temperatures. Right lead alloy at right temperature thus the right softness add impact and boom fusion.

I want to suggest a theory as to why you found it essentially impossible to fuse the two bullets. The problem is not so much the speed, or the composition of the bullets. It is the shape of the projectiles. The mini balls are just that, balls. The modern bullets are cylinders with blunt or rounded ends. The mass of the lead with the balls keeps the energy focused on the center because of the shape of the projectile. The cylinders want to expand as the lead compresses and splinter outward. Because the ball contains the kinetic energy rather than fragmenting and dissipating it, the focused energy fused the two balls together.

I think you forgot one other factor... Minieballs are .58 caliber, 500 grain bullets.  54 Long Colt are .45 caliber, 255 grain bullets.  Miniballs have more potential energy holding together due to their inherent mass, so it takes more kinetic energy for them to blast apart.  The bullets in the exhibited lost a lot of their kinetic due to being at extreme range, speed getting bled off by wind resistance until impact.   This also explain why the wallet let you fuse the buallets... it absorbed just enough of the kinetic energy of the bullets to let them fuse without disentegrating.

I did not go through all of the comments (there's too many of them!), BUT!  Let me throw out a couple of ideas.      I think that there are a few differences between your experiment and the display you saw at the Smithsonian.         First: Velocity. The differences between modern day gunpowder and the ahem "Gunpowder" used during the American Civil War would be too numerous to even attempt to list here, let's just say that there's a bunch of them.  (Differences in grade, composition,  even in moisture, etc. etc.)  Second: The same applies to the "lead" used in the bullets.  The quality/grade used surely varied wildly from one batch made in Georgia in the 1800's,  and another batch made in Pennsylvania. Add to that the differences between what was being used one-hundred and fifty years ago and today. Third: Size, shape and weight of the round. Today's munitions are vastly different than the relatively primitive ammo of the 1800's, none of which were jacketed btw, which I'm certain is one of your problems as well.   There's more, (including the way that you're aiming the two at each other) but that's enough for now.    Good luck!

Im thinking your biggest problem with getting them to fuze is not the lead or the copper or how much powder you use, its the type of powder. Black powder doesn't burn in an explosion, it burns more in a conflagration. Its a slow (relative to smokeless powder) burn down a long barrel. The projectile speeds were lower then what you can get out of your smokeless short barreled guns. Remember, they used expanding miniballs meaning the miniballs were smaller then the rifling on the barrel and only fit the barrel once the powder went off and expanded the back of the miniball. Lot less friction meaning the projectile speeds didnt need to be as high to get the bullet to its destination.  At the end there yeah i think the aluminum slowed them down, but i think it also acted like a mold for the exploding lead and held it all together till it solidified together.

when dealing with explosives in general, you actually want a little expansion room for the gasses to expand. this is why a gas tank that is completely full will create a MUCH smaller explosion than one that is nearly empty, same goes with pretty much any kind of modern bullet, grenades, pipe bombs etc. literally saw this explained on bill nye the science guy when i was a kid. the reason you're having issues with the bullets disintegrating is too much velocity, you are using modern bullets that utilize smokeless powder as opposed to older, much larger, much heavier bullets that utilized black powder, a much slower burning propellant. if you want the miniball results... use miniballs, thats not exactly rocket science.

Love the video.  Noticed one thing.  The historical bullets were fired in December in Virginia.  Their initial temperature could have been as low as 20 degrees F.  You tested in summer.  Could have been 80.  That 60 degree initial temp may have made a difference.  The interior of each bullet would have remained cold while the exterior was heated due to firing and friction in the rifle.  The colder bullets may have heated (due to impact) just to the point where they deformed and not to a point where they developed weakness and shattered.  Just a thought.

While it looks like it stopped in mid-air, it's only for a split second due to the high speed camera capture.  If you watched in real time, it'd be over in a blink of an eye.  Nevertheless it's really cool.    When a bullet hits a hard object it creates heat due to deceleration and friction.  With two bullets colliding it would have been interesting to see the heat flash using an infrared camera. ;)

When the kinetic energy in the collision exceeds the binding energy of the masses colliding, it *will* disintegrate. Same reason why high-energy moon impact craters are all circular, regardless of the impact angle.  So yes, you're going too fast for that kind of alloy.

I'm way behind on watching this video because I was out of town for the military, but I would like to share some firearms information with you if it hasn't been done already.  That section of the chamber where there is no rifling and gases are escaping around it is called "freebore." This is actually the primary difference between .223 and 5.56 ammunition. One has a couple thousandths of an inch more freebore than the other, which results in accuracy issues. Exactly what you are seeing here.  It'll be my luck that you say all of this later in the video, because I paused to make this comment right as you were talking about accuracy issues due to the projectile not engaging the rifling right away.

The video is truly great. Your setup is almost as it would have been. On the battlefield were some trees. It is likely that the bullets entered the limb of a tree. Based on my experience with lumber, the tree limb was about 2 inches in diameter. The bullets entered the limb from the north and south.  As shown in the video, the exploding force of impact causes a debris circle. If the bullets had met inside the tree limb, it would have contained the particles. The heat of impact would have fused the bullets into the single object. After the impact, the contained object would have remained at the impact site. However, the tree limb will have lost the ability to remain intact. Gravity would have pulled the outer part of the limb to the ground. The new object is likely to have stayed in the inner part of the limb. The local forces would not have caused much movement. After the battle, the field clean up crew would arrive. During the (likely undocumented) cleanup, a person would have found the lead object sticking to the broken limb, very likely at eye level. They would have removed the object and showed it later to others. They might not have recorded the location of their discovery. Thanks for making us smarter!

I dont know what kind of bullets you were loading aside from the bullet styles, but from the intro it sounded like they were store bought. I am sure you are already aware, but store bought non-jacketed bullets have a protective coating to the lead to reduce lead exposure in both handling of the bullets as well as to reduce how much lead is vaporized and sent into the air when the cartridge is fired. If I had to guess, that protective coating might be a notable factor to why the bullets are colliding with each other but are not becoming fused together since it could be acting as a barrier between the two. If you decide to give this a try again, I think it would be worth hand casting the bullets or finding a way to clean off the protective coating on the store bought non-jacketed lead bullets before shooting them at each other.   The other thing that might be worth trying is to use the longer hard cast bullets in the cartridges (similar to the bear protection cartridges for example) instead of what I presume is the standard .45 long colt bullet dimensions. I think that the extra mass due to the longer bullet dimensions and harder metal might increase the chances of the bullets fusing by extending the length of time both bullets are colliding (generating more heat through more mass) and the harder metal might help reduce the percentage of the bullets that is sent away from the impact as fragments (may cause the bullets to fragment more).

I have a Hypothesis on what the problem is with the bullets not fusing. The speed at which the bullets are traveling and the rotation of the bullets when they collide would cause the lead to melt and disintegrate upon impact. If only one bullet was traveling towards a stationary bullet the impact would be half the velocity of the two traveling at the same time. The two bullets you saw in the museum could have an embellished story behind them, or they were shot at such a distance from one another, that the speed was slow enough to not cause the lead to completely melt upon impact. I would check the velocity of a muzzle loader to know what the speed of the bullets are, and I would also remove the rifling in the barrels to stop the spin of the bullets. Lead melts at 621.5 deg Fahrenheit, so I believe the bullets at the velocity they are traveling would generate to much heat on impact to fuse like the two in the museum. It's just a thought. The mini balls were made of almost pure lead and were fired by black powder rifles. Pure lead bullets can not be used with modern smokeless powder. They are too soft. The lead you are using is likely what is known as "hard cast" lead - 6% tin, 2%antimony, and 92% lead. Can be purchased in ingots for the homebrew caster. It is also the industry standard if you as buying store bullets.  The bullets you are using are brittle, which is why you see so much fragmentation.  You will need to use black powder and pure lead if you want to see the bullets fuse on impact.
I second this

I just read that bullet surface temps can be as high as 500ËšF but this is *surface* temperature. It takes a significant amount of time for that heat to penetrate to any depth of the projectile and the length of flight before impact is usually a 1/10 to 1/2 of a second, more or less. Of course longer flight also allows the heat to dissipate (which is another interesting question in itself).

The bullets also presumably traveled further across the battlefield allowing them to slow even lower that the lower powder levels.  Metallurgy is still an issue, getting samples of similar lead bullets of the era and recasting them in a similar process may lead to similar metallurgy. The reason they weren't fusing seems to be a combination of weight and size. Confederate Era weaponry fired a .6 inch bullet which is significantly larger than your .44 inch. I'm not sure what grain round you used either, but the heavier it is the more energy it carries at the same speed. That can mean more heat upon transfer, which may cause it to join. So long as it's not too great to cause total structural failure, ie shattering. It's a mix and match to find the coefficient of the metals melting point.

Consider getting some sort of gun historian guy on the project. When trying to recreate something that happened in the past, it would be good to have an expert on how the conditions were in that past, to recreate them as best as you can. This means you'd probably greatly benefit from someone with expert knowledge on how rifles and bullets were created during the civil war. He might even have some good tips on how to recreate those conditions, or at least get a close approximation, without sacrificing too much of the neccessary accuracy.

I'm wondering what would happen if you shot two spherical, non-rifled bullets into one another -- musket balls, in other words.  It seems to me that the fact that the two bullets were spinning in (presumably) opposite directions would make it much harder for them to fuse.    Another thing you could try is rifling the barrels in opposite directions -- one clockwise, one counterclockwise.  That means that with the two guns pointing in opposite directions -- i.e., at one another -- the two bullets would be spinning in the same direction when they hit.

Modern lead bullets are made from jacketed antimonial lead.  You can get alloys with various compositions of lead with tin, antimony, and arsenic, all of which will make the bullet harder.  Sometimes, you get trace amounts of copper, silver, calcium, cadmium, zinc, etc.  The trick, in my opinion, would be to get an alloy with near-pure lead with maybe a bit of silver.  Adding silver lowers the melting point and may make the bullets more 'sticky', if you will.  You'd have to have pure lead at the contact point, but that would foul your barrels almost instantly.  I lube the entire bullet, but I guess you can get by with only lubing the sides.  Alternately, you can use a half-jacket.

Here's a little bulletin for you, no pun intended:  it wasn't an impossible shot (or it wouldn't have been made).

Destin, this is great work getting to this point. Really enjoyed the process part of your video. If you are interested, I think I can help progress your efforts to ultimately fuse two bullets in collision flight with some minor modifications to some key parameters. Your electronic firing mechanism is spot on for what it is intended. Adding to that would be closely controlling the bullet velocity to the impact. The powder mix and constancy is key to that. A simple velocity test with a chronometer would confirm the proper mix. That is a specialty of my son and a willing participant in this effort. In addition, the composition if the bullet as well as the shape should be closer to a civil war era bullet for some important physics reasons on the actual fusing of the material. One other aspect that may be important is the relative spin on each bullet. With the same spin from different directions, they are actually spinning in opposition to each other on a common axis. The rate of spin in the civil war era was minimal compared to current ballistic technology. Just slowing that down could help, but putting them on the same direction would eliminate it from the problem. The machining of matching but opposing barrels is also within the capability of my son. If your interested, let me know. We are willing an anxious to help if you want to pursue your dream to the end goal of fused bullets.

@smartereveryday Have you considered trying to fire two bullets using a copper outer with a custom clay inner material. The fusion of the clay may be slightly easier to achieve but there may be some consistency issues. In addition, similar to pencil lead (graphite+clay) the composition of early lead bullets may not have as much lead content due to availability and demand during the civil war.  Also if the sleeve is copper then fusion of two dissimilar metals may make it difficult to achieve the fusion of the two bullets, so the sleeving may make it slightly harder to achieve fusion between the lead inner.  These are just some points for consideration but I am no expert in guns and bullets. Hope this helps with future attempts. Look forward to seeing more of your videos.

Hi, I believe this was the first time I've seen your show, although your shows title sounds familiar, and I really love this one that you did. Bye, you try to fuse 2 bullet slugs by slamming them into each other head on from being fired from rifle barrels. I have always wondered what that would look like with high-speed photography. Awesome! Suggestion - you may want to use slugs made of all Heavy LED or lead iron as they used back in the Civil War. I can tell you the reason why those bullets refuse to fuse. The first reason is too much copper, the second most important reason is that rifles used back in the Civil War. Mostly, they were not rifled. Mostly because rifling just started in that timeline. And most rifles that had rifling was quite often worn smooth due to the inferior slugs they made. In just a short amount of time, thus having smooth barrels very little or no rifling left many times depending on the rifles they were using, so both bullet balls or slugs were not spinning making fusion possible quite often. The bullet slugs you were shooting were fired from rifled barrels, so both bullet slugs were spinning and spinning in opposite direction of each other, thus preventing them from fusing. If you can get the Slugs to hit each other head-on without the spin, you could probably get the fusion to work with bullet slugs you were using. That is why you got a partial fusion when you shot your aluminum wallet. It wasn't the fact of slowing it down, which was part of it. It was due to the fact it's greatly reduced the spin when they collided, thus fusion possible.  Or perhaps having one of the gun barrels rifled in the opposite direction, so both bullets will be spinning in the same direction when they collide. This I'm sure we'll make it possible to fuse. But I'm absolutely sure that you can get the bullets to fuse if you have no spin or minimal amount of spin when they collide. Also, the shape of your slugs would make a difference as well. Because you probably know the bullets that they made themselves back in that time. We're mostly round balls or close to round balls. And back in that time, they were not using shells, of course. Do to packing the gunpowder in and using material to pack in the gunpowder as well as fire cotton which was fast  combustion that allows the powder to ignite better, all these functions would massively heat up these led slugs to a very high temperature as they leave the barrel being surrounded by extremely high temperature explosion and combustion materials throughout the whole barrel. Even partially out of the barrel, which would contribute to extremely heated led slugs, which would definitely contribute to Fusion. These are definite factors to make fusion much more possible other than the spinning of the bullets, which I guarantee you is the main reason for non Fusion.

It occurs to me that ambient temperature has everything to do with this experiment's outcome. The specific heat of Lead is such that, it takes quite a bit of energy to move the thermometer.  However, the melting point is relatively low.  In your spring experiments, your lead was many degrees closer to the melting point than in the case of fusion at the battle of Fredericksburg.   The battle of Fredericksburg took place December 11-15, 1862.  The prevailing daytime temperature (researched in NOAA records, but not actually found by me) was, say, 30 degrees.    If I recall, you are near Huntsville, AL it appears to be spring in your video but you are not obviously sweating.  There is new growth on the trees.  Not sure what month you filmed but (per WeatherUnderground historical data) April 2023 average temps were 74 degrees, and May was 77 so the daytime noon (as determined by shadows observed in the video) temps were roughly 78 and 84 respectively.  I did not note you discussing freezing your leads when you discussed gunpowder loads and lead qualities.  However, I believe that if you cool your rounds down to 20 degrees(and otherwise play with lower temps) so that they are cold-soaked (as soldiers ammo would be exposed to outdoor temps continuously for days) at that temp before loading you would have closer true conditions to include temp which is a variable I don't see that your considered.  Your attempt at slowing the bullet down is a defacto attempt at preventing injection of extra kinetic energy into the Lead which becomes heat energy on impact.  By freezing the Lead you also achieve this goal and also ensure, through some metal contraction, that the lead does not hang in the barrel with low-power loads.  The reason the attempt with the aluminum wallet almost succeeded was probably not that the bullets were slowed, but that the aluminum (a great conductor of heat) absorbed some of the heat energy preventing the lead from fully liquifying and allowing partial fusion.  Of course, this is all just a wild guess.  ;-)

Amazing work. Very well through through.  Aligning the barrels with a laser was spot on.   I can't afford to donate to your patreon channel. But would if I could. So maybe I can lend a hand in the bullet making idea department. The gunsmiths in my family said that early bullets were made with a lower melting point lead of some alloy. Antimony makes it harder and is also used in early lead solder for electronics.  However when you make shotgun slugs out of lead with 60/40 lead-tin solder into the mix it softens the lead alloy a bit. It tends to splatter in a wider circle upon impact. Ergo leaving a larger wound channel in animals that one hunts.  I know the exit holes on door panels, wood, are much wider with softer slugs. Ignoring the lead fouling problem that comes with it. The tin content also explains why the civil war bullets didn't frost over so much as with normal full lead bullets. You can find older electronics with very little corrosion and the lead with tin flexes a bit in high vibration military electronics instead of cracking. (This is a problem with copper-tin solder at first when they switched composition) So my suggestion would be is to make a batch of differing bullets with solder into the mix before pouring the mold.  I would suggest a solid 60Pb/40Sn solder minnie ball or 90/10 lead-tin or a set of various ratios to see which sticks together on impact of each other.

The civil war bullets obviously impacted at a relative angle close to 90Âº and you're shooting at 178Âº. A lower angle would also lower the fragmenting, by redirecting the angle and not bleeding as much (like the inelastic collision that hung in the air).  Changing the angle will be met with its own issues, first of which is recovering the fragments. But if you could adjust it to meet at 90Âº, I think you might get what you're trying for!

First of all i am impressed. Outstanding work. I think i have the solution, why the lead of the bullets evapurates. It has nothing to do with other mixtures during the civil war and actual made bullets. The solution to keep the lead of the two bullets together and make them form a perfect donut ist friction of air. I bett, that the two bullets from the civil war had both at least 50 to 60 meters to travel from their musket muzzels to the meeting point in midair. The round about 100 to 150 m air between the two muzzels causes enough friction to slow both bullets down so much, that the energy in the meeting point was so reduced, that the lead was not foced in such a power, that it evapurated. It keeped together and mingeled even without the helping of your wallet in your test, that stopped the spreading sufficient enougt to keep more than 80 % of both bullets in the leadblock. One night sleep often helps to solve a puzzle. How to slow down the two bullets after they have left the muzzles so much, that the lead will only deform and not spread into thousends of fragments. On way is distance to let the friction of air do the work for you. But a biger distance between the muzzles causes a lot of other problems. So how to get more friction to get the energy out of the bullets? In your film you used plastic or paper cards to measure the way that  the bullets travel after leaving the muzzels.  If you use not one but 10 to 20 paper cards  all about two inch apart? That may cause so much friction that enough energy will be spend going through the paper cards. that the lead will stay together. You need to let the bullets travel about 20 inch before you place the first paper card to slow the bullet down. The space from one card to the next  should be at least 2 inch or you may cause a fire. It is a equation of energy and how to reduce the movement energy of the bullets after they have left the muzzels to the point where they meet in midair.

I was thinking that y'all had been using the wrong kind of powder for the entire first half or two thirds of the video, right up until you filmed yourself surmising that the problem y'all had had to either be the powder or the lead. XD  Back during the civil war, smokeless powder wasn't a thing yet, and wouldn't be a thing for another two decades after the civil war had ended. Smokeless powder combusts with a much higher velocity than black powder does, and so imparts more energy and power to the bullet. That's certainly part of the equation that y'all had figured out during testing.  I wonder if the other part of it was using a more impure lead. Like, I wonder if there could be any historical impurities that would have lent additional ductility to the lead to make it more capable of just melting together into a glob on impact instead of brittle fracturing to pieces.

Ah the old machinists demon strikes again.  From what I learned from the old heads at the paper mill I did my electrical apprenticeship at, I was doing a dual trade in instrumentation, and they used to get wandering calibrations on some of their instruments and it took them a little while to figure out what was going on.  A lot of the control equipment they used was pneumatic actuated and utilised PID control, with all the needle valves and such that go along with that kind of gear. They realised that the anchoring nuts and other bits that were supposed to lock the settings in these instruments were being affected by the general vibrations in the room from electrical motors and pumping equipment, and it was enough to cause some of them to loosen just enough that it would throw out the tuning on the control mechanisms, causing all kinds of headaches with poor and inaccurate readings and automation that wasn't automating.  So, they identified the problem. The solution?  Nail polish.  Usually bright pink or green or something easy to see. They'd put a bead of nail polish on the side of the nut and fasten it to housing so the setting was locked in place, but it was easy enough to remove with nail polish remover if it needed changing. It was perfect solution too because it could stand up to moisture, remained tacky enough to prevent it from cracking, and was a far better option than the various thread locking compounds that were designed for a more permanent bonding solution.  And that's why I now always keep a bottle of nail polish in my garage.

It's all about finding the perfect combination of velocity, mass, and malleability.

The  Minie balls were 58 calibers and 500 grains  with a BC of 160  with a mv of  right around  900 fps  to 1,000  fps  with about 60 grains of black power . That's right at  899.52 fpe  mv  at 900 fps mv   According how far they traveled before they hit each other that could have been  0 yards to up to 250  yards will be the balls fpe on impact  The lead had to produce enough fpe  to fuse together .  If the mv was 900 fps  you are looking at between 900 to 727 fps from 0 to 250 yards  and 899 to 587  fpe from  0 to 250 yards . So Its going to be in that range .   Even at 1,000 yards the bullet is still going  415 fps and still has 191 fpe . I'm guessing the 2 bullets would have had to have been at least 1,000 yards apart   to only mushroom together  . Any closer and they would have exploded the bullets into fragments .      The easiest way to figure this out is to  shoot a 58 caliber pure lead ball with a mv of around 900 fps and shoot at a pure lead plate .   Back then they used pure led so they could  pour it over a open camp fire . Start off at 10 yards  and walk back till you get the ball to mushroom out against the lead plate .   The best way without using gun power  would be to use a 50 caliber  pcp air rifle  that you can change the  mv .with a twist of the dial .  You can dial the  mv   from 1,000 fps down to as slow as it needs to be to make the lead  mushroom together without breaking apart .   Once you know  the mv  and fpe on impact  needed to do this it will be a good start to  making them fuse together .    The pcp air rifles  are very precise and very accurate. With a chronograph you can dial both guns to fire the lead bullets at the same  mv . I think this would be the fastest and cheapest way to  figure out  fpe needed . Because  you can use a pcp that has a built in regulator  each shot  will be the same mv  .   You can take a hundreds shots if you connect the guns to a  carbon tank  that can be refilled on the spot with a pcp air compressor   or just use a few tanks . Its more accurate than gun power .  Talk to the good people at Airforce Airguns they will even help you out to make this happen .   Once you get them to mushroom together  you will know how far away they were  from each other when  both ball were shot. It would be cool to know how far they were from each other  when they both were shooting at each other  . I bet they both wondered why they missed and why they were not  hit from the other  musket . Were they close enough to know they could not have missed ? Did they both think they forgot to load a ball in the heat of the battle ?  Were they feet apart  or 1,000 yards apart ? I wonder if they both  lived to fight another day or did the next reload  end a life .

When I was a kid, maybe 8 or 10, (1957?) Mom took us to Gettysburg Battlefield.  There was a small white wood building, formerly an old farmhouse, I think, that served as a museum at the time.  Just inside there were saveral display cabinets with collections of bullets collected from the battlefields.  There were shoeboxes full of plain minnie ball slugs of different calibers.  In the middle was a small box with maybe 12 to 14 pairs of slugs that hit and fused together in flight.  They were mostly complete, no splattered lead.  The chances of this happening and then being found almost 100 years later meant that there had to be a huge volume of shooting for so many of these to end up here.  The thought of that still haunts me.

I'm only part of the way through the video, but I see one of the problems you are having. Store bought lead bullets will be made of an alloy to make the bullet harder. That makes the bullet more  brittle. You will want to try a pure lead bullet. That will be more maliable and less brittle. It should also be much more likely to fuse together. You could also take some of the guesswork out of your loading procedures by figuring out the muzzle velocity of the rifles that fired the original fuzed bullets, then figuring out what the velocity would be at a distance you would expect for battles of that time. You could then load to that velocity and do your adjustments from there to account for error in the distance and loading estimates. Also, the miniball shape may have played a part in how the bullets folded together.

Someone may have already said this, but your velocity is too high.  To replicate, you probably want to check the velocity of a mini-ball from a black powder rifle, and try to reduce your powder in the casings to try and match the lower velocity.  Too much energy is being expelled at the high speed, and MUST go somewhere...causing the massive shattering.  The ridge wallet effect worked as you added a medium that absorbed energy at impact, equating to lower velocity impact energy.  Another similar effect is firing bullets into water, they will shatter at high speeds and not get very deep.  Reduce the velocity, and they will go farther in water, and they're energy can cause damage deeper.  IE: High velocity rifle ammunition vs bow & arrow fired into water.  Set a foam target in 4 feet of water and see which one make it to the target, and which one disintegrates before making it halfway to the target.

What a great video and narrative!  As an 80 year old physicist with a lifelong interest in ballistics, I have a couple of comments;  The muzzle loading rifles of civil war era used a much different rifling twist than modern ammunition.  The use of hollow base or "mini Ball" bullets rammed down a bore require a much different idea for stabilization.  The lead composition is very, very  soft so that the hollow base can expand to fit the bore tightly and engage the rifling without causing so much loading drag.  Many of the muskets used in civil war time were smooth bore, without any rifling.  Stabilizing the bullets in a smooth bore required a round ball , or in later years a Mini Ball with a hollow base or skirt.  Modern air rifles also achieve stabilization partly through the skirt stabilization.  If you compute the total energy of a bullet, it is not just "1/2 mv squared" of linear energy, but has a rather large rotational energy due to the rifling twist.  In a head on collision, this rotational energy is in opposition for the two bullets,  To achieve true linear energy transfer, you would either have to have the two bullets rotating in opposite vector direction, or not rotating at all.  For reference, a 45 colt is commonly rifled at a 1 turn every 16 inches, wheras the muzzle loading rifles ranged from smooth bore (no twist) to 1 turn every 5 to 10 feet.   My suggestion is to change the rifling to very long twist, in opposition, and use a pure lead bullet if you really want to see a fused bullet.  The other factor is velocity.  Black powder muskets had a typical velocity of 900 to 1000 feet per second, with a low ballistic coefficient, so they would slow down rapidly.  If there were something like 400 yards between the opposing battle lines, the bullets would have been traveling less than half the muzzle velocity at center path collision.  You might try to fire a pure lead bullet at a steel plate and determine the amount of deformation of that bullet then take half the linear energy backed out to velocity as a starting point for your powder charge and velocity starting point.  Modern large bore pneumatic or air rifles might be an easier and more controllable medium to base your configuration on.    Again i want to emphasize what a marvelous presentation you have made!!!

Regarding rifling, I did a couple back-of-the-envelope computations, and if my numbers are correct, standard rifling values actually result in a high amount of rotational energy. Assuming 1000 ft/s linear velocity, 1 turn every 16 inches, and converting to SI units (I rounded numbers a bit):  rifling = 1 rev / 0.38 m linear speed = 300 m/s rot speed = 1 rev / 1.27 ms rot speed = 790 rev/s rot speed (omega) = 125.7 rad/s <== this is incorrect bullet radius (r) = 0.0057 m normal accel = r * omegaÂ² = 90 m/sÂ² (at bullet periphery) => close to 9 g  Therefore, just after impact, molten lead experiments a centrifugal accel as high as 9 g. This may be the main cause for the corona shaped dispersion of molten lead and other bullet fragments. @Blaine Taylor is probably on the right path when he suggests using either a smooth bore or a very long twist value to limit dispersion and to fuse both bullets with each other.  Edit: since 1 rev = 2*Pi radians, the correct maths are:  rifling = 1 rev / 0.38 m linear speed = 300 m/s rot speed = 1 rev / 1.27 ms rot speed = 790 rev/s rot speed (omega) = 4963.7 rad/s bullet radius (r) = 0.0057 m normal accel = r * omegaÂ² = 140440 m/sÂ² (at bullet periphery) => close to 14300 g  The erroneous computation already gave a respectable value with 9 g, but the correct maths show a MIGHTY normal accel value with those 14300 g!

I like the video and would love to see the fusion happen.  I think I may know why you couldn't quite get there.  High-caliber, long-barrel muskets used in the Civil War fired extremely slow rounds.  If you compound that with distance, you could probably have watched those bullets approach each other with the naked eye because they were going so slowly.  Get much larger and longer barrels to remove as much energy from the rounds as possible and increase the distance as much as possible.  Your problem is the linear momentum.  The force required to fire those rounds far exceeds the force required to destroy the round.  You have relatively small caliber pistol rounds.  They don't have the mass to absorb such energy.  Test larger rounds against a stationary, bullet-proof target at the farthest range you can accurately shoot until you find a round that distorts as little as possible on impact.
