could they perhaps "curve the barrels" to simulate distance or somehow reduce the destructive impact of being so close? (not a physicist)

Â @raidermaxx2324Â  Just load the cartridges with a smaller quantity of  less dense powder w/ a heavier bullet. .45 Colt wasn't the best choice for this test because it is a naturally spacious cartridge, being designed for black powder. If you loaded a .45LC full of an appropriate smokeless powder your average .45LC revolver would explode, and we want slower not faster. The bullets designed for .45LC are usually in the 250gr range at between 950 and 1100fps from a revolver barrel, depending on the load. You could soft-cast a 500gr+ .45-70 bullet, then swage it down from .457 to .452, and fire it at only 600fps (or less). This would take up the excess room in the case with the larger bullet (consistant velocity) and help reduce the velocity (heavier projectile, less propellant). It would also increase the projectile length, allowing the bullet more time to splash everywhere and decelerate before running out of bullet. Remember, if both guns are firing at 1000fps, impact velocity is 2000fps (assuming minimal deceleration, we're at point blank here.) KE=1/2MV^2. Kinetic energy scales with the square of the velocity, meaning that 2000fps has 4x the KE of 1000fps. Reducing the velocity is key here.
Â @holl0918Â  what would "curving both  barrels" do,  as opposed to having two straight barrels pointed at each other? Any effect on physics you think ?

Â @raidermaxx2324Â  It would reduce the velocity due to the added friction of the bullet pressing against the barrel walls and deforming. The barrel would have to be made thicker than usual to handle the excess stress all concentrated along the outside of the curve, otherwise the pressure imballance would just punch a hole in the barrel. The bullet would exit the barrel slightly bent, and would travel in a strait line as soon as it left the barrel as there is no longer anything forcing it to change direction. Think of a ball or a yoyo on a string. If you spin it around your head and let it go, it will just fly strait off in whatever direction it what traveling at the time you released the string. The bullet would do the same, traveling strait out the muzzle just as in a strait barrel... at least until the air resistance acting on the slight bend imparted by the curvature of the barrel and the spin from the rifling cause it to destabilize and tumble. It would accomplish the task of reducing the velocity, but introduce a whole bunch of much more unpredictable engineering hurdles.

Â @raidermaxx2324Â  carbon fiber (CF) is only super strong under tension, not compression. You can pull on CF super hard (like in a cable for a space elevator, not that it's actually strong enough for that, but is stronger than steel in that way) and it'll be fine, but if you hit it with a hammer without even really going for it and it shatters. Of course that is more true of traditional weaved CF than the forged CF my wallet has, but still applies to each individual bit of forged CF where the fibers are oriented roughly in the same directly as they all are in the weaved variety, and the part that isn't fiber, is just still resin / plastic in both. CF is much more like a super strong string / rope that we then embed in plastic to use for 3D objects to make them better under tension than steel, but under compression, it's still just plastic and the side of that same super strong string / rope.

Your velocity might be too high. Normally .45 Colt is fired through a revolver, which has a gap between the barrel and the cylinder, allowing some gases to escape. your rig has a solid chamber and barrel, so there's no bleed off. Also, revolvers have a forcing cone that acts like a funnel for the bullet to squeeze down to just above the bore size, so the bullet can bite into the rifling. The forcing cone and the rifling add friction, which also slows the bullet down. This also allows for different tolerances from the machining process, no two barrels are identical. Longer barrels can actually slow bullets, depending on how the ammo was loaded, which is why a lot of precision shooters use custom loads for their guns.  During the Civil War, the soldiers were 80-100 yards from each other, which could slow the bullets down some. When you have hundreds of soldiers shooting nearly simultaneously at each other, weird things happen. If you're not first, you're last. It was the Quick or the Dead.

There are a few things. On both sides of the late Civil War, soldiers used British Enfield musket rifles and Springfield musket rifles. The South used paper cartridges supplied by the British with a Pritchett hollow based bullet or a minie style bullet, also hollow based. The cartridges were loaded with 60 grains of musket powder. The way the Minie bullet works, the base of the bullet flares out upon firing to engage the rifling and mostly seal the gases so it's more efficient. The bullet is also very stable from the shape of the bullet and the gyroscopic effect from the rifling. The bullet is going about 1000 fps. The bullets they used were also pure lead.  Modern cast bullets have some other metals mixed in like tin and antimony, so the bullets are harder on the Rockwell scale, which also makes them brittle. Hard bullets fragment when they hit hard objects, like steel plates or other hard bullets going the same speed. Pure lead bullets can be deformed by dropping them from waist height on concrete or even hard wood.  Another option to .45 Colt would be .45 Schofield, which uses a case about an eight of an inch shorter. The reason they call .45 Colt "Long Colt" is the US Army fielded Colt Single Action Army revolvers and supplemented them with Smith and Wesson revolvers, designed by a guy named Schofield. For some reason (maybe the weaker frame design?) they made the Schofield ammo a little bit shorter. So if you had a Colt revolver, it could chamber either round, but the Smith and Wesson couldn't chamber .45 Colt, so soldiers started calling the .45 Colt round .45 "Long Colt".  Of course during the Civil War, they used blackpowder, which has different properties than modern smokeless powder. Blackpowder requires compression with no air space between the projectile and the powder or it becomes explosive instead of a propellant. Smokeless powder increases chamber pressure if you compress the powder with the bullet, so you want a gap between powder and bullet. Different smokeless powders have different burn rates and different primers have different ignition times.

In order to do this safely and correctly, you professionals took the most dangerous and least effective path to your goal.  A.  You built an open air facility to photograph the phenomenon.  The better course of action would have been to place the barrels a few inches apart and completely enclose the impact zone in a printed plastic enclosure.  The barrels could themselves be printed by using one long boring tube that builds both barrels out of the enclosure itself.  This achieves two things.  The barrels are perfectly aligned to each other and they are reproducible out of polycarbonate thermoplastic.  If you damage the chamber, you simply print and bore out another.  B.  The high speed must be inside the enclosure in order to capture the phenomenon.  It's lens must be protect from impact.  A large polycarbonate protection filter can be placed in front of the lends that would protect the camera from shrapnel exposure.  C.  You can light the reaction space using silicon carbide LED's with white cap filters.  This will illuminate the space.

If you use historically accurate blsck powder it burns MUCH slower and accelerates the bullet through the barrel. The highest speed will be as it exits the barrel. So you get a slow speed without the bullet getting stuck in the barrel. Its common for black powder guns to fire bits of unburned powder out the end of the barrel if you put too much powder in.. When that happens the bullet starts to loose power since the excess powder is absorbing some of the energy.  For your project precisely timing a slow burn with black powder may not be posdible however.

When I was in elementary, we had a civil war historian come to our school and show us just how devatstating a musket ball could be. I couldnt believe how large a hole a musket ball left in a piece of 2x4. I remember the historian said, "musket rounds often left a wound  exponentially larger than the circumference of the round itself. That was interesting to me, because I always thought the round would leave a hole the size of the actual round itself. I was flabbergasted when he showed an actual musket round vs a simple 2x4 and the hole it left was around DOUBLE the circumference of the musket ball's size!

In order to recreate the phenomenon of two bullets being attached to each other as it supposedly happened 100 years ago or whenever it occurred, you would need to position the two guns at a certain distance. I'm not sure about the exact engineering requirements, but as soon as I understood what you were planning to do, I realized it was impossible. When guns are too close and they collide, they can disintegrate like powder. However, if the guns are positioned at a distance, the bullets would lose speed and cool down, which is the principle behind achieving the attachment of two bullets!

Came here to mention similar. Minie balls used pure lead so they could fire form to the rifling. Modern bullets use lead plus a composition of several other substances like antimony, tin, arsenic, etc. The 45LC is commonly a "hard cast" lead bullet which is full of other things than just lead. To get a fusion, you need pure lead boolits. I've done it once with soft lead 22 caliber bullets inside a bullet trap. Composite lead will do what we saw here - shatter. It's too hard and not malleable.

1972, I was in training at Ft. Lee VA.  I went to the Battle of the Crater, Battlefield.  There was a small Enclosed Museum and office. On one shelf was mabey a few dozen impacted  projectiles, stuck together, there were also afew boxes of others on the shelf... The Lady in the office said that people visiting the site over the years have found most of the bullets while walking around the monument.  I asked if the stuck together bullets had been caused by the explosion which made the crater.  She said that there were some crates of bullets which had been blown up by that blast.. And had been ruined or scattered and others had been found.. However those had been gathered by the government as we went to war with Germany. I came away with an amazing insight into the ferocity of the fighting before the blast...

A few variables to consider to make the fusion actually work: - what kind of air conditions existed in Vicksburg on that day (humidity, air pressure, etc.)? Might be difficult to find out this information, but you could use an average weather for that time of the year in that location. - how far apart were the combatants firing from? Should be able to find out the average distance battle lines were drawn up during that battle. Your setup may have been too close, not allowing speed to bleed off before contact. - What bullet type was used in the original fusion? Was it a muzzle-loaded round or a case-fired bullet?

You might want to cast your own bullets out of pure lead.  Modern casting lead contains a few percent antimony, which makes the bullet harder in order to cut down on barrel fouling.  The softer your bullets, the likelier they are to fuse mid-air instead of fragmenting.

Destin, great video. As usual, it was both entertaining and educational. I have a couple suggestions on how to make your two bullets fuse together, since I have a fair amount of experience in testing bullets against various objects.   - Velocity needs to be lower, but consistent. To that end I suggest asking your reloading friend to use Trail Boss powder; it's specifically made for larger capacity cases like the 45 Long Colt - it is a low density powder so that you get good case fill with more consistent velocity. You can safely use a full case of Trail Boss, but you'll want to use significantly less for this experiment.  - I recommend targeting about 500-550 fps; below that you probably will have too much trouble with consistent velocity. It might be worth measuring velocity from each barrel individually; they may not be the same. You also could adjust crimps and seating depth to get the most consistent values. (Some chronographs, like the CED ProChrono DLX, will send the data straight to your smartphone and give you statistics like standard deviation right there.) - Lead alloy needs to be as close to pure lead as you can get, to keep it malleable. If your reloading friend wants to cast the bullets from pure lead, he'll need to set the pot temperature hotter than usual to get the bullets to fill out well in the mold, or add a tiny percentage (less than 0.5%) of tin. Be aware that too much tin and/or antimony make the alloy less malleable, which is why your bullets shatter rather than fusing together. - If you want to use commercial bullets, buy muzzle loader bullets; these are typically pure or nearly pure lead, much like an old Minie ball. Another option is to use muzzle loader round balls, either .452" or a larger diameter sized down for more bearing surface. These are also nearly pure lead and should fuse together better than the bullets you tried in the video above. If nothing else, these will expand and come apart on contact in a different way than the more brittle hard cast bullets; I expect you'll see more of a "splash" and less "shatter" if that makes sense.  I hope that helps!

I don't comment on yt videos, but I feel like I have to get this out there so smart people than me can disprove it.   I think the two bullets fused together because they melted the aluminum just enough to be the bonding agent.   Those look to be led rounds and not full metal jacket. Led has a melting point around 1900degC and aluminum around 650degC. The two around hitting the thin aluminum from both sides at the same time transferred enough kinetic energy to melt or soften the aluminum just enough to fuse the bullets at the contact point.   This may work better with a full metal jacket round since copper metals around 330degC. The thin layer on the rounds themselves is not enough and fragments too fast to provide enough material for the fusion.   However a fmj round shot at aluminum (or copper) the same way might give a more consistent result due lower melting points of the metals, and a larger surface area (aluminum or copper) of the sheet (wallet) providing more material as the bonding agent.   TLDR: the kinetic energy from the two rounds coming in contact with the aluminum at the same time may have melted and then fused the two rounds together.

There is one more variable that I think needs to be considered for getting the bullets to fuse like you wanted.   Civil War Era long arms wouldn't be used at such  short distances from each other.  These weapons were mostly muzzle loaded and took an experienced soldier about 20 seconds to reload.  If you were close enough to just rush the front line in under 20 seconds,  they wouldn't order to fire, they'd call for a bayonet charge.  The fused bullets were probably fired from much farther apart, giving air friction time to bleed out energy before impact,  much like how they lost energy when traveling through your wallet. To get a similar effect without increasing the distance you would need something to create drag on the bullets, but that might make aiming more difficult just increasing the distance.  The only thing I could come up with was using a ballistic gel target, but the impact interface will certainly mess with the shot...

Id like a statistician to calculate the odds  of how many shots need to be fired to expect to have at least one mid air bullet collision, precise enough for them to stick together during  the civil war. Say, 2 lines of 500 men a piece, on level ground, 200(?) yards apart, all shooting 3(?) shots a min at each other (rate of a muzzle loader?).  This sounds perfect for r/theydidthemath. I would start with finding  the area of the targets, and divide them by the area of the tip of a bullet. After that, see how much time it takes a bullet to make it from one side to the other, (and vice versa would be the same). Then, multiply the odds of a shot being fired from each side within the same time it takes to cover the distance (so the two fired simultaneously would be in the air at the same time) by the number of possible points of impact.   I could plug in some numbers and see what I come up with, but i wonder if anyone will read this and immediately find a flaw with my method?
i told you he has a twin brother 2:21

Heres what i came up with. Civil war rifles: 1500fps(more like 1200-1400, but lets just say), .75 cal bullets  2 sides in lines of 500 each, facing each other 200 yrds apart (effective range 200-400yds)  Each man is 6', and averages 2' wide. All standing shoulder to shoulder like a wall, all shots targeted and hit this 'wall'.  Given the speed and distance, the bullets actually take .4 of a second to cover the 200yd gap, 1000 men firing muzzle loaders at 3 rounds a min equals 3000 shots per minute.   Area of each man wall divided by possible shot placements with no overlap is is almost 2m possible points of impact(or possible  trajectories).   Ill save you all the numbers, but amazingly with that rate of fire(3 per min each) times 1000 men means at any given time theres an average of 20 bullets in flight, 10 from each side. There's 4 chances per second it could theoretically happen.  Ill spare you all the numbers, but i came up with a mid air bullet collision is around 1:9.5 trillion.   I could be off by a factor of 100, and it would still be amazing. Its probably a higher number than that, this was 2 bullets coliding within the same square inch (not dead on), soldiers don't stand broadside shoulder to shoulder towards the enemy, musket accuracy was abysmal, i averaged and assumed numbers/times/distances/sizes, etc. Yet it still happened, at least once by accident(that we know of, with the certainty of having recovered the fused bullets) and at least once for yt lol. Seeing the original 2 bullets that collided at the Gettysburg Museum of History was pretty spectacular.   It was a Union 3 ring bullet and a confederate 2 ring bullet that hit mid-air and fused together. These ring bullets were different from the ball bullets that were quite common in that time period. The ring bullets look very similar to today's bullets with a conical nose and rectangular body and were used versus the ball bullets as the conical shape of the ringed bullets made for much better accuracy, stability and range. Try using less powder for a slower muzzle velocity guys. Higher velocity results in more fragmentation as the lead is unable to maintain it's structural integrity as the kinetic energy of each projectile is absorbed by it's opposite and re-directed perpendicular to it's original vector in the form of a pressure wave of heat. Lower velocity = less heat and pressure at impact, less heat and pressure at impact = lower terminal heat in each projectile. Less heat = more material cohesion = less fragmnetation.  Think of each bullet as an anvil from the perspective of the other bullet, and the powder charge as the hammer smashing it into the anvil:  If you want to shatter the bullet against the anvil, you'd pick the biggest sledge hammer in your toolbox with the longest handle and you'd wack that bullet with it as hard as you could. Lead is extremely ductile at room tempeture. The melting point of lead is only 621 degrees F. when you hit the bullet with your giant steel sledgehammer against a giant steel anvil, most of the energy in the head of the hammer is going to be transferred into the anvil after passing through the bullet.   The "lost" energy will go into plastic deformation of the bullet in the form of heat caused by the impact of the hammer and the pressure wave this creates as it compresses first the bullet, then the anvil. If this heat is high enough, the bullet will fragment as the lead is stressed past the limits of Pb's elastic and then plastic deformation point (yield point) under loading. These limits are dictated by a combination of the material properties of the Pb bullet, It's mass and initial temperture, the amount of energy put into the system, the time over which this energy is delived, the direction from which it comes (vector) and the geometric shape of the bullet. If the loading (energy) comes axially and symmetrically, and heats up the bullet enough, it will first permenantly deform past it's elastic limit, then litterally dis-integrate past it's plastic limit due to thermal and mechanical stress as it transfers as much of the hammer's energy into the anvil as it's capable of transferring before structural failure.   In this case structual failure occurs through fragmentation / shattering.   If you want to deform the bullet without shattering it, you need to put less energy into the system. The aluminum wallet absorbed enough energy from the projectile(s) to allow them to partially fuse rather than completely shatter. You need to load the Pb above it's yeild point to achieve ductile failure, but below it's plastic deformation limit.  There is a wide margin between plastic deformation and complete structural failure in ductile materials like lead. It's within this margin that those two civil war bullets fused instead of shattering. What's truly amazing is that they were fired on a battlefield at almost perfectly recipricol balistic trajectories, meeting at what appears to be the apex of both projectile's flight, with perfectly symmetrical / reciprocol azimuths and elevations.  Very spooky - but given the number of combatants (over 200,000) and the number of bullets flying (hundreds of millions ) in a relatively small area ( 5 mile front defined by the Rappahaunic River) it's certainly not impossible. My guess is that the fused bullets came from oposing firing Minie balls hundreds of yards from one another more or less simultaneiously.   At the start of the battle the armies squared off a mile or so apart from each other over the river, and no doubt millions of bullets were fired at the start of the battle by each side as they closed with each other. The real question is where the fused bullets were found exactly. That might give some clue as to the range at which they were fired, and thus the energy with which they met. If S.E.D. can replicate the fusion through energy management, they should be able make an educated forensic guess as to how far apart the guns that fired them were, and that might narrow down where the bullets came from. Fascinating, yet very flawed approach.  You are using 20th century firearms, ignition, and projectile technology in an attempt to replicate a 19th century phenomenon which used 18th and 19th Century firearms, ignition and projectile technology.  - Civil war era firearms all used Black Powder. Modern smokeless powder was not invented until the 1890's.  - A great percentage of Civil War long guns and pistols used muzzle loaded projectiles. In fact, many of the long guns were muskets, which shot  cloth patched round balls through smooth bore barrels. Muskets have no rifling to set the projectile spinning.. - Most modern "Lead" ammunition is not pure lead. It is a lead and antimony mix, which stiffens and hardens the bullet, making it more likely to fragment upon contact with something hard, like bone....or another bullet!  Hopes this information helps.

I recall seeing a photo from a museum of a civil war .58 musket, can't remember if it was Union or Confederate. Any way it had a burst barrel with a few inch  section missing from the impact pressure and you could see two Minnie bullets facing one another not quite touching through the shrapnel window. The theory was the moment a soldier raised his rifle and fired an opposing man at arms also discharged his weapon milliseconds earlier and the holder of the burst barrel caught the enemy's bullet in his bore and the resulting pressure shock wave  popped a finger sized fragment from the barrel exposing the projectiles. But the most memorable photo was of a poor Union soldier's weapon who  on guard duty, he was killed instantly by a lightening strike and his melted and contorted Springfield rifle and bayonet was also on display in a museum somewhere.

The two fused bullets in the Smithsonian may be .58 caliber minie balls, which were mostly cast from pure lead, without the hardeners used in modern lead bullets. (Zinc, tin and antimony are used to harden the lead in order to prevent "leading" of the rifling.)  But the minie balls of the civil war rifled muskets, such as the .58 Springfield and the .577 Enfield, used a 530-grain bullet with a hollow base to create obturation when the black powder charge behind it exploded, causing the soft lead skirt of the hollow base to spread into the rifling, sealing the expanding gas (obturation).   Your bullets may be shattering like glass because they contain modern hardening agents.

I'm sure there are multiple things to look at changing, but I'm thinking the rifling is actually working against you here. Having them spinning in opposite directions adds a sheering force that has to be overcome to get the bullets to fuse. I would suggest either using a smooth bore without rifling, or alternate the rifling (IE North gun spirals clockwise and South gun spirals counter-clockwise) so that they are spinning in the same direction as they collide. Great video! I've seen a couple of those fused bullets in museums, they are really amazing artifacts. You may already have this all figured out, but I had a few thoughts on why the bullets didn't fuse. I know a bit about Civil War era guns, though I'm not an expert. One issue is the bullets you are firing are way too light. I just weighed a couple original Civil War Mine balls I have, and they were 30-32 grams. I've read online they were 34 grams (that's for the 1853 Enfield). The other is your gunpowder. Looks like you were using modern smokeless black powder which is far more powerful than the black powder used at the time of the Civil War. It's a harder to find the old style of black powder (I have a replica Enfield I've never fired because I haven't got my hands on the right powder yet). But Civil War reenactors use it all the time, so it's definitely out there. Infantry manuals gave precise instructions of how much powder to load in the paper cartridges, so that should get you pretty close to the load that you need. Perhaps the lead composition may be different, but I would definitely start by addressing those issues first.   Looking forward to part 2 to where you get the bullets to stick!

At CERN LHC they do this with protons moving at the speed of light. There are about 100 billion protons going in each direction, confined to a beam width of 0.001 mm, producing about 20 collisions per crossing. Then they repeat the process 40 million times per second (25 ns between crossings), generating a billion collisions per second, continuously, for up to 20 hours. The impact point is surrounded with concentric cylinders of detectors to identify the outgoing products, generating millions of data values (25 Mb) per crossing, making about 1 Pb per second. All the data is filtered in real time to identify interesting patterns and save them to disc.

Or, try using less powder for a slower muzzle velocity. Higher velocity results in more fragmentation as the lead is unable to maintain it's structural integrity as the kinetic energy of each projectile is absorbed by it's opposite and re-directed perpendicular to it's original vector in the form of a pressure wave of heat. Lower velocity = less heat and pressure at impact, less heat and pressure at impact = lower terminal heat in each projectile. Less heat = more material cohesion = less fragmnetation.  Think of each bullet as an anvil from the perspective of the other bullet, and the powder charge as the hammer smashing it into the anvil:  If you want to shatter the bullet against the anvil, you'd pick the biggest sledge hammer in your toolbox with the longest handle and you'd that bullet it as hard as you could. Lead is extremely ductile at room tempeture. The melting point of lead is only 621 degrees F. when you hit the bullet with your giant steel sledgehammer against a giant steel anvil, most of the energy in the head of the hammer is going to be transferred into the anvil after passing through the bullet.   The "lost" energy will go into plastic deformation of the bullet in the form of heat caused by the impact of the hammer and the pressure wave this creates as it compresses first the bullet, then the anvil. If this heat is high enough, the bullet will fragment as the lead is stressed past the limits of Pb's elastic and then plastic deformation point (yield point) under loading. These limits are dictated by a combination of the material properties of the Pb bullet, It's mass and initial temperture, the amount of energy put into the system, the time over which this energy is delived, the direction from which it comes (vector) and the geometric shape of the bullet. If the loading (energy) comes axially and symmetrically, and heats up the bullet enough, it will first permenantly deform past it's elastic limit, then litterally dis-integrate past it's plastic limit due to thermal and mechanical stress as it transfers as much of the hammer's energy into the anvil as it's capable of transferring before structural failure.   In this case structual failure occurs through fragmentation / shattering. What if you want to deform the bullet without shattering it, you need to put less energy into the system. You need to load the material above it's yeild point to achieve ductile failure, but below it's plastic deformation limit.  Fortunately, there is a wide margin between plastic deformation and complete structural failure in ductile materials like lead. It's within this margin that those two civil war bullets fused instead of shattering. What's truly amazing is that they were fired on a battlefield at almost perfectly recipricol balistic trajectories, meeting at what appears to be the apex of both projectile's flight, with perfectly symmetrical / reciprocol azimuths and elevations.  Very spooky - but given the number of combatants (over 200,000) and the number of bullets flying (hundreds of millions) in a relatively small area ( 5 mile front defined by the Rappahaunic River) it's certainly not impossible. My guess is that the fused bullets came from oposing firing Minie balls hundreds of yards from one another more or less simultaneiously.   At the start of the battle the armies squared off a mile or so apart from each other over the river, and no doubt millions of bullets were fired at the start of the battle by each side as they closed with each other. The real question is where the fused bullet found exactly. That might give some clue as to the range at which they were fired, and thus the energy with which they met. If SED can replicate the fusion through energy management, they should be able make an educated forensic guess as to how far apart the guns that fired them were, and that might narrow down where the bullets came from.

Â @elementalist1984Â  I suspect S.E.D's bullets partially fused because the aluminum wallet absorbed just enough energy from each projectile before catastrophic failure to allow them  to partially fuse.  Aluminum is a soft ductile metal. This is why it's used to manufacture the beer cans we love so much and other lesser but useful objects through forming, pressing and extruding manufacturing processes. Al has a much higher melting point (double) and electrical conductivity than Pb and is much less dense. The thermal (heat) conductivity of aluminum is where things get really interesting - it's almost an order of magnitude (10x) greater than that of lead.   Kinetic energy and heat are interchangeable object  properties - both are forms of the same thing:  Energy, which itself can best be understood as a differntial between two beer cans/bullets/wallets in terms of mass, space and velocity, with changes in these states governed by laws of thermodynamics - like the direction of energy always flowing from hot to cold, never being able to get as much energy out of a system as you put into it, due to entropy, and paradoxically, the law of conservation of energy, which states that energy can't be created or destroyed, only changed from one form to another.  I personally think the 2nd law of thermodynamics and entropy are bunk, but I can't PROVE it until the universe ends and starts all over again of it's own volition and invalidates our primitive understanding of natural phenomena and the supposed laws that govern them.  Anyway....  .... In my understanding of current Newtonian consensus reality, the aluminum wallet absorbed and dissapated the energy of the projectiles as it yeilded, deformed, and failed through impact. This process converted the motion of the bullets (kinetic energy) into heat through mechanical deformation of the aluminum, which also conducted and disapated some of this heat through radiant and convective cooling and the rest through it's own kinetic displacement (movement)  The titanium and steel wallets suffered the same transfers of kinetic energy and heated, yielded and deformed and kinetically displaced based on thier elemental properties surface areas, thicknesses and masses, but their limits of plastic deformation were not reached, so the bullets never pierced them, and so never met, much less fused. Instead they were fragmented and deflected / redirected as they dissapated thier residual kinetic energy.  I'm not an engineer or a scientist or anything though. I'm just a highschool dropout idiot savant polymath who pretends to be smart on YouTube now then, so I might be wrong about all that....  ;-)

Your suggestion of the lead content being incorrect may be valid and changing that may yield better results, but the far simpler solution would be to introduce more drag on the bullets. Notes: The original bullets were heavy (about 460 grains), and nearly pure soft lead.  They'd likely slowed a lot before impact. It was probably almost like hammering them together. The chamber should always be cut to seat the bullet close to the leade. Freebore is undesirable and a source of inaccuracy and erosion. The short round looks shorter than .45 Schofield. Cartridges should be loaded to maximum volume for safety. Propellant and inert filler can be adjusted. This gives a consistent flame front, rather than a potential lateral ignition that can damage firearms (but wouldn't with the massive test barrels used) and affect pressure/velocity. I would keep the shields in place at all times except when zeroing or shooting.  Even if one side is empty, the shield is a good precaution against error. Awesome demonstration. The fragmentation patterns are fantastic.

As I first start to watch this, only one word comes to mind: CROSSFIRE!! Personally; throughout the first  half of the video, there was smokeless powder being used. This has much more power than black powder, which would have been used during the Civil War, and bullets at that time did fly much slower and, thus, could fuse. Smokeless powder is going to give off at least twice the power as black powder. Next is the copper jackets. Those will shatter right away, no matter what. Now, I could see them being used on and off, so, how often they were used is up for debate. If you try this again, don't use less smokeless powder to slow down the bullet, because that will only offset both packages. Use black powder and fill and entire cartridge. The physics will speak for themselves.

Yes, the lead is shattering because the bullets are moving too fast.  You can see the same thing with silly putty if you hit it with a hammer--it'll shatter.  This is the effect of the lead's viscosity and internal friction properties, like bulk modulus and shear modulus.  Any solid can only flow so fast as it deforms, because most materials are made of many tiny particles that hold themselves together through friction (unless it's a single solid crystal, in which case molecular forces hold it together).  If you try to deform it too fast, it falls apart because it can't flow fast enough.  Bullets in the Civil War obviously traveled much more slowly than modern bullets.  I'm also guessing that the lead was much less pure, which likely impacts the mechanical properties.  The impurities may have made it less viscous, but I'm not sure.

I have 3 things to add, maybe you have already figured these out but I'll leave them here for all to read anyway!  1st, modern non-jacketed (all, but less important in jacketed) lead bullets are designed to withstand much faster spin velocities and are hardened with antimony to both prevent barrel fouling and keep the bullet from tearing itself apart. This makes them brittle and is the major component in the exploding seen in the video. Civil war lead was more "pure" lead.  2nd, the overall mass of the bullets. Modern .45 Colt bullets are about 1/4th the mass of a Minie ball. A more direct comparison, in every way, would actually be a 12 gauge shotgun slug (both approximately 1 to 1.5oz, Minie balls being available in .577 or .69 caliber and 12 gauge being .729).  3rd, as you addressed in this video, the bullets are going pretty fast. The Smithsonian example was likely not "point blank" like this, allowing the velocity to be much lower than you can achieve with this setup. You can probably simulate it with a shorter barrel, but safety is obviously the prime concern here.  Good luck with part two!

Civil war guns used a powder that is not as powerful as modern powder.  In the years around 1900, most guns switched to being able to withstand modern powder.  There are plenty of warnings about putting modern cartridges in very old guns, which may then explode because the old guns were not designed to reliably contain the increased pressure of modern powder.  I inherited an old revolver that I have been warned not to use with modern cartridges.  For each firing with a modern cartridge, the gun may or may not explode, but there will definitely be increased leakage around the breach.

Two issues with your attempts. 1: the bullets. you would get better results if you went to a tire shop and took old lead wheel weights, melted them down for use in molds. 2: The powder. Civil war powder was, in fact,  black powder. They didn't have modern types of powder with a wide variety of grain size and different shapes. I think you would have more success if you explored this route. Modern propellants and bullets will not give you the desired results.
The lesson here is if you are ever in a shootout, just concentrate on shooting all the bullets coming toward you head on.

I think it's a combination of a few things.  The consistency/purity of the lead.   The shape of the bullets.  Speed of the rounds  And weight of the bullets themselves.  One thing you can possibly try to do is go back to the Museum and see if you can analyze the bullets themselvs both in weight, original shape and the metallurgy make up of them. If done carefully and with the right equipment it can be done without any damage to the artifacts.  All these could be factors that allowed them to Fuze together.  This was a freak "accident" under an exact set of circumstances where all the stars and planets in the universe had to align perfectly in order for them to fuse together like that.  The biggest trick is finding the right combination of variables.

'Today's lead' is considerably harder than the purer soft compound used back in C19, partially due to the increased velocities (thus stresses) modern propellant is capable of. Any jacketing may also be interfering with the desired weld - I am in no way an expert on any of these matters, but my gut feel is with what was stated during the vid: the lead needs to be softer & the velocity decreased.   Perhaps consider overboring the barrels used (with the same bullets) to simulate the lack of chamber pressure from period pieces? This would emulate the lower tolerances capable back then, & reduce the initial friction/loss of impetus from the bullet engaging the rifling grooves: for max efficiency (hence velocity) you want the bullet to fully engage ASAP, but these aren't 'skirted' bullets & therefore there would be some time period after primary charge ignition but before the bullet base expands enough to allow full rifle-groove engagement

@smartereveryday you probably only read and consider suggestions from patreons, but on on the off chance you don't, here's my suggestion: since you were not using the exact miniÃ© (pronounced mini-A) balles, I guess you would be fine using different lead alloys too. Use solder, optionally with a tin jacket, and put a core of solder flux in them. Solder is a Tin-Lead alloy, to a ratio that fuses easily and consistently. There are different alloys for fusing at different temperatures. I would not go for the solder used in electronics, as they are made to melt at the lowest temperatures, and they might get too liquid to stay together. Or perhaps get an expert on lead alloys from the welding (brazing) industry, not the ammunitions industry, and ask them to tinker with the perfect alloy for your bullets.  I'm looking forward to see your other ideas as well. I can think of a couple. Actually, you could start easily by just putting solder flux on the outside of the bullets you already have (unjacketed ones), just to help that flow. Some fluxes (e.g. SK10, available in spray cans) lower the melting point of the alloy and burn off immediately so it's just a very brief and temporary lowering of the temperature. They don't make the strongest bonds, but it could help fusing pure lead.  TL;DR: try spraying solder flux SK10 on your lead bullets, or cast bullets from pipe solder with an S39 flux core ( and spray SK10 on them as well).

It blows my mind that you had someone who actually does reloading as a hobby and he didn't say how bad of an idea it was to go with a shorter cartridge in a longer chamber creating bullet jump. Headspacing is a major key to tuning your hand loads to be accurate, every hunter who does their own custom loads knows this and tunes each of their hand loads to the specific rifle they're firing out of because you want to have a small and consisitent distance between the projectile in the chamber and the lans. Putting the same amount of powder in a smaller cartridge also affects pressure (increases it) which affects velocity. The "problem" you thought you had with the powder falling to the bottom of the case in a non-uniform manner isn't a problem because even your electronic primer should penetrate deep enough into the case to ignite the powder in a uniform manner.  To successfully fuse two projectiles in the manner you're hoping you'd need to have soft lead projectiles instead of the hardened and brittle standard projectiles that have a coating to make them safe to handle with your bare hands. You'd have to cast the projectiles yourself. You'd also likely want to have a smooth bore instead of rifling because putting a spin on the bullet isn't conducive to what you're trying to achieve, especially because each projectile will be spinning in opposite directions assuming you use the same barrel on both sides. You'd have to reverse the rifling on one of the barrels to make them match up and that's a lot tougher than just eliminating the riflign altogether (and the WoNA rounds probably didn't have rifled barrels.)

As other commenters have pointed out in one aspect or another, He'd have to try to duplicate bullet weight, speed, and composition of what was in use at the time. The fused bullets can get him on track as far as the caliber, bullet type, weight and composition.   From that, he can get much closer to the types of weapons that fired the bullets. But from a general perspective, at that point in time, for rifles, that would be in the 50 caliber region traveling at subsonic speeds, and most likely using pure lead. In fact, as pointed out elsewhere, the rotation of the bullets isn't helping either considering that they are rotating against themselves at impact. So that points to a smooth bore weapon.  The other thing to consider, which Dustin identified, is the lead type. Modern lead projectiles use trace elements like antimony to harden the lead. This makes it relatively more brittle than pure lead. Couple that with a much higher velocity, and a high angular momentum and we have the recipe for fragmentation.  What I believe is going on, is that the energy of impact, at much slower speed, and relatively 0 rotational velocity, allows the softer, pure lead bullets to "weld" themselves together.  Something else to consider: These two weapons most likely were fired at each other from a distance. And as such, their velocity began to decrease as soon as they left the muzzles. That means that at contact, their individual velocities would have been much, much lower than their initial muzzle velocities. This would aid in the welding process as the excess energy to dissipate through fragmentation would have been much less.  Another thing, I wouldn't get all wrapped up in the "Odds of this happening". Considering the millions of bullets that were fired in opposing directions, I'm pretty sure there are dozens or hundreds of these to be yet found. A search for "images of civil war bullets that hit each other" shows a large number have already been found.
Could it be because the heat of the old guns firing be hotter then today's gun powder and heated the lead more before impact.

Consider Occam's razor.  On one hand, the likelihood that two bullets actually met on the battlefield at such a perfect angle and speed to even create this artifact is extremely low.  Compound that with the likelihood that someone would actually find the unintentional artifact and was able to recognize the significance of the find to allow it to make it's way to a museum curator.    On the other hand, consider the likelihood that a couple of pranksters pressed two bullets together in a vice in their workshop and sold them to people as a rare Civil War artifact.  They probably would have made multiple copies and sold them all over the South before the hoax was revealed.  The likelihood that one of those copies wound up in a museum is exponentially greater than the artifact being real.    Not trying to burst anyone's bubble, just keeping it scientific.

I think the bullets fused inside the ridge wallet because the first one had slowed down to below half of its initial velocity. To get the bullets slowed down that much without deforming them or risking them getting stuck inside the barrel, you might need to shoot them through several thin layers of some soft material. Applying only a small amount of force several times should impart much less of a tumble on the bullet than one single impact. And sheets of material that slow the bullet down via their mass, not their tensile strength, would make the applied force most repeatable. Something like wet paper might be ideal; more mass and less stability than even dry paper.  Also, the barrel takes away a fixed amount of energy. Where "fixed" means it doesn't depend on the speed of the bullet or the amount of powder, it's defined by the barrel length and whatever friction the individual bullet you are firing happens to have with the barrel. Especially if your powder contains only barely more energy than what the bullet looses to friction, any fluctuations in the amount of friction can have massive influence on the bullet energy, relatively speaking. Whereas an impact with an object of 1/10th the mass of the bullet always takes away 1/10th of the momentum. I.e. in absolute terms a faster bullet will get slowed down more than a slow bullet.

Very fun. A couple things that I thought of. Seeing the fragmentation it was obvious even from the beginning that velocity was going to have to come waaaayyy down.  But the other thing that struck me was a kind of first principles examination of just what you were looking at in the museum. I don't think the ACTUAL caliber/mass/velocity of that specimen can be discounted. As I understand it, most of those musket balls were 68 caliber weren't they?  Additionally, their deadly nature was from their weight that would transfer a rather low speed projectile to the point where the bullet would remain inside the body. So I'm thinking you need to start this saga again but speak to someone who does civil war recreation firearm shooting. Get the data from them as far as the actual caliber and velocity of those original rounds. I think you will be surprised at how slow they actually flew.  450-500 fps would be my guess.  And that might even be high by 20fps.  Anyway... thanks for sharing this.  It was fantastic to watch.  Just splendid work.

This was amazing to watch. The only thing I can think of, and I'm sure you already thought of this, is to replicate as close as possible the actual event that fused the mini balls. The shape of the mini ball is very different from modern bullets as they have a hollow area at the rear and they were 50 or 55 caliber. Also, they were fired at distance with muzzle loaded rifles so their speed must have been much slower than what you were able to achieve. Maybe these factors are what is needed to fuse the bullets. Thank you Destin! This episode was so fun and brought back special memories of my journey in physics. I first saw two Civil War minie-balls fused together in the visitor's center of The Petersburg (VA) National Battlefield Park in the 1970's. I was about 10 years old. The park was about seven miles from my home and I spent many many hours riding my bike there and visiting the landmarks. That double mushroom hunk of lead opended up my mind to so many questions that, at the time, I didn't even have the words for ... humanities,  mechanical dynamics, materials science, shock waves, statistics .... Even ended up traveling south for two summers of graduate research at Redstone sending lightening bolts through dielectric materials - directed energy.

Two things which might affect the bullets sticking together. First, the rifling imparts a rotation to the lead slugs that adds to the forces affecting the fusion. Secondly, most significantly, air resistance against the nose of bullets causes the leading portion of the lead to MELT. This is why copper jackets were invented - they fly more accurately at longer distances because they don't deform.   Destin is firing at such short range that the lead doesn't heat up. Maybe try both smooth bore barrels, and a blob of solder at the tip of each bullet? Or perhaps some sort of heat source along the bullet's travel that will cause the face to melt. Something as simple as a couple propane torches - although the shrapnel might be a problem there.

Two thoughts, 1. about the lead.  Modern lead is rarely lead only for bullets, it contains antimony and tin.  This makes them harder.  Often the bullets will be hardened.  You could try heating them before the bullet is seated.  This may remove the temper during the casting process.  The best would be to cast your own bullets with no tin and antimony.  2. The Civil War rifles were not firing with modern powders.  The black powder will "burn" quicker.  This change in the "burn" time will change the velocity and likely give a better result. Fun fact... bullets from the Civil War era had aluminum in them. Less than 5%, I believe, but still had some in it. The bullets today are far more refined and cheaply made. They look for aerodynamics and impact damage more than composition of the bullets. Manufacturers use the cheapest metals or alloys they can to get the closest results of what they aim for. This makes fusion of the bullets all but impossible.  Using proper era made bullets would yield far closer result to what you are striving for.

Materials science of ballistics: The reason the bullets are shattering is because they are hitting with too much energy, Newton's 3rd law (equal and opposite reaction) and the bullets hardness is essentially equal. The bullets are hitting with so much kinetic energy (KE=(1/2)*m*v^2), on such a direct trajectory (not able to deflect off each other and keep going); that energy has to go somewhere, so it goes into the creation of new surface area, energy gets absorbed into the unzipping of the material grain boundaries (intergranular fracture, likely) or intragranular fracture (less likely) which results in shattering the bullets. With lower energy, the metal would still heat up, locally melt, and have a tendency to plastically deform instead of shatter, which is what you saw when the two merged after hitting the aluminum ridge wallet. In the case of shooting the aluminum ridge wallet, the aluminum hardness is much less than the bullet hardness, so the aluminum preferentially fails first; allowing that first bullet to slow down to the point that when it collides with the other bullet, there is less energy available to go into the creation of new surface area (i.e. shattering the bullet). In the case of the Damascus steel/titanium ridge wallet, the bullet's are less hard, so they preferentially erode first and shatter (there is a very tiny "bullet dwell phenomena" time, where the bullet literally sits on the surface of the metal plate, is eroding and cannot penetrate, this can be seen utilizing flash radiography, or see figure 9 in the monograph entitled Developing an Ultra-lightweight Armor Concept, by Charles E. Anderson, Jr. in Wiley's Progress in Ceramic Armor volume 1 by the American Ceramic Society, ACerS); this is essentially how modern body armor works by using high hardness steel or ceramic armor plate. So two conditions for you to explore; how do I have enough energy to leave the barrel of the gun, but at the point of impact, have lost enough energy such that the bullet material plastically deforms instead of completely shattering.   NOTE: One practical consideration for your experiment which you could do, besides decreasing the powder content, which might help you achieve your goal is to increase the distance between the guns. This would decrease the energy of the rounds when they meet since they are no longer at what is essentially muzzle velocity in your experiment. On a civil war battlefield, the soldiers firing at each other would likely have been at a much farther distance away from each other than your two-gun setup. One caveat though, depending on how far apart you place your guns, you may have to adjust for bullet arc (rise/fall of the projectile along it's ballistic trajectory), which is even more crazy to think that in the past, two guys shooting at each other, lined up at such a perfect distance and trajectory that when their bullets collided, enough energy of the round has been sapped away that they merged instead of shattering. Another variable is that modern gunpowder is likely different from civil war era gun powder, the burn rates, and thus energy propelling the projectile is a variable; slower burning powder down the X-length barrel takes longer to build up pressure; so depending on which powder you used to reload your ammunition, you may be able to change the burn rate by changing the powder used. Your comment about projectile metallurgy is also valid, as likely the metallurgical control back then was not as good as it is today; but what really matters is the material properties which I mentioned (hardness, which is mainly a function of local composition and microstructural grain size [itself a function of work hardening, heat treatment, temper])

Civil war era 'bullets' are generally .58 (.577) caliber, are moving considerably slower and are of very soft lead....The powder load varied during the heat of battle, sometimes being non-existent with the 'bullet' propelled by only the percussion cap and not exiting the barrel....It would be interesting to see how much the fused 'bullets' in the museum weigh compared to 2 intact ones....This might give some idea how much lead was actually shrapnel after the collision...People using the .577 Snider today use modified 20 gauge shotgun cartridges as it's not a muzzle loader and original brass is very scarce ( I have 18 original brass cases).......Personally, I would like to see you do this experiment with .58 (.577) minie-balls, consistent black powder and modified 20 gauge shotgun barrels and I'm sure you would get a higher percentage of each pair of 'bullets' fusing in the manner of those in the museum, even though the barrels would not be rifled as original Enfields , Springfields and others of the type are......It would be interesting to know how far each 'bullet' in the museum traveled before impact, half way across a field or possibly a few feet from the muzzle of one of the guns ? ..................John (west coast, Can.)

I haven't finished the vid yet, so I don't know how things turned out, but I had a thought while watching the slo-mo: It would probably be a bit difficult to accomplish, and could potentially introduce a lot of unwanted variables, but it might be interesting to redo things with one of the barrels replaced by one that has reversed rifling. Because they're pointing in opposite directions, the rifling for each barrel spins the bullet in opposite directions. I don't know how much of an effect it would have on the ultimate results, but I think it'd be interesting to see what happens when the bullets are only clashing in terms of linear momentum while being matched (as closely as one can reasonably get, at least) in terms of angular moment. Maybe it would be a less destructive and more plastic interaction if they weren't clashing rotationally in addition to linearly.

i think this test also left out a few key variables. 45 long colt and minie ball have similar muzzle velocities, but the bullet weights are way different. minie ball usually weight 510 grains. also the powder charges are different, black powder for the civil war and smokeless in the 45 long colt. also the distance at which the test was performed isn't the same as the conditions that the bullets may have collided. average engagement distances were around 60 yards in the civil war also this collision could have happened at at greater engagement distance which would also have and effect on the overall velocity of the projectile at point of impact. not complaining about the absolute mountain of work that went into the gem of free media but i think it's hard to dismiss it fully until all variables are tested. also the smithsonian could also be regularly cleaning the bullets as well to keep them in display condition.

Compared to two lead balls colliding with little rotation and fusing at a standstill and creating a more spherical shape.

Something to note, the munitions you're using are using modern day smokeless powder. Smokeless powder is a different beast to black powder. Smokeless powder has higher pressures and velocities compared to black powder, that higher velocity is quite possibly why your bullets are smashing instead of deforming.   So I suggest you try using black powder instead of smokeless powder, also you might want to go to a .50 caliber round instead, a larger bullet should have more lead in it and as-such should have a better chance of holding together. And you should try casting your rounds like you first thought, my guess is that, like you said, the lead mixture used in modern bullets is a harder alloy than what you would have had during the civil war meaning that instead of deforming on impact, it holds it's shape.  If you want to have an excellent demonstration of how the rounds would mainly crush and deform as they hit their target, I suggest watching Garand Thumb's video where he tries out a flintlock rifle and shows it impacting a target. Another possible source of info is Brandon Herrera's video where he recreated president Lincoln's assassination and also shows the round hitting the target.

So if you're going to do this again in the future a few things to note that'll (hopefully) make fusing them easier:  >The minee balls of the civil war rifles were sixty-eight caliber and weighed about three times the amount that a 45LC does while also being longer nose to tail >The lead in use back then was much more pure and much softer than modern lead used in smokeless powder applications >The lead bullets used back then had no jacketing >The rifles back then fired projectiles at much lower velocities than even a relatively slow cartridge like 45LC does using modern smokeless powder loadings  All four of these things taken as a group would (theoretically) allow for a much easier fusing of two rounds with this setup.

As a handloader, I loved this video more than you can imagine!  Using Remington E-tronx primers to solve the variable of lock time is exactly what I thought would work, haven't seen those in a long time! When you were talking about the amount of powder in the case, and how the 45LC case length left airspace in the cartridge under the bullet, I immediately said to the screen "why don't they use IMR Trailboss powder.  It's meant for exactly this.  Mimics black powder charge volumes and is usually on the slower side".  Cue to the part where you show the handloading and he's using exactly that!  Trailboss!  Impossible to miss with it's unique donut shaped flakes.  My only idea for this test would be to use cast bullets in the 250-300gr range (takes up more case volume, usually slower velocity as well) and cast them from dead soft pure lead like they used for minie balls in the civil war.  The bullets you're using, if they're commercial, I think are too hard for the fusion you want. Antimony in harder lead makes it fracture like that.  Aim for something in the Brinell hardness range of 5-7.  Let them air cool, don't cast and quench in water. Commercial bullets are usually 18-26 BHN.  Also, aim for 750-850fps. Can't wait to see the update!!  If you need someone to cast you some bullets for the test, lemme know!!!!  Fascinating stuff.  Keep up the good work!

@32:00 Ok guys here's the maths:  Two bullets each 0.014Kg with a velocity (I assume) of speed of sound (=340 m/s) collide, this gives a combined kinetic energy of 2X 1/2mv^2 = 1600Joule. So how much energy is that? Well to lift a person above your head height (~80kg) up 2 metre ~ 1600Joule (Potential energy = mgh) In theory then the energy of the collision is equivalent to a wrestler throwing his opponent over his head! In terms of heat generated in lead bullets at moment of collision, E= mCâ–³T (Specific heat),  1600 = 2X 14X  0.130X â–³T solving gives a â–³T =  440 degC, adding ambient outdoor temp of 25 degC gives final temp = 465 degC. Now lead melts at 330 degC so lead would melt and should have fused! But aluminium (wallet casing) melts at much higher temp (660 degC) so that's why lead bullets did not fuse. Oh you can't beat the maths!   ----> âœº <----

Just because I had nothing to do this one time, I calculated the approximate odds of this happening in a real battle in the Civil War.  I estimated the number of opposing bullets fired in a typical battle, and the number of possible places over that same battlefield where two opposing bullets might have come into contact.  The space between two armies is huge compared to the amount of space taken up by bullets.  The odds of two bullets colliding were one in an indescribably enormous number.  So enormous that I had to conclude that it was, in fact impossible. The velocity is too high for the bullets to fuse. Firing points distance and barrel length contribute to the high minimum speed for your test. Look at the velocity drop off over distance graphs for some standard ammunition. If you were 200 yds away (100 for each barrel) the bullets would each lose approx. 25% of their velocity only getting slower as distance increases. That would, however, make that impact point exponentially harder to hit. Another possibility could be to shorten the barrel to allow lower charges without getting squibbed. Best of luck on your fusion!

I think there are four contributing factors.  First, as you have determined, is controlling the energy.   Second, you need either pure lead or 30:1 lead:tin alloy.  I am sure any number of guys could cast some bullets for you.  Third, I think the miniÃ© bullet design might have a contributing effect as well.  The hollow base and thin skirt may act as a crumple zone to absorb some energy in a way the helps preserve retained weight.  Fourth, you may find that a higher initial bullet weight is needed.  The .58 caliber miniÃ© of the civil war was around 500 grains, giving a combined total of 1,000 grains for two.  You appear to have been using a Lee 230 grain tumble lube bullet.  The final retained weight of the joined bullets will be a function of the initial weight.   I would suggest a 400 grain pure lead bullet using a starting load of Accurate 5744 for a velocity of around 600 fps from your test rig.

Hey Destin, a fun aside for discussing how impact angle changes the resulting direction of expelled material. If you have two laminar streams of water pointed directly at each other, the resulting spray will come out in a 180Â° pattern. If you start to change the angle of attack the spray will decrease from 180 and decrease until the streams are parallel. If you point two streams at each other that are in a transitional state somewhere between laminar and turbulent, you can create a repeating signal that creates a fan that waves. It's similar to how windshield nozzles work. They're actually one line being rastered. You can see this if you take light up the stream with a strobe light. If you can change the frequency of the strobe, you can find the frequency of the fluidic.

@SmarterEveryDay A few notes for you to consider. I agree with changing the bullet composition. Modern all lead bullets are made of 'hard cast lead' which is a lead alloy mixed with silver, tin, and antimony. This raises the Brinell hardness from about 4 to 15-30 depending on composition. This improves penetration characteristics because it deforms less, but also makes it much more brittle and more likely to fragment than deform. Switching to pure lead with the lower velocities might do the trick.  Second, Civil War Minie balls were usually around 500 grains and .54-.58 caliber, meaning it is nearly twice the mass of an average 255 grain .45 LC and has a significantly larger diameter. Not sure if this will effect the test, but I certainly could see it happening.  Third, I am highly doubtful this would have an effect, but because of the distribution of rifles in the South during the Civil War, it is likely that only one bullet would have been spinning, and possible neither of them would have been. Although they are twisting so little during the impact, I doubt it has any significant impact.

DESTIN!!!  is awesome but  I see a couple of problems with your reloading!!  I also reload and you have an error in your thinking-  more powder does not equal more pressure or speed, less powder does not equal less pressure or speed.  Packed load (a load with no airspace) burns at a different rate than a load with airspace which equals different pressure and speed.  The best thing you can do is try a range of loads, say from 1.5 grn to 2.5 grn or whatever.  Increase each load by 0.1grn and then chronograph this.  You'll see points in the speed data that will level off around certain loads.  then choose a load in that range so if the powder burns slightly inconsistent or there is a variance in the powder grains the pressure and velocity will not vary much and you'll get more consistent shots.

Did you scavenge for scraps after each shot with metal detectors, so you do not mix up results? There is probably a way to design a fiducial such that you can see your writing from multiple angles, so that you can shoot from multiple angles. Multiple transparent planes, all 90Â° from the stablizing plane, crossing through each other at a single point, with half the writing on each side of the cross for each plane and with different coloured text on each plane. In editing you can fluff up/down colours for each angle. The colours even makes it easier with coding names for cameras and their shots. The downside is the same as in the video - the fiducial can not be the direct background to the bullets (the bullets can not be superimposed onto the fiducial), it has to be lower/higher than the bullets' paths. Another way to go about it is on the sides (two parts on each plane, except for the gounding plane/with empty space in the middle/with no plain crossing point), but you lose the measuring function the closer you get to the centre. That way you can not take the video shots 90Â° from the bulluets' paths, the quality of shots and number of planes would be reverse proportional, how close the video shot would be to 90Â° of the bullet's parths and the wideness of the plane gap would be reverse proportional (for a good quality shot), and if you want to capture the bullets through their full path (no superimposition of fiducials over a bullet), the gap would have to be big enough to fit both barrels' ends. It would also be difficult to reuse such a fiducial as such material would not sustain as much damage. Another way to go about it is to have a ring around the whole scene (behind the guns, behing the cameras) with repeated writing. To fix the measuring inconsistencies from the curviture you would need 3d magic on whatever is printed on the ring. Does trying this in vacum sound even more exciting or the same?

That gap between the bullet and the rifling is called headspace. An experienced handloader/reloader will make specific bullets just for their firearm by measuring the headspace. (as each firearms headspace is unique) The tighter the tolerence in headspace not only makes the load more accurate but increases pressure. Measuring headspace when making bullets for specific firearms has always been an important step for making an accurate load. I really appreciate that you were able to confirm this technique in high speed. The old timers that taught me how to reload/handload expressed the importance of this step. You confirmed it Dustin! As an avid reloader and some one who casts his own bullets I have thought about this for a long time. I agree modern "lead" is to hard. The tin and antinomy levels are too high. You don't need long range precision. A 99% or so lead would be perfect. I had always thought a .45-70's 405 would work great as the round due to the exceptionally long lead column. Swedge that to .452 for a .45 colt and use a custom load. And you could also use an over powder wad for more constistant powder burns in a reduced load.

Civil war era bullets were much softer.  It was a lead zinc ratio of 20:1 or 30:1, you could even go 40:1 if you wanted. If you purchased already made projectiles there is an extremely high chance you are running 92-94 parts lead, a couple parts Antimony and and the rest Zinc. Your Brinell hardness (BHN) is way to high which is why you are getting shattering and not fusing. Someone earlier may have already pointed this out, but thought I would pass the info along incase they havenâ€™t. I would love to see you get 2 to actually fuse. As they showed you need to be able to fire a gun perfectly level, know exactly where the fired bullet will hit the ground (that is far from easy) at the same time the bullet is fired release a bullet at that landing point (which as they found is far from easy for the points outlined in this video plus the addition of the length of wire needed for the electrical release created additional lag time that had to be compensated for) all to achieve that super slo mo shot of the fired bullet and dropped bullet landing on the ground at the exact same time in the same frame.    â€œEasyâ€.
Â @STS125Â  Bruh it's literally just an experiment about gravity... Did you not learn about that in high school?

Â @rppope1006Â  basically, itâ€™s a matter of the forces acting on the bullets, and the original states of the bullets. While one bullet is traveling faster horizontally (along the x axis for the sake of explanation) neither bullet is starting with any speed on the y axis; neither starts with any speed vertically. This means that from a physics standpoint, if we want to see when the bullets will hit the ground, nothing happening in the x axis matters whatsoever, because it works independently from the y axis. Thatâ€™s the basics, but taking it further, both bullets have one force acting on them in the y-axis, gravity. Acceleration (change in speed) of gravity on an object is constant (it doesnâ€™t depend on the mass of the object, weird right?) so, that means that the bulletsâ€™ speeds in the y axis are changing at the same rate , so if theyâ€™re dropped from the same height, neither initially going up or down, theyâ€™ll experience the same acceleration for the same amount of time, and hit the ground at the same time, entirely regardless of how fast either is moving along the x-axis. I'll mention something that will blow your mind:  barley flour.   There were a LOT of loading specifications that included barley flour in the powder charge.  So what you're looking at in the museum is a completely different kind of bullet.  Poured in a casting block from the nose first of all, the velocity was probably around 830-930f/s because they were under-powdering the shots due to moisture causing a slower but more expansive burn.    You CAN some shots get pellets to fuse together from a pellet rifle by sticking one in the muzzle and the other fired normally (both aimed out) and you get a nice sharp clap of breaking the sound barrier from the compaction.   I suspect the thing that made the two bullets in the museum stick was that clap, so we're talking about an incredibly accurate strike and probably both had a little dimple from where the pour happened and the sprue from the fill-hole was broken off.

This is the single safest, most controlled, most carefully made video I have ever seen when it comes to dealing with fire arms. The fact it took years to make, is honestly the best thing, because i know a lot of people would just rush to the chase, hook up 2 guns of same make and model, toss them in some vice grips, hide behind some old tires or other stuff, and use a string or simple mechanical device to shoot the guns at the same time.  Which is why you can tell this was done for the sake of science and personal curiosity, over actually trying to gain fame; this took YEARS to do, and the first 1/3rd of the video is literally going over every safety measure taken, and even bringing experts in to further idiot proof it. It brought me back to the days of Myth Busters, but even that was rushed to get a result often due to needing to be on TV in a reasonable time.

I am studying mechanical engineering at Tsinghua University and currently our team is developing a prototype "bullet detection and obliteration device" based on high intensity laser emitters and high frequency omnidirection infrared sensors. The prototype's application is wide ranging but primarily focuses on VIP and high value target protection from projectile based weapons. Our prototype can react to bullets just leaving a gun barrel less than a meter in distance and destroy it within nanoseconds (speed of light vs. speed of projectile) The challenges we're facing is the line of sight needed for early destruction of the projectile which would require multiple placement of the laser source/reflection mirror relative to the protecting target. Near distance destruction by umbrella structure device over the protection target is more risky and still requires somewhat a wide perimeter for safe operation.

The key to lack of fusion may very well be the twist rate of the guns that fired the bullets. I do not know the twist of the barrels in your test barrels. Recommended rates for 45 Colt barrels is one turn in 20 inches. Civil war muskets ranged from smoothbore guns with no rifling, to rifled musket twists varying from 1 turn in 78" to one turn in 48". A very common rate was 1 turn in 72 inches. In my opinion, if the spinning bullets are in opposing directions in your design, creating a shearing effect,  that would preclude any possibility of fusion. I would suspect that using a non threaded barrel in your gun might work. Or using barrels with the same direction of twist at the contact point might also work.

I'm just a layperson, but I think I know what the problem is. In order to fuse lead (or any metal for that matter), the temperature of the lead has to be identical and at the melting point of lead when it fuses. Otherwise, fragmentation will occur. And as we saw, that was what you were getting - fragments, not fusing. SO in the Civil War, the lead was traveling slower (as you acknowledged) because the velocity of bullets then were slower than they are now. However, it is the MASS of the bullets you are using now that is different. Civil War bullets had more mass. How is that important? It's important because the amount of TIME in which the Civil War bullets had to "melt" was long enough for the generated heat of impact to travel through the entire mass, allowing the whole bullet to melt and fuse. With your modern bullets, the mass is smaller and the time of impact is less, not allowing your bullets enough time to melt and fuse.
Have you considered much heavier bullets. They would move much slower. Maybe even go up to .410 shotgun or 12 gauge even. Slugs may be slow enough and they are remarkably easy to reload.

You should really try using some black powder and pure lead.  Black powder or black powder replacement propellant will have a different burn profile than modern nitro powders. You can also add a small amount of sawdust to slow it down a little, effectively reducing the quality of the powder. Consider using a wad to pad the case and keep the powder in contact with the bottom of the case too.  Pure lead will help with the fusion. You will find the pre-cast bullets are an alloy (lead, antimony and tin) and are harder than lead, they need to be to allow faster muzzle velocities and modern powders, this leads to greater fragmentation on impact.
