TLDR: You would have a better chance of fusion if you used smooth bore barrels, a larger caliber projectile and black powder instead of smokeless.   To get the fusion, you need to change a couple of things on the rig. First, you need a bigger bore. Something in the 54+ cal range. Second, not all guns used in the Civil War were rifled. They also used smooth bore weapons. With a rifled barrel you get spin, which adds momentum away from the center of the projectile. The faster you spin something, the less stable(structurally) it is. An example is if you run a 6.5 Creedmoor out of a 1:7 twist barrel at 3200fps, the projectile would explode right after it leaves the muzzle. It is essentially pulling itself apart. Add to that the fact that you have two bullets rotating in different directions, you increase that outward momentum times 4. Lastly, they used black powder. It's much faster burning than smokeless powder and develops much less velocity with a much higher case fill(meaning you can take up more of that empty space in the brass). It takes 150 grains of black powder to produce the same velocity that 50 grains of smokeless powder can do to the same projectile.

It comes down to precisely measured quantities. Bullets of the same mass down to millionths of a gram, same for the powder load. Even more so for the powder. Same number of grains and each grain being the same mass. Force equals mass times velocity so a bullet traveling even a fraction of a meter per second will have advantage over the slower bullet. Two bullets impacting one another can be readily duplicated under controlled circumstances as youâ€™ve elegantly demonstrated. That it actually happened during a conflict is a mathematical certainty given the number of battles through the ages. Itâ€™s probably happened hundreds of times. But it approaches the nearly impossible that two bullets met with enough force to have fused together and the result to be recovered.

There slow motion frames do appear to have rifling marks on the bullets...  I looked up the Springfield 1861 rifled musket (most common civil war small arm), and it has a 1:72 twist rate with a 1000fps muzzle velocity. That is a much slower twist than most modern guns. The bullet was also undersized, which would have reduced the efficiency of the rifling.  The minie ball projectile also commonly had a hollow base. The most common balls had a cone shaped divot in the base that expanded when fired to better engage the rifling. I thought they had rounded backs, but the cone would similarly impact center of gravity.

The bullets fly way to fast i.e. have way too much energy to fuse. Either the distance had to be longer or the amount of power had to be lower. Historical accuracy would imply the distance should be higher - not to mention most of this could be calculated beforehand, to at least get a sane estimate of the required setup, instead of that much trial-and-error. I guess it's the old age conflict between more scientific vs more engineering approach. Engineering is certainly the more "showy" one, so I understand the choice.  The metal composition observation is spot on - sure looks like the lead isn't sticky / gummy / melted enough to fuse - I would bet the war time lead had less heat conductivity so that it stayed hot longer and hence fused better. The lead in the video cools way too rapidly for it to fuse - maybe it's too pure? Don't know, I am not a metallurgist but he issue is interesting.   I've also noticed the default state of the bullet-plates is open, while it should be closed - defaults matter, a lot. Like in 26:26, you can see Destin loading one barrel, while the other one is open. Yes, most probably there's no bullet in the other one, yet. And the positive cable is disengaged BUT most of the serious mishaps happen when bad things lineup just right.  There could be a bullet in the 2nd one, because of some unexpected break in the firing sequence and a "happy" spark from a falling rock or something just happens to ignite the gun. Improbable? Sure, but it's the improbable things that kill most unexpectedly. Sane defaults are just another layer of safety and they are cheap - in this case basically free, use it.

ğŸ’¯ğŸ’¯ğŸ’¯ OF COURSE IT COUNTS!!! â¤ğŸ¥¸ğŸ¤ª The aluminum wallet slowed down the bullet allowing it to fuse. By YOUR OWN ADMISSION, the bullets are going to fast to fuse. The civil war bullets were NOT fired at point blank range. Weâ€™ll NEVER know how far apart they were fired from. But from a RESULTS PERSPECTIVE, it is obvious the bullets had slowed enough to be in the sweet zone of enough energy to fuse but not too much energy to explode. As with every bullet, muzzle velocity is always the fastest the bullet will ever go.  And the further you are down range from the bullet, the velocity exponentially slows down.  Aluminum wallet VS gravity and atmospheric conditions, both are external forces causing the bullets to slow down enough to not transfer enough energy to cause an explosion, but still enough energy to not cause the bullets to just bounce off each other.  There is a sweet spot of energy delivered at the point of impact that allows for fusion vs failed experiment.  From a kinetic energy, drag coefficient, velocity, mass and sectional density perspective, you have attempted to created an experiment that, as you pointed out is so complex, youâ€™ll probably NEVER figure out ALL the variables. And I KNOW that will drive you absolutely BONKERS!!  HOWEVER, accidentally you did discover a KEY factor in replicating the desired result. Figuring out a way to reduce velocity at point of impact.  Of course that equation is also something so full of variables it will probably drive you BONKERS.  Here is an excellent read on this portion of the experiment.   The external ballistics of a bullet's path can be determined by several formulae, the simplest of which is: Kinetic Energy (KE) = 1/2 MV2 Velocity (V) is usually given in feet per second (fps) and mass (M) is given in pounds, derived from the weight (W) of the bullet in grains, divided by 7000 grains per pound times the acceleration of gravity (32 ft/sec) so that: Kinetic Energy (KE) = W(V)2 / (450,435) ft/lb This is the bullet's energy as it leaves the muzzle, but the ballistic coefficient (BC) will determine the amount of KE delivered to the target as air resistance is encountered. Forward motion of the bullet is also affected by drag (D), which is calculated as: Drag (D) = f(v/a)k&pd2v2 f(v/a) is a coefficient related to the ratio of the velocity of the bullet to the velocity of sound in the medium through which it travels. k is a constant for the shape of the bullet and & is a constant for yaw (deviation from linear flight). p is the density of the medium (tissue density is >800 times that of air), d is the diameter (caliber) of the bullet, and v the velocity. Thus, greater velocity, greater caliber, or denser tissue gives more drag. The degree to which a bullet is slowed by drag is called retardation (r) given by the formula: r = D / M Drag is difficult to measure, so the Ballistic Coefficient (BC) is often used: BC = SD / I SD is the sectional density of the bullet, and I is a form factor for the bullet shape. Sectional density is calculated from the bullet mass (M) divided by the square of its diameter. The form factor value I decreases with increasing pointedness of the bullet (a sphere would have the highest I value). Since drag (D) is a function of velocity, it can be seen that for a bullet of a given mass (M), the greater the velocity, the greater the retardation. Drag is also influenced by bullet spin. The faster the spin, the less likely a bullet will "yaw" or turn sideways and tumble in its flight path through the air. Thus, increasing the twist of the rifling from 1 in 7 will impart greater spin than the typical 1 in 12 spiral (one turn in 12 inches of barrel). webpath. med. utah. edu/  TUTORIAL/ GUNS/ GUNBLST  Additionally, civil war bullets were ball ammo typically around .58 caliber. Not a round nose .45. Iâ€™d imagine ball ammo is going to impact differently than round nose ammo.  Some ideas Iâ€™ve thought about on this topic. Use the AIR GUN principle to replicate this experiment. CONTROLLING variables will be so much more efficient.  What ever yâ€™all decide to do for future experiments on this topic, I hope yâ€™all have a BLAST!!  â€¦pun intended.. ğŸ˜ğŸ˜†

I think there are 2 things that has to be factored into this regarding the Civil War bullets.  1) We do not know at what range those bullets were fired at. But if the range is sufficiently long, it could mean the velocity they were travelling at the point of impact could be far lower than their muzzle velocity. This could mean there is not a way for your setup to recreate the fusing of the bullets because the distance is too short and there is not a way to lower the powder charge so not to cause a squib (the bullet stuck in the barrel). 2) The pressure differences between modern smokeless powder and the Civil War era blackpowder (gunpowder) would influence the velocity also. Before smokeless powder, there was a limit on how fast you can push the bullet because the high amount of blackpowder given the metallurgy of the period would risk castetrophic failure of  the barrel and chamber. Which is why they use large caliber bullets (for more mass) instead of going for faster velocity to increase kinetic energy.

They're called Minie balls, not "miny". Notice that the spelling is different. Pronounced mee nyay. It's a French word (the name of the inventor of the conical ball). The barrel twist is a German invention, while prior every firearm was a smoothbore. The French invented the ball as we know it today. Prior to this invention balls were all round and lacked precision. The term ball in English comes from "balle" which in French implies round ball or as in English any ball to play with, baseball, basketball etc... but is also used to describe a complete round of ammunition which is still called "balle". The "e" is silent. "balle de fusil" means rifle bullet or rifle cartridge interchangeably. The entire cartridge. Balle de revolver means revolver cartridge, balle de pistolet, means auto handgun cartridge. Great idea for a test. Very interesting !! Glad you're all advanced in the tech world, that's what it takes for a test demanding so much precision. Well done !

I would like to suggest that you can actually load black powder into these cartridges, it should be safe, and consider finding a hollow base bullets and use a softer lead.

Lead is naturally sticky.... When it's not tarnished. The goal is essentially cold welding. So, one could assume that in the civil war time that they could have JUST made fresh slugs and were dispersed quickly to the soldiers, before they had time to get the film of oxidation on the slugs. So, i say clean the mating surfaces surfaces in hopes that the natural stickiness would act like cold welding. Also, modern lead has zinc in it to keep it from oxidizing, since the bullets would be presumably sitting in storage for some time before use. That zinc also changes the spalling pattern to smaller fragments for maximum damage. I would assume the bullets from back then were pretty close to pure lead, which is like bubble gum at high speeds like this. When it hits its target, it would smush out but stay intact, unlike lead with zinc, which is designed to maximize fragmentation. Looks like you'll have to smelt your own lead slugs to achieve the accuracy of being as close to period correct as possible. You may even buy a genuine civil war era slug and do some kind of purity test on the lead to find how to recreate a period correct recipe for the lead composition.

Havenâ€™t read all the comments. But hereâ€™s my suggestion, others may have already said it.  The two civil war era bullets were very likely non alloyed lead or, if alloyed, a much softer alloy. Those bullets had to be engaged into the grooves and lands of the rifling by hand and then forced down the barrel with the ram rod. A hard alloy would slow down, or make impossible, reloading. At the least it would slow the COMBAT shooter.  The modern bullets, even those that were not copper jacketed, are modern alloys designed for terminal performance in modern shooting situations. They could be for paper targets for which the alloy would be largely unimportant other than desired density. They could be for hunting or self defense in which case the alloy would be chosen for its ability to retain mass and size while allowing sufficient penetration to cause maximum damage. If they were for â€œCowboyâ€ or â€œdynamic shooting courseâ€ use the projectiles would likely be a softer alloy (though likely still harder than Civil War era). Dynamic shooting often involves steel plate targets and soft lead will splatter reducing ricochet hazards.  The copper clad bullets are simply inappropriate choices due to the copper jacket.  I would suggest returning to the museum and asking the curator if they have or can check with the main Smithsonian for any metallurgical data they may have on those fuzed bullets.   In the absence of data on the specific bullets, research on commonly supplied bullets should be available somewhere.

@Smartereveryday- I think the shape of the bullet is why it won't fuse together. If you had ball shaped bullets it might of worked. My theory. Is the shape of modern bullets there is more weight in the back of the bullets still pushing the nose foward. If they were round the center of the ball bullet is majority of the weight and that is were the momentum will stop when the center of the ball bullets collide they will effectively have to more weight with foward momentum to keep pushing. There for when the center of the ball bullets meet in the middle the foward moment u m will no longer be forced away from the point of impact. The ball bullets will stop once the center mass of each meet in the middle. Just a though I had and a possible reason it didn't have the same outcome as the end result you were trying to replicate.

Extremely interesting and fantastic engineering. As to the fusion of the two bullets, I suspect you are at least partially correct in that it is the bullet material. However the bullet design may have also played a roll.   Bullets of that era were made from pure lead, not alloyed lead used today. Also the bullets most often used were called mini balls. (Think of how you might fire a plastic/paper cup from a gun. The bottom would be forward and and the opening you'd drink from to the rear where the powder is.) This way the bullet could be made slightly undersized to make loading a lot easier. When fired the rear of the bullet would open up creating the seal with the barrel.  Maybe try to find some hollow base wadcutters in that caliber. To get pure lead you might have to cast your own. Lee at least use to make mini ball molds for creating these.  Any one into traditional muzzle loaders should be able to help you out.

Pretty cool.  Take-away:  The two civil war bullets did not meet in "clean air".  You sort-of proved that in your testing.  Obviously, they did not meet in an aluminum wallet, either.  So what sort of medium would have been present on the battlefield?  A book,  a bundle of clothing. other known "kit" that CW soldiers would have been carrying, etc.  Another answer would be "human soft tissue", but that's kinda hard to test.  Maybe the Smithsonian bullet has been tested for organic matter coating the bullet(s)?  Paper, leather, etc?  May not be helpful since blood, powder, etc would also test positively as organic, so further testing would need to be done on that sample to determine origin.  Another takeaway:  it would be a miracle that the two war bullets met in the exact middle of their flights.  One bullet likely had far less energy upon impact than the other bullet, having traveled farther to get to the intercept point.   Great video.  Keep experimenting!

Part of the variables that are adding to the misses is the fact that some powders are heat sensitive. As you are filming throughout the day the temperature rises and it affects the powder. Also, as some others have pointed out the lead of today's "lead" rounds is not pure lead. Even with pouring your own lead bullets, you will end up with inconsistent bullet forming that is not 100% concentric that can lead to bullet yawing in flight. Then there is the matter of barrel twist rates, and how the lands and grooves were cut. There's also the primer equation, which there could be small variances in them as well. One problem with fusion of the rounds is, civil war bullets were soft lead. Modern bullets use lead-tin-antimony for lead bullets to lower lead fouling of the barrel and also hardens the bullets. I'd doubt the propellant difference of modern smokeless powder vs black powder would make a realistic difference, as that'd be more an acceleration curve while inside the barrel and be irrelevant to the rounds impacting one another. Velocity, as in range the civil war rounds traveled likely was much lower though, as most battles weren't fought at point blank range. So, emulating that, one could use a lower propellant charge and slightly larger bore barrels, while going with pure lead projectiles, as finding non-alloy rounds is beyond unlikely today.

I havenâ€™t read all the comments and someone may have already said this, but I think your bullets wonâ€™t fuse because modern lead bullets are usually an alloy of lead, tin, and antimony to give them hardness , whereas the Minie balls used in many civil war era muskets were more likely to be a more pure form of lead. The skirt of the hollow base of the Minie ball obturated to fill the rifling grooves when pushed forward by the expanding powder gasses, sealing the bore and engaging the rifling to give the projectile rotational stability. The powder used was black powder that varied in consistency and quality of formulation as well as quantity, thus giving a wide range of velocities. I donâ€™t know what the range of those velocities might have been, but suspect that they were slower and more wide ranging than the velocities given by modern smokeless powders. Iâ€™m theorizing more than what I know, but wonder if a pure lead bullet propelled at black powder velocity might fuse with its counterpart meeting it from the other direction more readily than a bullet of a lead, tin, antimony alloy.

This is also an outstanding visual demonstration of what happens when celestial bodies collide in our universe, whether they're stars, galaxies, moons, asteroids and meteorites hitting a planet, and the comet fragments that hit Jupiter.  You can easily imagine the violence, speed, disintegration and new orbits and paths of the fragmented objects. The bullets that remained suspended for an instant show how some of the material would have fused to create a new object, and some of it would be ejected by the force of the collision. A lot of people don't know this and only have a rudimentary understanding of the forces that shaped our universe.

One problem with the bullet fusion is that during the Civil War, they used pure lead not hardened lead alloy. Traditional muzzleloaders can only use soft lead as the roundball never touches the barrel, that space is taken up by the patch. Minni Ball has a conical back end using the expanding gasses from the black powder to engage the rifling. Also, the rounds used during the Civil War were no less than .50 which was nothing more than a squirrel gun back then. Most military arms were .64 and .76 inch, not a tiny .38. More mass, soft medium and much slower speeds.

Nice work. Civil war Minie bullets were generally cast from dead soft pure lead, which was required for the base to obturate and take the rifling. They were slightly small for the bore to facilitate very fast reloading. Even today black powder bullets are generally dead soft pure lead. The 45LC bullets you were testing with were alloyed harder to avoid leading in the barrel, hence they are harder and shatter. Looks like a similar comment below. This is all well known in the reloading and blackpowder communities. Have fun and be safe!

Probably two reasons but I think the main reason is that most of the led used on modern led bullets is an alloy to try and make the bullet harder to allow for greater penetration on impact. Question: could a hotter bullet temperature prior to collision make the bullets more likely to fuse?  I'd assume that a longer barrel would both give the powder more burn time and also result in more friction as the bullet's engaging the rifling for a greater length of time.  It may also be worth investigating just how tightly the rifling from a Civil War-era musket grips a bullet and if it's tighter than in modern firearms.  Speaking of rifling, could bullet spin impact the likelihood of the rounds fusing?  If so, it might be worth investigating a lower (or possibly higher) twist ratio.  Similarly, it might be useful to try rifling one of the barrels clockwise and the other counterclockwise to reduce or eliminate the relative spin when the bullets impact.  Taking this further, you could also try using smoothbore barrels, as a quick Google search (which may or may not be accurate) says that both sides had some non-rifled muskets at the start of the war.

Since the first collision and shattering I knew the problem, the reason you are not getting them to stick. Its the heat. Lead melts very easily and those projectiles are not getting the time to dissipate the heat energy they carry from the powder ignition and the friction in the barrel. So, without increasing the distance by elongating the test apparatus you instead have to experiment with the right amount of temperature by, say, cooling the rifles or somehow cooling the lead the right amount before impact to create maybe an even better looking, science assisted bullet congregation.

In May of 1654, two teams of fifteen horses each were hitched to  two copper hemispheres that were held together by nothing but air pressure and the vacuum inside them.  The man of presenting the demonstration, Otto von Guericke, was showing off his new vacuum pump. Emphasis on the showing off part, because one of those teams of horses was entirely superfluous - if one of the hemispheres had been tethered to a building or tree, it would have provided the same force with half the number of horses.  While the  theater of two guns firing at each other is not lost on me, the relative velocity which seems to be a problem and probably is considerably higher than Civil War mini balls, could be cut in half and the whole rig greatly simplified by simply mounting one bullet on top of a soda straw and shooting at it. There are surprisingly a lot of things different between the civil war bullets and your rig. First, the civil war balls were shot at a much longer distance and will have slowed down considerably when they hit. Second, they were fired with what we would call "shoddy" black powder these days which will have made them travel a lot slower. Maybe loading with fireworks grade powder would more closely mimic the original. Third, they were made from real lead. I'm not sure that modern "lead" bullets are not more pewter than toxic lead. Fourth, I'm not sure that modern bullets don't have some sort of anti friction coating on them to prevent them from sticking in the barrel and slowing down. These are things I would definitely investigate before trying this again.

to help with your shattering problem you might want to make sure you're using black powder. It is known for being slower burning than modern smokeless powder. 45 long colt comes in black or smokeless powder loadings. I don't know what you were using before but that could be part of the issue. either way, you may have gotten as close as you can to the lowest velocity possible with you small powder load but it is still something I thought about. It would take a lot more effort on your part but you could also re build your guns using a larger caliber. Many muskets in the civil war used .58 or .577 caliber cartridges. This might allow you have better contact area and generally stronger bullets that won't shatter so easily. Just some ideas for your consideration. Love the video and all the work you put in!

Maybe part of the reason the two bullets that went through the wallet partially fused was not just that the thin aluminum sheet slowed them down enough. One bullet hit the wallet just before the other one did. Maybe that first impact imparted a tiny bit of friction-generated heat to that bullet that softened an outer layer of lead just enough to make it stick to the second bullet in addition to slightly reducing its velocity just before the bullet-to-bullet collision. The two Civil War bullets that combined didn't shatter; they kind of look like they got squished together as if they were Play-Doh. Is it possible that, in addition to being a somewhat different kind/purity of lead and traveling at different velocities than yours, those two bullets were at a higher temperature at the instant of impact than those that you were using, such that the metal was more malleable and less brittle and thus more prone to merging than shattering? The rifles that they were fired out of probably had much longer barrels than your homemade solution (which is ingenious by the way :D ) and therefore probably would have had more heat imparted to them when they left their barrels due to the extra time they had engaged with the rifling.   There are of course a bunch of other variables to consider, such as how far away from each other the two Civil War rifles were when they were fired and how that might affect things, but maybe something to think about?

The issue is the lead. Muskets in the civil war time, used pure lead. Modern "lead" bullets usually have a bit of tin, and antimony. Makes the bullet more robust for the higher pressures, but can also make them brittle.

Hi Destin, I have some additional critiques/suggestions for your safety protocol.  1. Both blockers should always share the same open/close state. This is due to the rear of the blocker having two almost 45Â° angled plates that direct shrapnel back towards the gun/loader when only the far one is closed. 2. Blocker(s) should be closed before loading so all shrapnel is angled in the same 90Â° direction at all times in the closed state (giving a clear no go side of the setup). 3. You should be filming from the other side to prevent entering the no go side defined in #2.  Love you and your content. Thanks and stay safe.

Commercial â€œleadâ€ bullets are â€œhard castâ€ meaning they are an alloy of lead, tin, and antimony (and rarely silver). They typically have a Brinell hardness of about 11 to about 30 there is nothing that you can do to get hard lead bullets to fuse.  On the other hand, pure lead bullets (those used in the Civil War) and bullets made of up to a eutectic mixture of tin and lead (63-37) will fuse.   Pure lead has a Brinell hardness of about 4. The collision has to raise the junction temperature of the collision above the melting point (or solidous temperature in the case of 1%-36% lead). When the collision occurs at the minimum velocity to make this happen, the bullets will fuse.

Get a filler on top of your powder charge. Then slightly compress the load when you seat the bullet. There are commercial fillers available but cream of wheat or grits works. This is a bigger deal with some smokeless rifle powders because they can cause secondary explosive effects and spike pressures to unsafe levels with cases that are not full.

The reason the bullets were fragmenting vs fusing like you wanted is because the miniÃ© balls had significantly lower velocity than even other black powder weapons. Minie balls were hollow and contained their own powder charge. This limited space mixed with their large bore meant the bullet was traveling quite slowly.
Alot of civil war rifles were smooth-bore. Have to take that into consideration too.

Minnie balls used a regular load. Only some needle primed â€œrocketâ€ bullets were as you described, and used in small pistols. A Minnie ball would be much larger and probably slightly slower than .45lc, but they also used soft lead, modern lead is much harder

in order to reproduce the fused bullets like the one from the civil war, it is important that the temperature at the point of collision exceeds the local melting point. This requires two conditions at least to be satisfied: (a) choosing a type of lead alloy that has low enough melting point, and (b) the texture at the bullet tips are rough enough (i.e. high coefficient of friction) to efficiently convert the kinetic energy to heat.

Even with the lowest level of powder to make it out of the barrel youre still at much higher combined velocities than two bullets hitting at the far end of their reach which you almost certainly already know. The question is how to get a lower velocity and still get the bullet to leave the barrel.. well first logical step after reducing the powder is reducing barrel length, starting with 25% reduction and working your way towards 50 and 75% reduction because that reduced length will reduce consistency but at this point it is your biggest limiting factor regarfing your minimum velocities  Your other course of action is to use "stickier" lead. Most lead used in bullets is alloyed to minimise fouling but in this case its the same property that causes fouling that will cause the bullet fusion (essentially cold welding the lead) so a pure soft lead will increase your chances as well

There could be two reasons, the bullets didnt fully fuze in mid-air without support.. Either modern gunpowder, or too tiny of a caliber.  The composition of "gunpowder" and "black powder" are two different recipes. One is made from sulfur, potassium nitrate and charcoal, and the other is made from either nitrocellulose, or a mix between nitrocellulose and nitroglycerin.  Modern gunpowder, aka smokeless powder, is a high explosive and burns way faster, accelerating the lead too fast, resulting in too much kinetic energy on impact, destroying the bullets.  Black Powder is a low explosive, burning much slower, which also means lower muzzle velocities, meaning lower kinetic energy on impact, meaning its a good chance the bullets will fuse.  While I'm nowhere near qualified enough to have any right of statement, I would propose the suggestion of either a bigger caliber, or a slower burning black powder mixture.

You did over engineer that thing - first, you didn't need the shields as your safety is having the power turned off AND the power cords disconnected from the power source since black powder and modern gun powder won't spontaneously ignite. You also over designed those zip guns as you could have bought a pair of 1851 Navy revolvers, removed or locked down the hammers, removed the nipples and then easily loaded and slid the electronic firing mechanism through the hole for the nipple. There are devices already on the market which allow you to lock a pistol in place for precision firing and zeroing, so you didn't need to waste the time and money on the braces for the zip guns. As for using that huge chunk of metal beam to set the two zip guns up on - another waste of time and money as a solid wood table and a level could have easily done the job. All said, you could have had the rig built safely and properly over the course of a Saturday afternoon and for a fraction of the cost while having the real look and feel of redneck engineering.

You might be able to reproduce the impacted projectiles stuck together is you used larger projectiles. The mini balls used during the civil war were .69 caliber for the Harpers Ferry rifle, and .58 caliber for the Springfield design. These are pretty large in diameter compared to modern pistol projectiles. They are also cast lead which bullet molds can be purchased to cast your own. I wouldnâ€™t be surprised if you can find some commercially made these days as well. Slower velocity may help as well, you can down load the powder charge. From searching online, rifled Muskets of the day were capable of firing projectiles at over 1800 feet per second. That is on par with modern hand gun ballistics but slower than a lot of common modern military calibers. Bigger bullets made of more malleable material with more mass moving at a slower speed might be what you need to make the impacting bullets stick. I wonder if shotgun slugs might do a better job at what you are trying to accomplish.   Cool video, thanks for posting!

Question on your loading procedure, why did you leave the blocking mechanism open while loading?  It seems to me that is when it should be closed, in case the round went off during the loading process for whatever reason.  Leaving it open would allow the bullet to impact on the other barrel stand.  I would think it would be safer to close both blockers until you were ready to fire.  The other part of the question is why wasn't there a catch can to stop the fragments as they ricocheted off the blocker plate?  As far as your bullets exploding and the civil war bullets welding themselves together, you have two variables to consider, velocity and the alloys of the bullets.  Most likely those two bullets were fired a couple of hundred yards apart, so they would have slowed over the distance traveled and the alloy of each bullet speaks for itself.

As a pipe organ builder I cast lead pipes professionally and we work with different lead-tin alloys to achieve different capabilities. At the eutectic with a SnPb ratio of approx. 63% Sn and 37% Pb the melting point of that alloy is the lowest, about 183Â°C. If you can't reach that temperature with the colliding bullets it might be possible to use a softer  alloy with a higher lead content to achieve something that looks like actual fusion but is actually the softer lead holding on to each other. On this note it would be interesting to know if those civil war bullets actually melted together or just "stick" together really strongly.

As you mentioned, metal composition and speed are likely important factors. In some first shots, the colours of some of the metal fragments made me think of Bismuth crystallizing. I know that Bismuth is used as a lead replacement some places, because it's less toxic, but I have no idea if this also goes for bullets - it likely doesn't, because of the low melting point of Bismuth.  (The following is not meant to have subtext. I don't know how to communicate it clearly without using the words I've used, so please excuse me) Also, shape and size might be important. With more material, there's more material to hold the things together. Also, they were referred to as "miniÃ© balls", and a ball might be able to stick together more, because it doesn't have a cylindrical shape behind it, so it's not adding equal amounts of material for the duration of impact. However, looking at the bullets in the beginning of the video, it does look like they used to have more of a bullet shape, than a ball shape. But maybe they had a much smaller cylinder-to-sphere-ratio, than the bullets used in this video.

I think the best way to do this would be to cast the bullets out of pure lead, it will be much softer than the hard cast alloy you appeared to be using.  If you are worried about casting inconsistencies, you could build a centrifugal mold and use centrifugal casting, or, if you need more precision than this, just turn them on a lathe (maybe overkill).  Either way, I would probably anneal some bullets, to see if the dead soft lead sticks better.  If all the above still is not enough, I might remove the oxide layer (probably with an acid dip - vinegar should work), and maybe flux them if even the acid dipped, annealed, pure lead was not enough.  Honestly, I am guessing that a well-cast pure lead bullet should be sufficiently consistent to make the setup work and will stick just fine.

TL;DR: Buy a Hybrid wallet from KingsLoot. Easiest wallet for finding the right bills, better deployment of cards than Ridge. Doesnâ€™t deface credit cards like a Ridge will.   I had an aluminum ridge wallet back when they were a lot cheaper. I switched to the KingsLoot Hybrid which is about the same price as a Ridge or cheaper. The reasoning is that youâ€™ll have to get new cards ever 1 to 2 years with a Ridge because they scratch against each other. Thereâ€™s no soft leather protecting them from each other. So you can still have 3 cards you most frequently use deploy quickly, and instead of having a money clip where you have to pull all your money out and find the right bills and then fold them back up and slide them into the clip, you just open your wallet like a book, and tab through the bills until you find the right ones. Their customer service is great too. The first one I bought, the pull tab broke on the second time I used it. The old Civil War bullets were propelled by black powder. It's a slower burning lower power powder compared to today's modern smokelss powder. The 2 bullets from the Civil War hit each other at a much lower velocity and less power than the 2 in the video, but were still capable of doing devistating damage to the object they hit, usually an enemy soldier in this case.  The 2 bullets in the video had so much more power and speed that they exceeded the bullets ability to survive the impact of another bullet also traveling at the same speed. However, both bullets were hit at twice their own speed and twice their own energy. Therefore, neither of the bullets survived the impact intact.

Three relevant factors: - How fast they are - How well they stick - How massive they are With factors 2 and three not being wholly independent, since they are both influenced by the material and size of the projectile. Some ideas: Speed - use a ballistics gel target (may also help w/ stick), put the guns closer together and use less gunpowder, use shorter barrels. Stick - Put impurities into the lead that make it even softer to make it fuse instead of fragmenting or go the opposite route and use something much harder and stable to stop it from fragmenting altogether or mix both approaches so one almost passes through the other, until it loses enough speed to have the rest stick to it (least promising approach, but possible and would be cool if it works) Mass - If you use a larger caliber with less gunpowder, it will be affected less by air resistance and lose its low speed less rapidly. It also contain more binding energy and be less likely to explode all over the place. Sadly, this advantage could be offset by it also getting a larger transfer of kinetic energy due to the higher inertia of the colliding bullet. So going smaller might actually help more than it hinders.  Be that as it may, amazing video, I hope you don't mind my musings. Thanks for the great content, as always.

If the historic bullet had to align within .050â€ of another, there are 57,600 points in a single square foot.  If battle accuracy was a very optimistic 3â€™ x 3â€™ square, thatâ€™s 518,400 points that each rifle is firing at.  The odds of both hitting the same point is 1/57,600.   What are the odds the timing will be the same within even within 1 second?  In a 16 hr battle there are 57,600 seconds, so itâ€™s 1/57,600 for each shot.   1/57,600 x 1/57,600 is 1/3.3^9.    A civil war soldier could only fire once every 15 seconds at most or 3840 shots.  Thatâ€™s a probability of .00000116 per day, not taking into account angle of fire or ballistics or odds both bullets are capable of bonding together, which would take the odds truly into outer space.  However, at Gettysburg 7 million bullets fired by 160,000 soldiers is only about 44 shots per soldier for the entire 3 days.  Many of the collided bullets from the civil war look suspicious with little to authenticate they happened as described.  Very nice video - one of my favorites!

If the bullet is engaging the rifling, it causes over pressure.  If itâ€™s too far from the rifling, it causes bullet jump.  The key is the closest distance from the ogive of the bullet to the rifling of the barrel without the ogive making contact.  Imagine setting a brick on a glass coffee table.  The glass will hold the pressure of the brick. Then raise the brick an inch above the glass and drop the brick.  The brick will easily break the glass.

I'm pausing at 21:20. I haven't seen any part of this video past this timestamp. I want to inject my thoughts so far. In your best collisions so far, those closest to the nose-to-nose dead on ideal,  the bullets are shattering rather than melding into a solid mass like the Civil War two miniÃ© bullets. Why? My hypothesis has three factors: the velocities, the angle of collision, and the metallurgy of the bullets. To get the final result, you must replicate the Civil War situation as closely as possible. Both the Yanks and the Rebs used the same caliber and the same metal, a soft lead that was easy to cast around a campfire, whereas your modern factory-made .45 Long Colt projectiles are cast from a harder alloy designed to leave very little lead fouling in the barrel. When fired against plate steel, these bullets "splash" almost like they're liquid. A sufficiently soft lead alloy for this experiment should mushroom into a disc. The Civil War armies used black powder, i.e. charcoal, sulfur, and potassium nitrate, which produces relatively slow muzzle velocities and low chamber pressures. The kinetic data for the .58-caliber Springfield 1861 is probably available through one or more reenactor websites. Finally, you'll probably need to lose that offset angle.

Great work!  In my younger days, I shot muzzle loaders in competition and cast my own bullets. Civil war era bullets are usually cast from pure lead which is much more malleable than the harder and more brittle lead alloys from which  modern bullets are cast.  Pure lead also has a lower melting point which would also make it more likely to fuse at the temperatures generated by the collision.  Civil war era Minie bullets are also hollow based, which coupled with the softer lead would provide a greater bonding surface as the bullet skirts deformed upon collision.

Viewing this as someone working in the discipline, this was a GREAT video. I will be sharing this with our lethality team.   Modern cast projectiles are made of lead, zinc, and antimony. The lead provides the weight, the zinc improves shape consistency and complete filling of the mold, and the antimony provides hardness. Civil War Minnie balls were likely pure lead. Modern bullets are also swaged which also aligns the â€œgrainâ€ of the metal. Since modern bullets are â€œhardâ€ due to hard alloy and swaging, they shatter upon impact rather than fusing.   Also, smokeless  (cordite) propellants  are more brissiant than civil war era black powder. Check the pressure curves of cordite vs black powder to mimic Civil War projectile muzzle velocities. Modern bullets are made with an alloy of lead and antimony which produces a less ductile and malleable metal than pure lead which causes less fouling of the barrel or leading making it easier to clean but it causes the bullets to shatter into dust rather than fuse together. Using pure lead should be more successful than the modern bullets but the most ductile and malleable metal is gold and one gram of gold can be drawn into a wire over 2 kilometers in length and gold can be rolled into sheets thin enough to transmit light. I think you will never be able to do it. In order to fuse two bullets together they would need to be hot enough such that they could melt, and yet cold enough such that they would stick. The problem is if the temperature is right for one thing it ain't going to be right for the other. It may not be possible to do this while they are flying in the air, but let's say if the ammo was in an ammo cache, the fact that they are bunched up together may allow for the bullet to stay together long enough for it to cool down and fuse. Having said that it is far more likely that the specific example shown is simply a forgery (literally), it's already unimaginably unlikely that two people firing at each other would be able to do it so perfectly for them to hit each other in mid-air, not to mention make it hot enough for them to melt together and yet cool down fast enough before they get split apart. The math just doesn't add up.

Hey @smartereveryday The bullets spin when you fire them because of the spirals inside the gun. They both spin in the opposite direction. And upon collision, this produces enough friction to scatter them into tiny pieces. I say this because the spirals were designed to assist the bullet to pierce through harder materials. In this case, you definitely don't want the bullet to do that. N.B. I could be utterly wrong.

Chamber size matters, this is why a .223 is more accurate then a 5.56 chamber. The .223 Wylde chamber offers a compromise. Also you have to deal with pressures in the chamber. You canâ€™t just shorten a chamber either without understanding the peak pressures made by the type of powder you are using. The gap that the bullet jumps in a 5.56 chambering, also called the throat of the chamber being the distance between where the bullet leaves the case and engages the rifling, is critical to the pressure curve. If you put a 5.56 in a .223 chamber, the gun will eventually suffer a failure due to the pressures.   Now one question I have always had is about stabilization. There are 3 offerings of twist rate for at-15 style rifles that shoot a 5.56. The original twist rate offered in the M-16 rifle length gas systems of Vietnam. Then you have the twist rates of today offered for the M-4 carbine which is 1/7 but is also using a 14.5 in barrel. Now for civilians, who donâ€™t want to pursue tax stamps we will run a 16 inch barrel. My question. Does a 5.56 or .223 have the same stabilization when shot out of a 16 inch barrel with a 1/8 twist rate as the same rounds shot out of a 14.5 inch barrel with a 1/7 twist rate? I am genuinely curious because the rounds have the same amount rotations in the barrel. Both make two complete revolutions in the barrels. Also what is the stabilization characteristics of different grain offerings out of 1/7, 1/8, and 1/9.   Do we as civilians buy 1/7 twist rates for no reason. I assume the acceleration through a tighter twist rate effects stabilization. But how much?

If your test showed a low velocity pistol cartridge had to be reduced to little more than a squib load and still didnâ€™t leave much of the bullet intact, perhaps the original fused bullets werenâ€™t as authentic as the museum was led to believe.  The probability of the alignment with anything short of a carefully controlled situation is very low.  Very very low.   Doing this at battlefield rifle range is much much more difficult.  Then having equal momentum when fired with two different rifles takes those probabilities to an even higher level.  Even if a million rounds were fired in a battle, what are the odds 500k firing events would be able to meet the criteria to fuse bullets - compare that with the odds of someone faking a â€œone in a millionâ€ fused bullet, when counterfeiting civil war era items is one of americas favorite past times.  Your test shows it takes relatively low velocity - I canâ€™t help wondering if those velocities could replicated without shooting them from a gun by someone in a garage 200 years ago.  There were many pistols of that era with two barrels that fired with one cap and anyone with a black smithing forge could form a couple of rifle barrels so they curved and pointed at each other and the bullets donâ€™t have to be seated completely at the breach.  The low velocities might not have even involved black powder.  A burst of steam, or flammable liquid or gas could produce what are essentially pellet gun velocities.  Guys who searched battle sites for anything they could sell would all have plenty of relatively intact bullets to experiment with, or just cast bullets from an old mold.  As a kid we used to dig Calvary bullets out of a nearby hillside that was used for target practice and many of those could easily be reloaded.  Iâ€™m excited to see round two of these experiments with pure lead used - Iâ€™m betting the softness will require such low velocities that it will essentially disprove the authenticity of the original museum piece.

Excellent video! I think I know why the historical lead fused where the modern didn't, though.  Historical lead bullets are much more pure, and were almost always going much slower than modern bullets; the higher purity of lead gives it a lower melting temperature and makes it softer, and the lower speed is the critical factor. to me it LOOKS LIKE the 2 minet ball projectiles from the civil war hit *far from the muzzle on both guns*, giving both bullets sufficient travel time *that they could slow down*.  I think that slower hit, pushing and smushing the metal but without more force than was holding it together, is the  missing variable to make "two bullets melted together in mid air by their respective gun shots".

Anyone who has done LONG RANGE shooting (long range is dependent on the caliber/speed) knows how it looks and have found many disks of bullets like you found.  I have fused 22lr to a steel target when shooting long range because they are going so slow at that point that the disk doesnt completely fragment.  9mm also does the same.  Really all you did was capture smashing bullets but its nothing amazingly different from what all shooters knew was happening and shooting steel has been captured alot.  Also another solution for the bullet having to jump to the rifling would be to turn down the back of the chamber thus letting the bullet casing get closer to the lands and you would be able to use the shorter cases. If you cant bring the lands to the bullet bring the bullet to the lands.  You can also alter the set depth of the bullet in the case but there is only minor adjustment to be had there. Precision loaders  have been doing this for years for precise shots and you actually tailor a bullet load to a SPECIFIC gun.

I did some calculations: If I trust the guns-fandom-site the muzzle velocity of a MiniÃ© rifle is around 270 m/s and the bullets turned with approximately 140 rotations per second (considering a rifling of 1:78 which I suppose is meant in inch). On Destins slower attempts (26:43 and 26:48) his bullets traveled at around 140 m/s with approximately 400 +-10 rotations per second . Â @danieldonaldson8634Â  Most people that have never shot a slug through a shot gun or really old smooth bore musket don't understand how accurate they are at short ranges.  The rifling really helps for longer ranges and since both barrels are rifled in the same direction but being projected at each other the force would multiply not cancel out.  For that one would have to spin clockwise and the other counter clockwise at the same rate.  Trust me at 2 meters the smooth bore will not effect accuracy and the shot is really only about half that for this set up.

Mini balls were made with pure lead.   At least as pure as they could make back then.     The other factor I believe is the conical slugs have  hollow bases.   Kind of a bucket shape or skirt.   The modern stuff is solid and a harder lead alloy and it is doing what it is designed to do.  Penetrate.   The mini balls nose was fairly solid but the rest of the slug is like a skirt and it collapses on itself easier than a solid lead bullet.   Being hollow thin walls it would absorb the collision and reduce the amount of lead trying to penetrate.    Kind of like a crumple zone in a car.    Some bullet energy would be transformed to deformation and heat from friction of deformation.    The over all mass of the slugs is higher too so there is more lead mass to deform also.   45 slugs are like 250 grains.   Mini ball slugs are 1.14 ounces or about 500 grains of lead.    My 2 cents.    Another thing I recall from old reloading manuals was when guys would reload lite loads they used cotton of synthetic stuffing to fill the empty space in the case to keep the powder pack consistent inside the case up against the primer hole for more consistent ignition and burning rates.   I think the stuffing would burn up upon ignition.

19:32 That's not quite accurate.  The direction of the scatter plane around the axial direction (the axis along the barrels) is defined by the direction of the bullets' offset around the axis, but the angle is not the same as the tangent of point of impact. That is because the disintegration of the bullet is not instant, but happens over a period of time and continuous contact with constantly changing opposing forces due to deformation. Especially the normal force in the point of impact. Also, that particular force is much weaker then inertial force along with the axis travel direction. Etc, etc...   The phenomenon is helluva complex thing quite unlike for example shooting an armoured steel plate. The claim you  make is a sufficient approximation for people who are not interested in the nitty gritty detail, but you never were that guy yourself so I'm wondering why you don't go into further detail into that.  22:09 But this must be one of the most beautiful things I've ever seen. There are two things that I've noticed, and which could be responsible for the problems with the bullet fusion.  1. You're shooting a bullet directly at another bullet, with nothing but air in-between. All the energy in those bullets is dumped into one another, so it's only natural that they will shatter. Instead of trying to shoot the bullets slower, try having them meet in a different medium that is soft enough to allow penetration, but hard enough to deform the bullet, such as gelatin. This way, the bullets can slow down enough to not shatter, and the expansion process begins before they hit one another, which will give them more surface area to fuse to.  2. You're shooting modern bullets. Civil war era bullets were made of pure lead, and they were most likely cast. Modern age bullets are made of lead-antimony alloy, and they are made via different drawing and stamping procedures from billets. It is possible that your bullets won't fuse because not only are you using a more brittle alloy, but that alloy is also work-hardened. Sure, the modern, work-hardened alloy might not be significantly harder or more brittle than the original, pure lead, cast bullets, but I think that it's a big enough difference to cause problems at those speeds.

When I was stationed in North Carolina at Seymour Johnson AFB back in the late 1970's, some of the places I would stop at that had some odds and ends to sell. One of the things I would see was a section of a tree that would have a Civil War Bullet embedded from that time. During a battle the trees would get hit and over the following years the tree would grow around the bullet. Some of the loggers or lumber mills would run the logs through a metal detector and if they got a hit they would try and cut that section out for the tourist or visitors to buy. Don't know if they are still finding them and I kind of wish I bought one. Great video and I hope you try this again.

Assume both rifles were fired on level ground.  Based on an average shooter's height, calculate the time for the bullet to hit the ground, then take ballistic information for the mini ball round and determine the speed of the round at that time.  Assume the two bullets struck at about this minimum velocity.  Load to just about this velocity.  Use a soft lead and barrels with the least amount of rifling you can to avoid tearing forces pulling metal away at the time of impact (the two rifles using this ammunition at the time had a 1:78 and 1:72 twist rate which is nearly smoothbore).  Basically if you know it was accomplished under specific circumstances, try to get as close to those circumstances as possible.

In the Civil War, pure lead is what was used/available for the bullets. They wanted the balls to deform, and flatten out quickly to cause a wider, more devastating wound channel, transferring energy as quickly as possible. Most people shooting cast lead nowadays, are handloading for a hunting/wilderness protection round. More modern cast lead bullets are an alloy, resulting in a much harder, albeit more brittle lead. This makes for a better penetrating, narrower wound channel, to penetrate to the vital organs of large game, like a moose, or brown bear. Using the lower velocity loads you were making, with a pure lead projectile would, I believe result in the fusing of the lead together. The newer lead loading bullets you are using are too hard and brittle, so are fragmenting instead of being malleable enough to collide, and melding together. Awesome video as always. I think your problem is using bullets.  During the war they would have used manually powdered musket shots.  Musket shots have a poorly measured amount of poorly burning powder with poorly manufactured barrels and poor purity lead.  I think your going to need to consider getting rid of the rifling because the spinning bullet is imparting forces.  Use colder powder because the hot powder is causing the bullet to move too fast and to heat up too much.  Lastly, you're going to need to play with the purity of your lead to make sure that the hot lead is malleable and not brittle.

Beautifully done, as usual, and very well explained.  As a pure demonstration and proof of concept, it couldn 't have been done better.  BUT ----  I can't help wondering if such well-considered, planned, executed, evaluated and presented studies like this won't contribute to the further normalization of the American relationship with firearms.  Handguns have only one purpose -- to end a life. They're very efficient at it. 50,000 Americans die each year from gunshot, including 2000 school children.  In Switzerland 1 or 2 die each year.  14 in New Zealand.  Every post-industrial western democracy experiences less than 200 gunshot deaths each year.  Except us.  Why is that?  [Rhetorical question;  I already know the answer].  This video just might make a few people a little less gun-shy, to coin a phrase. These few reformed snowflakes may buy guns. If they're typical Americans most, but not all of them will store their guns properly, i.e. locked up.   There will inevitably be a few of these new guns left lying around to be discovered. Ok Destin, you have made such an amazing video I have a few potential improvements for you.  Exhibit A, civil war rifles were primarily smooth bore, this would make the projectile fly almost perfectly without rotation, I believe the counter rotation of the two projectiles may have caused them (once they contact) to shear apart especially for heavier bullets that require faster rotation.  Exhibit B, civil war bullets made in a factory were preferably made of lead but given supply being cut off for one reason or another soldiers would be forced to mold their own from ultimately anything but the preference was to use pewter dinnerware. this is not a lead bullet but an alloy of 85%-99% tin, containing different amounts of lead, antimony, silver, bismuth and other metals depending on the purpose, of course I'm not a scientist so I can't provide you with any exact numbers but I know this would vary the fusion temperature/ force, as well as the ability to resist shear force within the metals. I hope this message reaches you someway and I hope that this allows you to succeed in your mission of fusing two bullets in flight.   I love your channel and all you do to contribute to modern science and to expand the knowledge and creativity of adults and children alike all around the world.   Sincerely Evan Morgan

I'm going to suspect the reason you never got the bullets to fuse is that you are using rifled barrels. Those barrels are probably  rifled in the same "handedness", so since the bullets are traveling in opposite directions, they are spinning in opposite directions relative to each other. This is creating a great deal of shear, preventing the bullets from fusing.  (The Civil war saw the first introduction of rifled barrels part-way thru, it's possible the fused minnie-balls were fired from unrifled muskets)   You could try either unrifled barrels, or use barrels with rifling of opposite "handedness" .    Despite that, this whole thing is awesome, and the engineering of setting this up is fascinating.

As a reloader and competition shooter your theories on the velocity and how the powder charge works is incorrect my friend. I shoot a 6BRA and I "jump" the bullet 60 thousandths off of the lands of the barrel. This is done because at this point the bullet is exiting the barrel in tune with the harmonic whip of the barrel. The powder is then tuned from there. Usually 80% charges actually work best, however this does change based on caliber and what the barrel you are using likes. Generally speaking though a case that is maxxed to 100% powder volume will not shoot as good as a case that is at 80% case volume, just to give some hypothetical numbers. My powder charge is 30.2gr of powder with a seating depth of 1.7950 base to bullet ogive and I have a case volume max of 39gr. Tuning the load is your best friend in this test and measuring powder to an accuracy of .02gr rather than .1gr. Fantastic content though my friend.  There is also a ton of over variables with the brass, how it was annealed, the quality of the dies and how well they repeat neck tension, seating depth in comparison to powder charge, and much more.

In attempting to duplicate a historic curiosity of ballistics, perhaps an examination of the specific style of projectile would be relevant.    The Miniet ball was a vastly different projectile compared to modern projectiles, being distinctly more massive, with a cavity at the back, which was originally intended to have a powder charge, and function similarly to a gyro-jet munition.  It was discovered that the powder charge was being expended when fired, but the design of the projectile itself helped it far more effectively engage the rifling of the weapon, resulting in better gyroscopic stabilization, and prevented gasses bypassing the projectile, resulting in higher velocities.  I think the mass and shape of the projectiles may be directly relevant to the attempt to achieve projectile fusion.

Modern cast bullets contain lead, tin and antimony. Bullets from the civil war era were pretty much solid, soft lead. Solid lead leaves a lot of fouling in the barrel, which is why they started mixing tin and antimony into the lead, to make the bullets harder and less prone to fouling. The reason you're not getting that two bullets to fuse together like in the museum is that they're too hard and brittle, hence the shattering.  There were cases in the civil war where a soldier would go to quickly reload, the fresh powder would hit the hot lead fouling and set off the powder as it went down the barrel. Modern cast bullets still foul barrels, but not like the old solid lead bullets. If you could find some pure, soft lead and cast your own bullets you might get the fusing together you're looking for. However, you'll need to clean your barrels regularly, or the lead fouling will affect your accuracy. Do not use old wheel weights, as they contain tin and antimony to make them withstand the rigors of being a wheel weight. In fact, wheel weights are almost the perfect blend to make modern cast bullets.

Another thought, when loading the bullets in the case you might want to put an inert spacer (like a shotgun wad, only smaller) between the powder and the slug. This would eliminate the possibility of inconsistencies caused by the unequal burn of the loose powder in the casing. While allowing the use of the long casing with minimal powder loads.

You seem to have worked around the inconsistencies of how the powder column would lay in the case... But a quick suggestion...   I watched a video a few years back of a gentleman loading and firing an original antique Jaegar rifle... There was a rough spot in the bore that would tear the patches and cause inaccuracies. His solution was to load the powder charge, then load a measure of semolina on top of the powder before loading the patched ball. This acted as a spacer and moved the patch/ball combo up past the rough section of the bore without leaving a dangerous air gap between the powder and patch/ball.  Perhaps a similar approach would help in this case.

Checklists are amazing. I was working on the DARPA Urban challenge, and we had an intermittent problem with entering autonomous mode. We were able to enter autonomous mode with driver sitting in the driver seat, but couldn't enter autonomous mode when a driver was not sitting in the seat. We started building a checklist that allowed us to figure out what was happening. All of the drivers instinctively kept their foot on the brake, and a check from some early code was hard coded to not enter autonomous mode unless the brake pedal was pressed.

You're comparing apples and oranges.  Yes the composition of the "lead" is different, but the dynamics of the propellant as well as the ballistics given your choice of barrel length will play havoc with the equations.  The rifling difference between a Civil War era rifle with a minie ball vs modern standards shouldn't be too big of a change (there are still differences though) but the softer composition of the round can result in a better gas seal for the round, the extra barrel length will change the expected speed as well as the plasticity of the round after it has left the end and the slower burn/lower pressure of Black Powder vs Smokeless..... That's just "firing from the hip" variable wrangling....  Also, why not use a laser bore sight to get the guns aimed? You had a card at the desired impact point.... drop in a laser bore marker and then match them up on the impact card and lock everything down?  My initial thought was to have a bore laser on one end and a photo diode in the other gun so you know they're aimed directly at each other, but you did make a very good point about the slightly offset angle for hardware safety... ;) Good call.

Do you realize that this experiment debunked the Civil War myth about the two bullets colliding in mid-air? What most likely happened was someone took a musket bullet and stuck it in a hole in a target, then shot at it with another musket until they hit it. That would cut the velocity in half which is most likely going to keep both bullets from disintegrating. If you try that, I'm sure it will reproduce the two bullets that are stuck together. Made for a good war story, though. Also, with the powder/case capacity problem, an old trick is to add the powder charge to the case, then fill the case with a buffer, like poly fill from a pillow or something. I used to do that with smokeless loads in a 40-82 WCF. That will hold the powder against the flash hole for more consistent ignition. I would also recommend fully prepping the cases, trimming all to same length/ deburring the mouths, and also deburring the flash holes and  cutting the primer pockets to the same depth and square with the case head. One last thing; a good, heavy crimp on the bullet will ensure a consistent starting pressure. I always recommend seating and crimping in separate operations, so you're not still trying to seat the bullet while the crimp shoulder is trying to crimp the case against the bullet. Hopefully you're weighing everything; cases, bullets, powder (not using a powder measure - even the best powder measures will have a little variation). Like you stated in the video, you want to eliminate ALL variables.

The two Civil War MiniÃ© balls are huge .58 caliber, hollow based, conical bullets at about 500 + grains in weight each. Back then those MiniÃ© balls were made of pure lead, not an alloy. Judging by their appearance being fused together, they were probably only traveling at about 100 or so fps when they collided. The black powder they used then was far less powerful than modern day propellents. So you had a real miracle when those two MiniÃ© balls hit each other, fired from rifled muskets, using black powder, probably traveling along a rainbow shaped trajectory. It was fun watching the video, but I don't think you can duplicate in the lab what a billion to one chance pulled off 160 years ago .

The problem i am noticing is that the bullets are at high velocity, which causing then to shatter instead of fusing. A better solution is to make slow down before hitting each other. Maybe by placing some layer in between but it would be time and cost consuming. The better way is to use water to slow them down.  Place a small plastic container in between with 2 holes on each sides so that the bullets can enter the container. Close the holes with some thin plastic paper/sheet. Fill the container with water.  Now the bullets will hit each other in water. The plastic papers are replaceable for further experiments. Hope that i will see the results in the next video

It is probably the lead composition. Modern "hardball" lead ammo is a mixture of lead, tin, and antimony. This mixture helps prevent lead fouling, but the antimony is probably making it too brittle to fuse. I would try 100% lead, then some tin, and then more tin. Pure lead was standard pre-smokeless powder and used to be pretty common in cowboy action rounds.  Might want to consider bumping up the mass too. 45 caliber was a pistol caliber in the civil war, the rifles shot something like 68. It might help keep everything together.  On another note. I know it was a big battlefield, and we will never know the origin points or destinations for those two civil war bullets, but they might have saved two lives that day.

Destin, I respect you in many ways, but you did two safety fails from 5:18 to 5:21 of the video. Once the bullets are loaded, use some 4 0 steel wool to clean the lube off the nose of the bullets. Clean lead will fuse better than dirty lead. Same as bonding any metals, ask a welder how clean metdl welds versus dirty metal. Most store bought lead bullets are hard cast. These hard cast bullets contain tin and antimony. Tin reduces surface tension of the molten lead, allowing better mold fill out. Antimony is added to make the bullets harder. It also make the bullets brittle.  Get some pure lead and pure tin. Mix in about 2% tin by weight. This is enough tin to cast good bullets but not enough to effect hardness. Then cast your own bullets. Lube as usual,, load then clean off the noses as mentioned earlier. You might0 find it works better than store bought.
Or as Michael Peltier and a couple others noted below, smoothbore might make a difference.  The rotational energy from rifling might be just enough to break apart any fusion that might be starting.

In my experience I'd say in order to make the bullets fuse you are on the right track with velocity and lead alloy. Minie bullets are dead soft pure lead. The lead used to make modern pistol bullets is typically alloyed with antimony and tin for increased hardness, which also results in a more brittle bullet. This will result in more spelling effect and less potential for an actual Fusion of the two pieces of metal. Additionally, minie bullets are larger therefor having more lead that could be sacrificed on impact through initial spalling as the energy and velocity is depleted to a level that would result in the final fusing of the two projectiles. Definitely some excellent work here and you are heading in the right direction. Great video!

Noticed your variation in time to ignition.  To get more precise ignition time, reduce your heating time. This time can vary based on the thermal load of the mass of powder touching the element. To reduce the delay caused by thermal mass, use a high voltage capacitor discharge system in your ignition. This causes the heater to rapidly overheat, and the high current causes the coil to move, effectively exploding the heater and throwing molten metal through your main powder charge, and the heater breaking, will cause a high energy arc adding additional high energy to the now short ignition dwell time. I could assist with how to do Capacitor discharge ignition.  Wish I knew you were going to do this, so I could review and collaborate.  The high energy discharge greatly reduces the chance of a misfire, as the ignition energy is quite high and difficult to quench with thermal loading. It is more dangerous for electrical safety due to the amount of energy stored, but when the capacitors are discharged with a bleed resistor, the circuitry is safe to handle.  This would need a charge time in your pre igntion sequence to charge the capacitors.  Photoflash capacitors are recommended for this project. A 50 to 500 Joule discharge in a few parts of a nanosecond ensures a quick ignition.  There will never be a few miliseconds in the ignition sequence to cause discharge delays in the projectiles.

So a few major contributors to why you aren't getting fusion are probably down to the bullets you were using. Firstly, while yes the .45 is a very big bullet it's not near the size of the old minie balls used back in that day, both sides used a wide array of weapons but the two most common were a .58 caliper and a .69 caliper. Both are much larger traveling a little slower with over double the mass of the modern. That paired with this second factor is probably why you can't get the results you want, that second and arguably most important factor is modern ammo uses much harder lead alloys vs the very soft lead used back then. Oftentimes pure lead was used which mixed with the size and speed of the rounds probably allowed them to fuse. Your best bet would probably be to cast your own minie ball type bullets out of as pure of lead as you can, you probably could have a set of black powder barrels machined instead of using cartridges just using black powder charges and for the lead I would suggest casting them out of lead sinkers as they are probably the closest to the soft lead used in the civil war. Remember, the minie ball was designed to expand a good amount under firing pressures to engage the rifling while still being easy to load so it was a very soft lead, cast your bullets out of lead sinkers and I'm willing to bet they'll stick. You need to check the Brinell hardness of the bullets you are using, most hard cast bullets run somewhere around 20-30, while pure lead is around a 4. Before getting further than 3:20 .. as we're "thinking about this together" I wanted to write down my initial thoughts  Safety: - Both guns behind two metal plates. Metal plates have a cutout for the gun to fire through with a second plate slightly oversized to the cutout on the barrel side of the plate to cover the opening.  Second plate is hinged from the bottom with a latch above to be able to lock the plate in place before ready to fire. Triggers: - A Mount system with solenoids rigged against the triggers to be actuated by digital signal. Timing: - Sample size of time from trigger to barrel exit and round speed from 20 rounds (from the same box) fired from each gun, check for any major outliers and average it out. If any major outliers....... (to be filled later ;D) Destruction: - Same as safety system but keep the cutout circular and only slightly larger than the size of the gun barrel so in the event of misfire its more likely to hit the sacrificial plate vs the gun behind it.  4:10 - in and loading rounds manually for better control over the gunpowder charge is great idea 7:45 - LOL - the blastshields are awesome - even if could get similar results with a simpler setup. 9:35 - Scratch that - being able to remotely "re-safety" the system in event of misfire is the exact reason you'd want to be able to remotely the disengage and re-engage of the safety 13:56 - I would assume a copper bullet or such is going to be needed for them to fuse together. The FMJs seem to be too soft to be able absorb the energy from impact without destruction 32:15 - I'm curious how much having a second material inbetween also assisted with the fusion of the rounds. Multiple different possibilities I could see in my head... oxygenated outer shell of the lead being pulled away, having a dissimular metal inbetween.. reduiced impact energy.. etc.. etc..   P.S Obviously my 5 minutes of drafting aren't going to be the same as years of safety planning but it's def fun to see the thought process from my draft to Destin's final conception.

The bullets you bought no doubt contain small amounts of tin and antimony. Tin is added to lead in order to harden it, but tin and lead don't want to stick together all that well. Reloaders learned ages ago, maybe as early as the mid-nineteenth century that antimony can be used as a binding agent. Those old Civil War bullets consisted almost entirely of pure lead. I'd bet a dollar against a carrot that you'd get your bullets to fuse if you used pure lead bullets -- or at least bullets with as little hardening or binding agents as possible.  Other comments about rotational differences aren't a factor (I don't believe). Nor would the direction of the rotational spin. I've been reloading since 1971 when I was just shy of 13 years old. My very first thought was that your problem in not achieving any fusing of the bullets was the material. Tin and antimony were added as hardening agents to allow lead bullets to be fired at much higher velocities without having an excessive amount of lead fouling to be left behind and stuck to the interior of the barrel. This wrecks accuracy. That's why for years, reloaders would love to use old wheelweights or even linotype alloy for casting bullets. Even with hardened lead bullets, you can only get so much velocity before you reach a point of diminishing returns, hence the invention of cupro-nickel jacketing material for bullets.

im no genius when it comes to physics, but i have some theories on why none of them fused, for starters, the fact their not traveling straight on might prevent it from ever happening, even though it might not be totally repeatable to do a perfectly straight on shot. i also would like to think the ammo your using is just to small, as well as having smokeless powder may also be preventing you from getting your desired results, i think the best bet would be to recreate the conditions of your example from the civil war, speed is certainly needed for them to fuse but to fast and theyll just shatter, black powder may go slower as well as preheating the bullets more and provide some more favorable conditions. also again not entirely doable but play around with distances, im sure your example from the museum weren't fired from such close range, bullets will slow down the farther they travel in air. the hard part with bullets is at such a tiny and fast scale the physics become nigh unpredictable. im certain there is a set of circumstances where this is possible for the bullets to meet and fuse midair but its just so improbable it may not happen anytime soon.
