I'm no physicist but, In order for them to fuse it would be under the idea of friction welding. The main idea is high twist rate plus high compressive load. In order to achieve this you'd need a higher twist rate barrel with a larger powdered casing. The larger powder load would be simulating the higher compressive force as you're colliding two entities with separate Ke (or perhaps a larger caliber as well), rather than a moving force colliding against a static object. Lead solder welds around 300-350 centigrade, generating that temperature for a small amount of time would theoretically fuse whatever 2 pieces of lead that could transfer the Ke to that level of thermal energy. In 1862 (the museum shot) both sides were using mostly musket rifles.  The fact that they used a percussion cap meant some of the gas from the powder bled off, reducing the speed - and the calibers were larger, .577 and .58.  So it's heavier bullets moving slower, and the distance each traveled before impact was probably around 200', further reducing velocity by air resistance.  Increasing the distance between the barrels is impractical for an experiment... I wonder if there's a safe way to redirect some portion of the gas to mimic the likely velocities?

I think the problem is two fold. One, the material the bullets are made out of isn't working out and the other reason is probably because you're firing too close together and need more distance so the bullets can slow down enough and have less force. You can't use less powder, or less explosive powder, because then the bullets won't leave the chambers and you need the bullets to engage the rifling at the moment of ignition, which I believe means the only solution is to lower the force transferred into the bullets on impact by increasing distance.  Of course distance will add another factor to solve for, that being air pressure (wind). You'll definitely get more misses with more distance. One final possibility would be to use shorter barrels. I suspect that will leave the problem of too much force keeping the bullets from fusing.

When you were talking about the bullets fusing... if I remember from my days doing civil war re-enactments, a bullet from a 3 or 5 band musket weighed at least half an oz or even an oz (or MORE!) of pure unalloyed lead.  It also had a heck of a lot smaller load of slower burning black powder rather than modern smokeless.  The bullets from the long colt are far too small and going way too fast to 'fuse' - as seen, they simply obliterate each other.  Considering their mass you'd have to put just a pinch of powder behind them to slow them down enough for the lead to deform at the point of impact but NOT liquefy.  Also, those fused bullets did NOT strike square on nose to nose.  In that instance the rear of the bullet imparts forward energy that rebounds from the point of impact, causing the remains at the center to recoil.  Where larger bullets are fired slowly and strike ever so slightly off center the rear of the bullet sheers to the side which lessens the rebound force caused by the trailing material. This is perfectly illustrated @32:26 - the wallet prevented the trailing material from transferring its inertia into a rebound, it was captured by the material of the wallet before it could rebound.  And copper jacketed modern rounds simply won't do it - too slow and the copper will prevent the lead from interacting and any faster than 'too slow' they'll either fly apart or bounce off of each other.

Shooters found over time that pure lead bullets were inaccurate and caused a lot of barrel leading when shooting them where they directly touch the rifling.  So they would harden the bullets by adding tin and antimony.  Most use something close to or exactly a mixture called Linotype.  It's 84% lead, 12% antimony, and 4% tin.  It makes the bullet much more stronger and stops the leading problem.  But...  it also makes the lead flow differently during elastic and a partially in an inelastic collision.  It fragments and flows differently.  That's why you are seeing a 'shattering' of the bullets more.  You need to try pure lead bullets and preferably ones with a lube ring on them with lube in it to help prevent leading up the barrel.  You will also need to inspect the barrels every 10 rounds or so for lead build up in the rifling.  Second.  If you are using black powder, you can throw the charge of powder and then backfill the case with dry ground corn cob on the powder and then seat the bullet on top of it.  It may help with the inconsistency and allow you to get to a lower charge without having the primer flash over the small powder charge.  Good luck, and I await part two.

While I have no personal experience handling firearms, as someone who's learned a lot about them over the years, as soon as those first two hit and exploded, I felt I know what was wrong. Older bullets, even back in the old west era of things, were made from softer lead than modern bullets, at least on average, and black powder firearms used the same if not even softer lead. Then there's the velocity of the modern powder and rounds, block powder produces lower pressure and thus slower velocities than modern counterparts. Combine the two differences and it felt obvious why they were exploding instead of fusing together like the MiniÃ© balls could, at slower velocities and with softer lead. You thankfully came to a similar conclusion, but figured I'd share my thoughts from a different perspective arriving at the same conclusion. If you plan on trying this again, I'd recommend looking into reaching out to your local or nearest re-inaction group/organization and try using compressed air to fire musket rounds.

To pick a couple of nits, the â€œbulletâ€ is the projectile that leaves the gun when itâ€™s fired. â€œCartridgesâ€ that consist of bullet, case, powder, and primer, are what are loaded in the gun prior to firing. Itâ€™s true that a bullet is loaded into the gun, but without the other components of the cartridge, it would never go anywhere. And the other one is that the formal name of the cartridge you were using is just 45 Colt; the â€œLongâ€ part is mistakenly added by many shooters, but it is not part of the formal nomenclature.   Itâ€™s also not the least surprising that your bullets disintegrated when they hit each other in flight. Even lead 22 Long Rifle bullets fired from handguns will typically disintegrate when striking hard materials like steel. As you surmised, the Civil War bullets must have been traveling very slowly when they met to have not disintegrated as well rather than fusing together. I believe youâ€™re also correct that the type of bullet metal may have affected how well they would fuse. Unjacketed bullets of the type you were using are typically made of a lead alloy that contains some hardening metal such as antimony to help prevent leaving lead residue in the gun barrel. That may make them more brittle and less likely to fuse together.    And although I canâ€™t be certain, I believe the one piece you recovered that had copper (gilding metal) on both sides was from the base of the one jacketed bullet. When shooting such bullets at steel targets, itâ€™s very common to find fragments like that on the ground in the area.

GREAT project!  Some tips from a lifelong marksman.  * shoot pure lead full wad-cutting bullets. * Don't leave light power charges laying around in the case.  It can undergo DTD (deflagration transition to detonation).  Single base powder is nitrocellulose.  Double-base powder is nitrocellulose with nitroglycerine.  Both are high explosives.  Powder BURNS in a gun.  If it transitions to detonation, it will open up the chamber just as if cut by a knife.  This happens with very light loads.  The solution is a buffer that is made to hold the powder against the primer.  This is usually polyester cotton that is pressed tightly against the powder by seating the bullet.  In the 70s out wives got together and bought Dad, my brother each  a series 70 Colt 1911 Gold Cup.  We all stepped out into the driveway to fire a few rounds.  We were using my medium power semi-wad-cutter hand loads.  They had just enough powder to reliably cycle the action.  I shot first, a three round group.  All through 1 hole in a piece of slate.  I dug them out of the dirt and two were welded together.  Dad went next.  A master marksman who lost the National Matches inter-service marksman competition by one point in 1942, he  took his shots.  Again through the same hole.  I dug them out and found all three welded together.  I still have those.  So welding bullets together with modern ammo is possible.  Everything has to be juuust right and the bullets should be soft 100% lead.

This is probably going to get lost in a sea of comments, but I believe the reason you were struggling to get the modern bullets to fuse like you want is because modern lead bullets are hardened/annealed better. If you had cast your own bullets using a mold you likely would've seen better results but the store bought bullets you were using were probably much harder than the correct Civil War era Ball munitions. The reason you see them fusing after hitting the aluminum wallet is the impact with the aluminum caused the bullet that hit first to get hot enough to be more malleable. As it came into contact with the second bullet, this hotter and softer bullet molded to the still cooler and hard one. Your fragmentation in the video shows that the majority of the fragmentation came from the bullet that didn't hit the wallet first.   I personally believe that in order to get a good fusion on the bullets you have, you should figure out the annealing temperatures of lead and try to heat them, then cool them to make them as soft as possible, then when you fire them, fire them at very low speeds, similar to that of black powder cartridges, and not modern smokeless speeds. These two things should get you the fusion you are looking for on impact.   Whether you revisit this or not, it was an extremely interesting video. Thanks

Awesome project! A few tips on variables I have are these three based on the civil war fused bullets. Black powder of that time was way less powerful compared to todayâ€™s smokeless powder also being such a short distance on your masterfully crafted test rig the velocity is a big difference. The bullets were just good old lead like todayâ€™s non jacketed target ammo but you are using .45 caliber, most civil war caliber ranged from .57-.70 so much larger surface area for contact. Finally bullet design, many civil war bullets had a deep cup in the back side to both hold powder but also expand to seal tight to the rifle barrel preventing tumbling along with lose of pressure. I see a lot of work went into setting this up but for success I recommend using 12ga 1oz slugs in a smooth bore at low speed. Hope this knowledge and advice helps you get the preferable results, thanks for sharing this great video!

Hey Destin, I'm sorry if this reads like a gotcha comment. This is clearly a triumphant moment in your career as an engineer, science educator, and curious person. But since you invited your audience to have a conversation about safety, I'd rly value hearing your thoughts on the implications of scattering so much lead across an unassuming, safe looking, pristine environment.   I know the US has a proud history of gun use. I know lead represents a cheap, dense metal that makes for great bullets. And I know recreating flukes from the civil war means using the same materials as the civil war.   But lead is dense metal because it's a literally a "heavy metal". It's severely poisonous. Frankly, exposure to lead will do the opposite of making someone smarter every day. It's brain poison.   And unlike a lot of metals, it's non-ferrous, so it's not as easy as just waving a magnet over the ground and collecting the old shards. That lead is now a part of the soil.   I get that I'm overstepping a bunch of cultural implications that come from firing guns in the US, especially for someone trained as a projectiles expert. I'm sure this probably isn't a normal way you think about your results. But dude, it's hard for me to watch a science educator spread lead in a place it looks like kids could roll around someday.   Even if it doesn't seem like kids could play in this space now. That lead is just going to sit there invisible and soon forgotten, and no one knows what the future holds.  So would you be against scientifically reflecting on lead toxicity as a safety risk? After all, maybe I'm being ignorant. Or maybe you'll learn something that shifts your safety protocols and models something new for gun owners or people who fish with lead weights. Either way, I'd value a thoughtful conversation to get smarter on the subject.

Not necessarily true that "muskets" of the civil war were all rifled. While it was true primarily in the North that they used the 1841 rifled musket either a .58 or .69 caliber as standard issue. Due to the manufacturing advantages the North had. Even at that there was still smooth bore muskets used by the North until they were phased out as the war progressed. Approximately half the weapons issued by the South at the outbreak of the war was about 50/50 smooth to rifled issued to troops and didn't improve throughout the war. Instead with weapons imported from Europe during the war, they ended up with over 100 different rifles being issued to troops, up to and including the old British Brown Bess smoothbore and even flintlocks converted to fire Mini ball ammo.   All that TLDR said, I think it's possible he has a point. Assuming both bullets from the civil war are even the same caliber, the slow twists of the rifling of the time is not even close to the twists per inch of a modern pistol, if nothing else it was a much slower twist from a period muzzle loader. Then even though it's a Minie Ball it doesn't mean it wasn't fired from a smoothbore musket. There's documented battles during the war of troops out of ammo using cut nails and even rocks to fire at the enemy, so it's possible it was shot much the same way so long as it could be jammed down the barrel.   So I don't disagree that rotation could be part of the issue.    Another is, we're talking about on avg for the time a 500 grain Minie Ball, that's so much more mass than they used. Speed could be a factor, with documented bullets hitting the wool uni's they wore and falling to the ground. Testing from the period rifles showed that muzzle velocities as low as 200 fps are possible. The North even recognized that with velocities that low wouldn't punch through wool at distances of approx 100 yards. So they had a recommended powder load to achieve the desired effect. However a very common thing for solders under fire in the war was very light powder loads, a lot of time no powder loads at all. There were rifles found with over half a dozen Minie balls in the barrels with no powder.    Mass, rotation, speed a combination of the three could be at issue. But hey I can be completely wrong, and I'm ok with that. Sorry for the legnth and probably way to much content in this comment. ğŸ˜…

Now admittedly, I am no engineer, but I can think of three variables that might impact your experiment.   1: Bullet Alloy... (You touched on this at the end of the video) Bullet alloys have changed a fair bit over the years and so it is possible, likely even, that the lead alloy used in the civil war is different than that lead alloy used today to make bullets.  For instance, a lot of bullets today are specifically designed to fragment on impact for safety reasons.  A softer alloy may be more prone to fusing instead of fragmenting, especially at lower velocities, which brings me to the second issue...  2: Gun Powder... (You also touched on this at the end of the video) Guns of Civil War era used Black Powder as a propellant, whereas guns today use Smokeless Powder... And black powder has a slower burn rate, thus lower pressures, than smokeless powder does... Resulting in lower bullet velocities.  3: Differences in Firearms... (This I didn't see you touch on.) Many of guns used in the Civil War were muzzle loaders, which likely also contributed to the bullets fusing instead of fragmenting... Breach loaded firearms were around then, but not so much in common use... And unless the firearm was a breach loader, it was likely that it had a Smooth Bore Barrel instead of a Rifled Bore... Which would Definitely have an impact on the outcome of the colliding projectiles.   I would also suggest looking at the design differences between muzzle loaded bullets and modern breach loaded bullets. And try to match things up, load for load, (ie; bullet weight, etc.) to the types of firearms used in the Civil War.   The only variable we don't know is how far apart the two men firing the guns were in the case of the museum piece... The distance of which would have slowed down both bullets to some unknown degree.

I wonder what is alloyed with the bullets your shooting based on the fragments. 1) The Civil War bullets were pretty much pure lead. 2) Most commercial casters use some tin and antimony in their alloy. The tin helps reduce surface tension and helps the lead fill out the mold. The antimony does not actually alloy, it forms crystals in a matrix of lead but acts to 'harden' the bullet so it doesn't leave deposits of lead on the bore of the barrel. BUT the harder bullet doesn't smear as much and tends to fragment when it hits a hard surface (and hitting an oncoming bullet counts as a hard surface) 3) Years ago I was dealing with refurbishing an old machine and it actually has the Molds for casting it's bearings. I first cast regular lead bearings and when I ran the unit the lead smeared into each other. What I found was originally they didn't have Babbitt alloy but did have DIFFERENT alloys in the two pieces so they didn't friction fuse. Recast one with 2% tin and the other with 4% they didn't fuse and worked And consider galling in aluminum or stainless, two pieces of the same alloy will gall easier so the engineers specify different alloys (or in aluminum have anodized parts, and use graphite or other 'never seize' compound for stainless)  So based on that experience,  I believe that you should make sure each of your bullets are pure lead to try that variable

I just made the same suggestion. Antimony is used as a binding agent to get tin to bind to lead, which hardens bullets. It's desirable to harden lead bullets so they can be fired at higher velocities without leaving an excess amount of lead fouling in the barrel. Your instances where accuracy was an issue was probably due to the rifling becoming filled with led since you're using full on lead casings. This will foul a barrel and it's rifling MUCH quicker than using a copper jacket. After just a few rounds the rifling between the two barrels were no longer exacting by design. This immediately will start causing differences from one round to the next resulting to quite a few different variables from difference in velocity, accuracy and bullet stabilization. This normally doesn't start causing issues until around 25 - 50 yards but when you're looking for equal performance and results between the two firearms at the exact same time then this certainly becomes a contributing factor when looking for such exact results. I do a ton of different firearm competitions from idpa, 3 gun and bench shooting between tons of different calibers. When using calibers that primarily use full on led bullets you need to run a patch through the bore way more often compared to copper jacket bullets. I've actually seen significant increases in velocity from one round to the next at 7 yards when the bore & barrel start becoming more fouled.

There's multiple reasons why your bullets might be missing each other... anywhere from inconsistent powder burn rates to heat levels inside the barrel causing an ever so slight amount of warping.

I suggest that the spin is part of why they didn't fuse. Were the civil war guns rifled? If your barrels have identical rifling, then they will impart opposite rotations when they're facing each other. This will mean the bullets are spinning opposite directions and feeling unnecessary shear force at the point where they meet. You need to replace one of the barrels with one that has rifling curved the other way. That will make sure the bullets are rotating in tandem when they meet instead of rotating in opposition.  I could be wrong. Stir welding is a thing, and that's nothing but shear force. Although, the shear force in stir welding is not parallel to the meeting plane like the bullets are experiencing.

I'm certain that the reason why the bullets aren't fusing is 1) Because they are far too close together. I have no doubt that the Minie bullets that fused, were fired probably well over several hundred feet apart, therefore, most of their energy was lost, by the time that they met. 2) As you mentioned, the lead composition is completely different, and there isn't as much of it, since you're using a .45 Long Colt. You need to use something like a shotgun Sabot slug or similar. You could even use black powder rifles with a .50 caliber Sabot to more closely mimic the Minie ball and the ammunition of the era. It would be much more labor intensive, of course, but I think the results would be very satisfying!

Black powder musket ballistics vs. Smokeless powder cartridge ballistics are different. Smokeless powder explodes and ejects the projectile like directed shrapnel. Black powder burns. It burns much slower, so pressure builds slower. Pushing the projectile like a spitball.

Lead composition isn't a major factor.  You have a dozen variables to contend with: The Civil War bullets were fired from a longer distance and both had air-drag-time to slow them to just the right velocity to fuse rather than explode.  I doubt you could mimic a head-on strike in under 4000 rounds (2000 attempts) by adding distance, and that assumes you have the distance precise already.

Once you think you've written a foolproof plan, make sure to hand it to a fool (or a child) to check over. Having a naive appraisal of a plan is the single most powerful reality check, if you're willing to listen.

I reloaded and cast lead bullets for many years. FIrst thing i noticed is the modern bullets are to hard, containing Antimony and Tin in the lead hardens them making them more brittle and likely to shatter. the Brinell hardness of a historic Lead ball was near pure lead soft enough a fingernail can dent the tip. They had to of been fired from a good distance with the loss of energy to not shatter still and instead fuse at the perfect temperature.

Not sure if this is relevant or not, but not all Civil War rifles had rifled barrels.  Most of the rifles used by the  South were muzzle loaders, either manufactured or "home built", and used .50 or .58 cal round ball or mini ball shaped like a 'bullet".  The North had mostly rifled barrels.  Both used Percussion caps, which weren't always made exact, powder was not the modern smokeless we use today and had inconsistent burns.  The LUCK factor, 2 projectiles hitting each other enough to fuse together is extremely low and doubt it happened more than a hand full of times.  Just like replicating mid evil time weapons using today's methods, is not going to give the same results.

One thing I guess here is that yours are hitting each other at muzzle velocity, whereas 2 rifles firing at each other in the Civil War would probably have been at least 100 yards or more away from each other and lost some velocity over the distance travelled along with air resistance and trajectory arc by the time they smacked into each other and fused, and not necessarily fired simultaneously depending on how far each travelled over different distances to meet. Either way, still very well executed.

I've seen those bullets fused together, too... I've wondered what would have to happen for that to occur. NOW, thanks to you, Destin, I'm wondering if it didn't ACTUALLY happen in someone's arm or leg... with just enough flesh or maybe hitting in a saddlebag or backpack... a pouch or canteen or even a waterskin... JUST enough substance to contain the lead so it didn't fragment.      I DO KNOW that bullets were "very slow" back in the day. They were even slow enough that the advantages of rifling were debatable... which is saying quite a lot if you think about that. It's not that there wasn't a significant upgrade, but that upgrade in shooting for precision and accuracy was PLAUSIBLE to argue about. That means there had to be marksmen who knew their smoothbores well enough to consider the advantages at least somewhat dubious... figuring they could compensate with purely skill.       We DO know better now, but we also have smokeless powder and derivatives of nitrocellulose that burn more reliably giving a consistent supersonic speed. That's a HUGE step in technology when it comes to basic projectile weaponry. AND the difference between a bullet penetrating water and exploding within a few inches of the surface is whether or not it's a supersonic round...       ANYWAYS... My point here is simply this. JUST IN CASE, you try the slower and slower rounds and continue to see them ricochet or fragment rather than fuse together... Try some different targets of varied thickness and material, ESPECIALLY ballistic gel. Not only is the stuff FUN to play with, it CAN be a decent analogue for penetrating flesh in case the originals WERE cut out of a soldier... Some small nitpicks:  - Rifling is singular, not plural  - The best way to achieve repeatable accuracy is to free float a barrel, not clamp it down. That is likely the source of most of the inconsistency.  - There will always be some gas leakage around the bullet, as long as it is consistent, it's not an issue.  - Jamming the bullet into the rifling can cause issues with accuracy  That said, fantastic video.

Just a hypothesis, but surely the shape of the bullet is also a factor in making them fuse? The Civil War used minie balls. Which, depending on the manufacture, tend to be more pointed with a smaller front end diameter than a modern .45 long. Having less surface area on the initial impact may increase the time before the bullets fully collide.   Basically the initial impact would cancel out most of the force between the bullets, slowing them down and letting them more easily fuse on complete impact. This may be somewhat confirmed by what we saw with the wallet fusion at the end, the bullets were slowed to a point where they still had enough force to fuse, but not break apart.  I hope that makes sense, think about the collision at 22:00 but if the bullets were moving at a slower rate after the initial impact which could allow them more time to fuse. Itâ€™s all just a theory though, watching this video and trying to dissect the physics of it is really making me realize how absurd the original Civil War fuse is!

Destin- I'm wondering if purity and accuracy play a part in it also.  If you think about it, back in the time of the Civil War we did not have the manufacturing , conditions we have now,  meaning and especially the technical accuracy.  What I mean by purity is when they manufactured their gun powder, the purity of the mixture could affect the burn rate and explosive power of it.  Our gunpowder today is made to such tight specifications, but that didn't exist back then.  And with a less pure mixture, the velocity provided would be decreased causing a slower impact.  Also with purity, the bullet material then may not have been as pure as today's.  They might have used any materials laying around to melt down and make their bullets, which could drastically affect the properties of the metal upon impact.  Every thing we manufacture today has such tight tolerances and specifications that didn't exist in that period,   And back to the gunpowder, the Civil War guns were loaded by hand with powder, it was up to the operator to measure out the correct amount.  And when you're under fire and just trying to get a  shot off, your odds of getting the correct amount in is greatly affected.  So when you look at all the variables (purity of powder, amount of powder and purity of bullet material) you have a lot to deal with.

Momentum is a vector, so yes, it's a cancellation, i.e. a vector addition with a zero vector as a result. Kinetic energy is not a vector, so there can't be a cancellation. All the energy is transferred into heat and the kinetic energy of the fragments. The sum of all the fragment momentums is also zero, at least in theory.
I think thats a semantic distinction and depends on your reference frame. Both cancellation and transfer work.

I appreciate your emphasis on safety.  Civil War era black powder will burn slower than modern gunpowder, which might be a factor unless that is what you were using in your reloads.  You used 45 caliber bullets, and the museum piece might have been 58 or even 69 caliber.  Big & slow is different from smaller & faster.  Barrel length might affect completeness of burn.  Twist rate of the rifling may very well have been slower, or even non existent in the case of smooth bore muskets.  Now you might need some twist for stabilization and repeatability, but the spin is going to affect the stick, as at the moment of impact both bullets are doing an opposite spin. At the time of this comment's writing, I am at about 16:50 minutes into the video. I've paused it because I had a thought about why the experiment does not seem to be working as intended. At this point in the video, Destin is about to start analyzing what factors could be affecting the experiment unfavorably.  My idea is that the merged bullets in the museum is likely two shots that collided with each one consisting of differing metal composition. One is denser and allowed the other to deform into it. The gunpowder used back then was likely pre-measured in packets, but there likely was not an efficient standard to ensure they all were equally measured. So it likely was the one singular moment where the right amount of everything was a perfect combination.

The Civil War bullets would most likely have been Minie type made from pure soft lead.  These have large hollow bases that may or may not have had a wood plug.  They do not shatter like a solid bullet, but fold or collapse.  It is likely the two fused bullets at the Museum contacted each other after flying some distance.  I would try using Foster slugs from a shotgun barrels with reduced powder charges or air released.   The twist rates for Civil War rifled muskets were very slow in the order of 1 in 60 to 1 in 72 inches.  Some were left hand twist and some right hand twist, so it is possible that two bullets could strike each other rotating the same direction and reduce the shattering aspect.  There are several examples of fused soft lead bullets around from the Civil War and the Revolutionary War.

As far as I know modern bullets are chilled lead (quenched immediately after casting) making them harder and probably more brittle, you might be able    to soften them by annealing them, that would probably be easier than casting new bullets

Distance will slow the velocity of most bullets as such as the one during the civil war. Also have to consider how hot their guns were after firings for many many hours. Percussion caps used in the civil war burned even hotter than their older counterparts. I'm going out on a limb to suggest that during the civil war one or both of the bullets fired were preheated to near melting points inside the musket/rifle already. If you look at the pictures of the ones from the civil war they are almost a perfect mushroom. Similar to what you would see if you heated up lead it would expand pretty evenly. It's possible to keep the barrel from prefiring or misfiring from overheating with the fluids they would use to clean the black powder out of the gun, usually a watered down ammonia or just hot water.

I am sure that you have been told this in the comments, but, just in case, you will want to use lead bullets that are similar to what they used in the Civil War. The lead they used was not as hard as we use today. Modern lead is not as pure as that which we used to use - today we use antimony to harden the lead. This results in the shattering the high speed camera shows. The purer, softer lead will deform more than shatter and should bring you closer to your desired result.

Without having watched all the way to the end, my guess is that you are not going to get them to stick for two reasons.  1) the bullets are likely not "lead", but a "hard-cast" alloy.   &  2) your muzzle-velocities are probably also too high.    Civil War era cast bullets would have been basically pure lead, and the muzzle velocities of field loaded rifles would have likely been sub 1kFT/Sec, with significant drops in velocity after 100 yards.  I think your bullet material and the energies you are impacting at make you goal (to recreate the museum piece) impossible. Edit:  Finished the video and feel a bit vindicated. For slowing down bullet speed its safer to change the powder. You can get extremely high , unsafe pressures , when using low charges, because the primer can flash over the whole charge .  Each type of powder should have ballistic and pressure tables based on manufacturing data in guns almost exactly like yours, with added pressure transducers for gathering chamber data pressure.  Also, different primers may make different pressures, as well as different lot numbers of powders.  For extreme accurate competition, bullets are also weighed, balanced, cases trimmed and measured for concentric walls, etc. lots of variables

The spacing from the bullet to the rifling is an important measurement in ballistics and is why headspacing is so important for accuracy.  You could also try solid copper bullets. When casting solid lead bullets, the hardness of the lead is important and can be manipulated by using different lead alloys.  The hardness of the lead in jacketed bullets is not as important because the jacket keeps it all together and prevents the lead from contacting the barrel. In jacketed bullets the lead is often much softer.  When the bullet is just lead, the lead needs to be harder to reduce fouling, or excessive amounts of lead rubbed off in the rifling. When under loading or using light loads, often called cowboy loads because of the use in revolver trick shots, a packing material can be used in the case to hold all of the powder to the rear.  That could be paper wadding, sand, flour, talcum powder, bread, or any number of relatively inert materials.  However, when you use a packing material, you're decreasing the volume and some of the packing material will ablate, so you'll get a bit higher velocity with the same powder load.  Finally, handgun and shotgun powder burns quickly to utilize the shorter barrel, but you're working towards maximum control, not maximum velocity, therefore a slower more steady burning rifle powder might produce better more consistent results.

The lead alloy is too hard. Bullet lead alloys contain antimony and tin. Pure lead is much softer and less likely to fragment in shards.  Plus the bullet velocity is way too high.  You need softer lead and slower bullets to attempt to fuse the bullets together. Also, you might need to have a thick copper jacket around the lead to resist some of the expansion pressure and help the bullets retain more weight after collision.  It is easy to cast pure lead bullets at home but difficult to make jacketed bulletsâ€¦ you will need assistance from a bullet manufacturer for thatâ€¦ and they all have way more important things to do. To get access to their equipment might require purchasing an entire production day which could exceed your net worth.

I've seen a number of comments on reversing the rifling of one of the barrels to get the bullets spinning on the same direction. This alone, may solve your problem, but, as a chemist, my initial thought was to look at the composition of your bullet.  If the "lead" is not pure lead, but instead has lead oxide or other compounds mixed in, they may be hindering the fusion upon collision. Lead naturally forms a patina of PbO, which can further react and form PbCO3 and PbSO4, and any of these will make it more difficult for the bullets to combine. If pure lead is in contact with pure lead, you should end up with a much easier fusion of the bullets. Most cast pistol bullets have antimony and tin in them to make them hard enough to withstand the pressures generated by smokeless powder. Most traditional muzzleloader/black powder bullets where mostly lead and very soft.  General rule is that the harder a cast lead bullet is the more brittle it is.  Also if you use the heaviest bullet weight available that is appropriate for the cartridge you can reduce the velocity of the cartridge.

I'd suggest a couple of design changes. Use a pneumatic process as opposed to gunpowder to fire the bullets. In that manner you can more accurately regulate the "chamber" pressure. If using a pneumatic device you could dial down the chamber pressure to get whatever velocity you want. Maybe even use a pneumatic piston. Secondly, if the rifling engagement is a potential issue (as far as being able to get the bullet out of the barrel) switch to a smooth bore and use a card wad behind the bullet. With no rifling to engage that variable is removed from the process. A slightly undersized bullet to the bore diameter would also allow lower velocities to be achieved.

I'm sure someone has mentioned it by now but I'm feelin nerdy so here goes: If you are using smokeless powder and a different rifling twist rate you may not be able to achieve conditions close enough to fuse two lead bullets together like the 2 minie balls at the museum. Smokeless using the pressure from a building gas pressure from burning of powder. Blackpowder not so much. Are your rifling twist rates at all close to civil wartime rifling? Did the museums display say anything about distance? If two bullets were fired at each other from across a long field bullet drop might also influence angles. Also, your leads purity could be causing extremely small variations. During the casting process today, any two bullets you make are very close in composition. In the 1860's you not only have impurities from the periods casting process, but you have 2 different casting impurity chances from two different factories even if the procedures were similar. Purity might be questioned if one side couldn't use all lead because of a shortage. :)  -Kirk (former UAH grad student)

This is amazing. My theory about the fusing is probably due to the speed of both projectiles as well as the bullets having a different shape than the MiniÃ© ball of the Civil War era. Since the Minie is hollow like a cup, the force of impact compresses the center mass of the bullets "into" the hollowed out sides of the cupped section. With the speed and heat, the metal being compressed into itself is probably heated high enough to fuse it into one solid mass before it can basically flower out completely into bits. Since the bullets you guys used were "whole" bullets, the impact force on contact pushed all that lead at the core but had no "hollow place" to go into, and so the entire center mass compresses at the middle while expanding radially outward like a flower and all that excess material essentially "pushes out" the rest of the side material until it splits apart into bits.  It's kind of hard to explain, but imagine two plastic cups. One has been frozen with water inside it, making it a solid block (the bullet you guys used), and the other is an empty cup (the Minie ball bullet). If you put both cups upside-down, and then smash both of them at the cups' bottoms with a hammer or maul, the ice-filled cup will probably shatter while the empty cup will get crunched up or flower open in almost one piece.

Really smart people ask other really smart people for their input. A person can be really smart, but no one is a subject matter expert in everything. Different types of Safety Procedures have different subject matter experts.    This in no way makes the smart person look dumb. I can think of person after person claiming to be the smartest person in the room, who are never wrong, and belittles actual experts, calling them dumb. That is a demonstration of self-delusion that actual smart people don't demonstrate. Even Einstein level geniuses have teams with a variety of people with a variety of skills and experiences.  Getting 2 locomotives to collide head-on... easy peasy since both are on same track. Getting 2 cars to collide head-on... a little bit harder. Guide cables and drives needed. Getting 2 bullets to collide head-on... not easy on paper, almost impossible in real life.   Margins for errors is minuscule. Bullets have very small frontal area contact zone. A millimeter off in a 3D space is same as miss. Cartridges never exact same load. Bullet mass never exact same. Closing velocities never exact same. Breach firing devices never exact same. Timing never exact same.  There is only 1 variable you have control over... the number of tries it takes to succeed. Maybe it can be done with first attempt, not likely. Better have boxes of bullets and lots of time. It could turn out to be a long day on the firing range.

There are a couple factors that weren't mentioned in the video that may be affecting the outcome of the tests. Destin is much smarter than I am so he likely considered these, but I figure they are worth the mention. First, were the civil war bullets fired from a smooth-bore or a rifled bore? This would have an effect on exit velocity as well as accuracy. The second is somewhat related. Were the civil war rifles which fired the fused bullets loaded with black powder or smokeless powder (smokeless powder was starting to be used around this time, but Im not sure in this case)? Black powder has different burn characteristics than smokeless which might affect the final outcome.

The bullet "jumping the gap" before engaging the rifling not only effects velocity but also the accuracy of the bullet. Every shot will engage the rifling a little bit different and you will get inconsistent accuracy like you experienced.

Just some wisdom I have picked up being a competition shooter for years...  I was always told that you get the most consistent velocities when your case is 80% full of powder.  It needs some air room to expand into during initial ignition.  Full cases generally have less consistent velocity, so you may have had the opposite of the intended effect going with the smaller case.  You also want to keep it above 50% capacity or the primer might flash across the top of the powder instead of the back.    The rifle jump theory is probably part of it too.

During your discussion about misses I believe the following might help provide some insights:  I know in rifles, when reloading and testing accuracy there are things to consider such as "barrel harmonics" and "barrel whip". Since no 2 barrels can be the exact same, each reacts differently to different power charges. Not sure how much that affects these short barrels you used. However on 20" barrels it is pretty easy to see on high speed cameras. The barrel will literally whip/bend during the shot.  Second thing in regards to testing accuracy is bullet selection as the tail end of the bullet can change how the gases affect the bullet once it leaves the barrel and gets engulfed by the exiting gases behind it. Again you can see this on high speed cameras. Thus why boat tail bullets tend to have better down range accuracy. Again not sure how much that would affect you as the distance is pretty short.  The other thing is, jumping the "lands" is most definitely going to cause accuracy problems. However in rifles there are varying degrees at which it affects it. I've had some rifles that want a .02" jump and some that want to be jammed into the "lands". I've also had some guns not care about jumping the "lands" too. Just comes back to barrel harmonics.  Other side note:  Consistency between bullets and cases also matters. I bought mass produced ammo and reloaded myself, and have found that consistency between rounds does vary. I've had it where in a pack of 50 bullets I've had a 5 gr difference between the lightest and heaviest bullet. Same for powder. Not every time do you get a consistent charge.

1. To fuse the bullets, you need big heavy slow moving bullets. 2. There is no need to power the bullets by gun powder. They make perfectly fine large bore air rifles. 3. There is no need to have both bullets moving. The same collision can be obtained by having one of the bullets suspended on a soda straw or a string. 4. Start by shooting at a steel back stop. If the bullet shatters there, it will not fuse to another bullet. You need something that will smush against the back stop with minimum loss to shattered pieces. This means, of course, soft material at slow velocity. 5. Copper jacket bullets cannot fuse, the copper material is too hard. Definitely only soft lead. And they can be round balls, although your museum Minie bullets are cylindrical. 6. OK, I understand, you really want to have two moving bullets driven by gunpowder. Once you get the collision parameters worked out doing things the easy way, you will just need the camera work with the two moving bullets.

Problem with the bullets shattering and not fusingâ€¦  My first thoughts are 1) Hard cast lead projectiles instead of the soft lead used during muzzle loading eras 2) Modern velocities from modern powder are much higher than old black powder days.  The difficulty with converging in the intended location. You essentially cannot get bullets to behave in a consistent enough manner to make this process 100% reliable. This is an inherent limitation of the objects under test. These are variables that cannot be controlled to any exacting degree.  1) Even with an electronic ignition, you are relying on the consistency of the primer and powder mix, which will not be exact for every primer. Primer compound is often hand mixed. In theory the powder, if from the same batch/container will be the same, but the mix may not always be completely humongous enough to be perfectly consistent. Plus other factors will come into play 2) Small differences in powder amount will result in different burn rates and resulting velocities. Itâ€™s a narrow window you need to have them meet in, so small changes make a big difference 3) Even something as simple as how the powder is piled up/sitting in the case will affect the burn rate. The less powder you use, the less consistent. Filling a case full so that you get slight compression of the powder is more consistent, as there is no air gaps that make for room for the powder to shift. Slight compression can even help reduce differences caused by small differences in the amount of powder. 4) Even small differences in neck tension (the amount of force that that the cartridge case grips the projectile) can have a big impact on how the process progresses once fired. Which means another variable that affects the velocity and timing of the projectile. 5) Having the barrels offset at an angle already puts you at a disadvantage. A necessary measure for practical and safety concerns, but one that increases the difficulty  I get the desire to try to isolate variables for consistency in experiments, unfortunately small arms ammunition will never be as exacting as one would want for such experimentation scenarios where timing is crucial.  So letâ€™s continue the video and see what gets figured out.  Edited for spelling and clarityâ€¦  Edit 2â€¦ Using shorter cases, yeahâ€¦ That long jump from the chamber to the leade and then rifling will make for an extra variable.  Edit 3â€¦ Looks like I was spot on with the lead alloy and velocity thing.

As a big Napoleonic warfare buff with a hobby in ballistics, I'm almost 100% certain modern bullets aren't going to fuse specifically because of the materials they're made of. Older bullets that were cast in molds by the soldiers themselves were soft. It was a soft lead, melted over campfires. And that's why those bullets could fuse together if they collided in a one-in-a-million shot. It's a materials problem. I think you were 95% of the way there, but if you really wanted to duplicate the Fredericksburg Miracle, you'd need to have done what you originally mentioned, and cast your own bullets. It would have created more variables, sure, but modern bullets are just too hard to fuse properly. They'll either bounce or shatter.

Lead has a fairly low fragmentation velocity, which is why modern rifle bullets are always jacketed or even monolithic copper alloy. Have you considered loading super heavy bullets that reach back into the case? Not only will it give you the advantage of a lower muzzle velocity, but since kinetic energy scales with the square of velocity, you'll double the drop off of velocity in the collision and very significantly reduce the amount of energy per mass of lead. I bet that your collision velocity is still way higher than those low-BC antique bullets, which probably had lousy muzzle velocity and surely bled off a lot of energy pushing through the atmosphere. Biggest downside is that you may need to cast your own bullets and even make your own die, but that's probably peanuts to you folks! Great video. Thanks for uploading it, and good luck refining your technique!

Rifling.  Your bullets are rotating in opposite directions, creating a shearing force between them.  That shearing force is probably preventing them from fusing together. Reverse the rifling in one of your barrels to make both bullets rotate in the same direction.  Thereâ€™s a decent chance the the Civil War era bullets were shot from smooth bore  muskets, and therefore not rotating at impact.  Or possibly, since rifling was a relatively new development in small arms during the Civil War, there may not have been a standard rifle direction so the two fused bullets on display in the museum could have been from oppositely rifled barrels.

The reason the Civil War bullets fused together was probably because they were made out of iron. The kinetic force was so strong those two crude iron bullets probably turned back into a malleable ingot for just a brief fraction of a second but it was enough for them to merge together. That's just my guess though.

3 thoughts: 1. The bullets used in the civil war were often shot from smooth-bore muskets. The spin, while helpful for ballistic repeatability, is a strong counter-force keeping them from fusing and instead directing more energy radially.  2. Metallurgy matters as you noted. The thinner the oxide layer the better I would assume. Many civil-war era bullets were cast on the battlefield, so are likely to have slightly less oxide layer. As to the actual lead vs alloy makeup, I am ignorant.  3. Even that 1' might be imparting enough influence to affect the meeting even if not plain or obvious. Try narrowing it as much as you can justify. Your risk tolerance is not for me to judge.  I suspect a longer rig might also benefit impact-site ballistic stability, but also increase error. The tradeoff may not be worth it.   Also I should note I feel you should have at least one shield lowered at all times when not firing. I noticed you had both open when loading the first barrel. Love the stuff you do but I have to take exception to this one. Civil war minie balls were pure lead and also bigger - typically 54 or 58 caliber - which means more mass and more frontal surface area to absorb and distribute the energy of the collision over. The "balls" were also typically fired from a lot further away from each other, sometimes hundreds of feet, than the 10 or so feet apart in your setup. Therefore, the velocity of the balls would have been slower by the time of impact and thus less chance of them disintegrating. So with all due respect, and as impressive as it was, I don't think your test was a legitimate replication of what caused those minie balls to fuse.

I don't know about it being an "impossible shot," there are at least three known examples of combat produced bullet-to-bullet fusings from the American Civil War.  The most familiar is located in the Visitors center of the Petersburg National Battlefield Park outside Richmond, VA where many thousands of visitors see it each year.   These are soft lead 58 caliber 'Minnie" balls, but they have points rather than round front surfaces so this had to have been a near perfect collision.

Of course, you had problems with that. You are definitely correct. That much bullet jump can cause major inconsistency. That is why precision ammunition is tailored to each barrel. For example, people who shoot f class will use tools to find jam and then hand load all of their ammunition to have the same jump to the lands every time.

I think I might be able to shed some additional light on your failure to fuse the bullets together. Firstly, the weight of the bullet. A .58 caliber Minnie Ball would tip the scales at about 500 grains. Roughly 2x what the .45LC projectile weighs. That's a lot more material to you have to tear up before you reach 'splatterfication' (That's a Huntsville reloader term, btw) The second comes from velocity Those two projectiles in the museum probably met mid air with less than 1,000 fps combined velocity. Remember, smokeless powder is much more energetic than black powder. It becomes very difficult to drastically slow down just by reducing the amount of powder because you end up detonation and not deflagration. Pressures can vary wildly and thus velocities.  I think you are on the right path about the lead content of the bullet. Go back to your original idea of casting the bullets and use as little antimony as possible to harden the lead... just enough to keep lead from fouling the barrel. The move to black powder loadings. There are a ton of CASS loadings for 45LC that use black powder and I BET good money you can get your bullets to fuse.

Amazing videos! I have noticed a potential issue that may help you get the bullets to fuse. Your barrels have rifling in the same direction. When you point them at each other, the bullets become counter rotating. At the surface where the bullets touch, the rotating shear forces would be extreme. for the bullets to fuse the momentum of rotation of the bullets would need to cancel each other out. If you had one barrel rifled in a clockwise direction, and the other rifled in a counter clockwise direction, this issue would be resolved. Love your videos, keep it up!

You should try it with larger, roughly 50 cal size projectiles... like with shotgun slugs. Use a smoothbore thats also an open bore with zero choke. This will make using less powder a less of an issue. They may even be able to be fired with the primer alone. Sort of like how a 40mm projectile works by using just a primer. The primers may help eliminate any fluctuations you'll have with powder. The 12 gauge slug will imo match the design of a mini bullet better too.  You're going to also have to clean the lead better where you want it to bond at. Any oxidation haze color is a good sign that they won't bond. During the time when these flukes happened they was using freshly casted lead, that was likely in a pouch and jumbling around, and scrubbing each other and that prepped the surface to bond best by doing so.  Trying to do this with such small bullets is the main part of your problem, that and the rifling. By the time you add enough force to free itself of the confines of the barrel it will already be moving at catastrophic speeds. So to me it seems like the bigger the better. Think two 4 bore sized slugs being more likely to bond and not damage each other vs two 556 tiny bullets that will zap each other. Hope this helps, good video

Â @mycosysÂ  To me i think the issue is the temperature of the bullets.    They are shooting out of short barrels.  This will be traveling much slower than out of the barrel lengths common of that time period, 30 - 40 inches was pretty typical.  A 1853 Enfield rifle  had a 39 inch barrel. That is a much longer barrel which means the bullets have more time to be heated by the combustion gases, and also greatly increasing the travel speed of the bullets.   A one inch change in barrel length on most rifle calibers can easily translate into a 25-50 fps difference in the bullet speed. Also that is a much greater length of Rifling to encounter in a 39 inch barrel, which puts lots of additional friction on the bullets which would increase their surface temp.   With the increased friction and heat of the bullets imparted by a longer barrel length, I think the probability that they could get the bullets to fuse would greatly increase.  He mentioned the Gunpower used in their loads being slower, but seemed to be referencing the amount of powder used. Powder volume and Powder Burn rate are two totally different things.   The ideal Powder (burn rate) that would be most usable out of a short barrel would be vastly different from the type of gunpowder one would want for the same caliber bullet being fired out of a much longer barrel.   It's not just about decreasing or increasing the amount of powder, you need to utilize the right type of powder (e.g. 'Hogdon Titewad' has a much faster burn rate than 'Hogdon Varget' powder). I use Varget in my .308 Win custom loads, but I wouldn't use Titewad as it's too fast a burn rate and will finish burning long before the bullet leaves the end of the barrel, so no help from combustion to continue to force it's way down the barrel and spin itself from the friction caused by the Rifling.  If you used a very slow burn rate powder meant for rifles in a load for a handgun with a short barrel, you'd have a massive amount of unburned powder still after the bullet left the barrel which would result in some huge Fireballs out of the end of your handgun.
MiniÃ© balls have a depression in their tail that flares out during firing to engage the rifling. That and they are larger than the ones used here.

Â @SyntheticFutureÂ  That old lead likely had signifigant amounts of silver and zinc in it as contaminant, which will enable fusion. Modern lead is likely contaminated with things like Antimony, Calcium and Cadmium, all there to make the lead slightly harder and thus more rigid, which is added to make it more suitable for the largest use of lead, in modern car batteries, which need a durable thin grid that will not degrade, so they can up capacity and lower the amount of lead not in active plate material. The silver and zinc are stripped out in production, as valuable by products, then the other materials are added.  The lead they have likely is from recycled batteries, they need either old lead off a roof, at least a century old, or to go to a mine and get a few kilograms of ore, refine it and get a lead that matches 200 year old lead. Probably needing to have a higher silver content in it , along with a little copper, zinc and tin added as well, which are all things that are present in roughly refined lead. A few kilograms of Galena, plus a silver coin and a few zinc pennies, will probably make a nice soft alloy, that will both cast well, have a good finish, and also stick together on impact.

The engagement with the rifling when loading the firearm is crucial. You'll notice with semi-auto pistols, and more significantly rifles at range, the first shot from a magazine will be offset from your grouping. This is because all subsequent shots are loaded by the semi-auto loading system operated by the recoil or gas, and is consistent. Meanwhile first shot is loaded by manual release which has a different force/speed, causing the first shot to seat differently.

Destin, Something to consider in your pursuit of bonding two bullets together. Modern bullets have a composite material for truer flight and a smoother, slicker (if that is a word) outer surface. I do not recall what the materials are, but I believe the intention was to reduce the amount of material that bonded to the rifling inside the barrel. Of course cheaper materials also mean profits. Anyway, the bonded bullets at the museum would have been a mostly pure lead allowing the two bullets to actually mold together almost like clay. My mind is not as sharp after a stroke some years ago, but I think you are on the right track slowing velocity. The material probably the key to getting them to actually fuse. After watching this, my conclusion is that the Civil War era museum piece is not the result of a high-speed collision (they did not have high-speed cameras at the time and had no way of knowing what two bullets colliding would end up looling like, they could only guess), which leads to the conclusion that the piece in the museum, although likely historical (old), is a forgery, to make it look like two bullets collided mid-air. And you can see this from the impact zone in the middle. It looks like the metal 'flowed' more slowly and almost melted together, which, as this video so well demonstrates, would not happen in a real high-speed collision. Yes, heat is generated by the collision, but lead has a certain thermal conductivity, and the heat generated by the collision could not have traveled through the entire mass of the bullet to soften it to the point of making it malleable enpugh to fuse the two bullets together on the insanely short timescale of the collision. It looks more like the museum piece was created by heating both bullets up to the point of plasticity, and then slowly pressing them together in a press. Also, due to the short impact timescales, the lead would not have time to 'flow' like the museum piece shows. It would plastically deform and fragment like in this very excellent video. So the museum piece might be a very nicely crafted piece of art, but not the result of a real collision.

I was going to type a long winded reason to be skeptical of the original bullet shown in the museum... But I'm more interested in pointing out my thoughts and letting the comment section deliberate some ideas i'm not really seeing here.  The bullets fused together from the American Civil War at the beginning of the video show what appears to be a significant amount of lead. After watch Destin's video, we are aware how much explosive force is occurring even in the "slow" bullets. We don't need to recreate the scenario in which the specimen was made.  A simple test to find out if the museum piece is a fabrication would be simple to weigh the amount of lead and measure two minie balls. A couple of thoughts. Civil war era rifles using black powder were lower velocity than modern powder. And there might also be a difference in the lead and contaminants used for the bullet making it more brittle than what was used in the past. Add in the fact that those bullets shown fused were fired at a good distance, also lowering the velocity by the time they hit and you've got some variables you need to account for. It may also be the oxides formed on the outside of the bullets from having sit for a while compared to possible recently poured balls in the civil war bullets. The shape of the ball rounds compared to the bullets could be a difference too, as well as the spin rates from the rifling compared to ball rounds.

Modern bullets have antimony and sometimes tin, added to harden the bullet. This reduces fouling in the bore caused by today's higher velocities. The amount of antimony depends greatly on the source of the lead. This is often because the lead is sourced from tire shops in the form of wheel weights. Over the years I've cast many bullets. Pure wheel weight makes the bullets very hard to the point of shattering and quite dangerous for indoor ranges. I've also sourced lead from lead-cased telecommunication cables. This is 98-99% pure lead and makes for very soft bullets that hold together very well but foul the bore considerably. My ideal mix is 9# of pure lead with 1# of a wheel weight. This reduces the fouling to an acceptable level while providing a safe bullet for indoor shooting with Pyrodex.  Additionally, Pyrodex produces more pressure than the black powder used during the civil war. So, I would suggest using actual black powder along with pure lead bullets. This will more closely replicate the velocity and bullet type as found in the museum. If you would like, I can provide the pure lead bullets for 45LC.

Noting your concern about loading density, this is a real problem with bottle necked cases ( low loading density of powder leads to inconsistent burn, wildly varying pressure to even dangerous levels)..I am suprised that no one thought to bulk out the density with a wad ( be it paper, cream of wheat, the idea is that it occupies volume, it is soft so you will not abrade your rifling), this is known in the rifle community with both low density loadings as well as fire forming brass ( think of this as blow molding donor brass to a new chamber dimension)

I haven't finished the video yet, but when steel changes temperature, it moves.  That steel I-beam painted black and given the length, it's going to move and flex as the outside temperature changes. It's not enough to cause misses, but it will change the point of impact.   You found a big issue when you equalized the jump to the lands.  Another thing you can do to lower the velocity is use a slower burning powder and shorten the barrel length.   They manufacture a wide variety of burn rates in powder.  Pistol powder and shotgun powder have the fastest rate because pistols have short barrels and need the powder to do its thing quickly.  Shotguns are smooth bore, so having a slower burning powder isn't beneficial for building pressure because there isn't much resistance caused by the pellets and wad moving down the barrel other than the mass of the projectile.  Rifles are going to have the slowest powder.  There is a greater resistance caused by the rifling in the barrel cutting groves in the bullet.  In rifles having a longer barrel, you have to have a slower burning powder because of the increased time the projectile is exposed to resistance. Your problem isn't the bullet composition or your carriage load. The bullets you saw in the Smithsonian are probably .50 cal shot from much longer barrel rifles. They would have had a lot more power than your projectiles. The thing that you are probably overlooking is how far the bullets traveled before hitting each other. If they traveled sever hundred yards before colliding, they would have lost significant amounts of energy.  Given the amount of research devoted to civil war battles, you could probably figure out the weapons used in the battle, the distances the engagement happened at, and the volume of powder typically used. Add in some basic math and you can estimate the velocity that the impact occurred at.

Your on the right train of thought about the lead. Most store bought bullets are made with a lead alloy. This is to keep the barrel from leading.  The minie balls of the civil war were made of pure lead which is softer than the alloyed used in modern bullets. You can buy pure lead bullets that are used in black powder cartridge bullets. I have bought them in the past for the .45 long colts. I believe it was from the Missouri Bullet Co. I think the pure lead will hold together better. â€‹Â @tis7963Â  Seems likely this slow rotation would permit the fusion of the bullets. The travel through the space at the collision looked like about 1/2 inch per bullet or 1 inch total. Since the bullets are spinning in opposite directions the relative rotation at the point of collision would be about 1 rotation in 24 inches -- 2 x (1 in 48) -- yielding about 1/24th of a rotation (15 degrees) relative to each other using the less aggressive rifling of the civil war rifles.  I went back and looked at the video and it looked like the bullets got about 1 rotation running the length of the measuring device (which looks like about 12 inches) which means about 4 times as much rotation as an equivalent civil war bullet, or 60 degrees. That feels like enough of a difference to explain the bullets not fusing.  My theory of what happened in the aluminum wallet situation was, at lest partly, that the wallet material slowed the rotation of each bullet just enough that they collided with slow enough relative rotation to fuse. Each bullet, after all, independently hit the aluminum on its side of the wallet, and deformed the aluminum which would have given each bullet time to be grabbed a bit by the aluminum before the two hit each other and mashed the aluminum out of the way. Â @smartereverydayÂ  rifling was invented in about 1498. By the 16th century, after many experiments, it was recognized for the benefits to precision (reproducibility) of the trajectory and a more accurate shot at longer ranges. However, because the rifling of the barrel had to be engraved by hand, it was not until the mid-1800's that the Industrial Revolution made it common place. So, at the time of the civil war, there was mix of smooth bore and rifles, i.e. old and new tech. Rifles would have been likely been in the hands of snipers. Some owners of smooth bores may have gone to the extra expense of having their barrels rifled to take advantage of its benefits whether for hunting or warfare.

It looks like the lead wasn't just softer, but also those bullets originally had a very deep hole on the rear end, as they were supposed to create a tight fit only by flaring out inside the rifle rather than being a tight fit from the start. Also these bullets were originally grease-coated, which may have helped a lot with preventing oxide buildup too, and may therefor have increased the chance of welding together. It would be amazing if you could start using use some lenses with less chromatic aberration. These highspeed shots are so incredible to witness, but they are often hampered by the strong green/magenta fringing which also reduces the overall sharpness of the final image. As much of a workhorse the Canon L-series photo lenses have been, they have always been rather prone to said fringing; something canon has typically compensates by fixing with in body processing, which really only works on photos, and isn't passed to other manufacturers.  If it is something you might consider, I would recommend at least the relatively affordable Zeiss Otus series primes, but ideally the Zeiss CZ.2 / LWZ.3 series zooms. They are pricy, but are considered among some of the sharpest cinema zoom lenses. To go the extra mile, whatever lenses you use, it is best take them to a cinema camera rental house get them shimmed for the particular camera you intend to use them on. Notes prior to watching entire video. Â  1.  Lead bullet vs jacketed. Â I think you (all) figured that out. 2.  Alloy bullet vs pure lead bullet. Â As you mentioned, Civil War era bullets were pure (within manufacturing tolerence) lead bullets.  Those are far more malleable than current alloy (mostly lead, some tin and antimony).  The current allow reduces leading (the deposits left after shooting) by making the bullets harder, therefore more frangible.  You sort of grasped this.  Probably should cast pure lead bullets.  Pain in the foot to regularly clean barrels, but would make the bullets more malleable and easier to 'fuse'.    3.  Blunter vs Pointed bullet. Â I think you (all) figured that out. 4.  Velocity high vs. low. Â You did figure that out. 5.  Use of barrel only guns vs commercial rifles or handguns. Â You did figure that out very well. Good job. 6.  Reloader works on consistency in accuracy, taking loading density, 'jump' to leade and insuring consistent velocity.  You did understand this, I thing much could be solved with a shorter cartridge, with the barrel chambered for the cartridge chosen.    All in all, great job. OK, I can help you. I'm actually surprised a little that you didn't think about this. Here are a couple of the reasons you did not get the result you were looking for is this. 1. The mass of a mini ball is significantly larger than the 45 long colt you are using. There is more there to absorb the shock. 2. The speed of the bullets are affected by two factors, one, muzzle velocity and distance. A mini ball getting fired from a musket is actually moving quite slowly and my guess is that the distance of two bullets that were fused together was between 50 and 150 yards, which means that these bullets slowed down quite a bit from the muzzle. Unlike your frame where they were hitting in just a few feet away. 3. This is the only part I am guessing a little, but I think the hardness of the lead is different in lead you use today verses the lead they used in bullets back then.   The best way to accomplish what you are trying to achieve is to research the actual muzzle velocity of a mini ball musket and then try to determine at what distance the two original mini balls traveled before hitting. They look like they were deformed pretty close  to the same which tells me that they were approximately the same distance to the place the two bullets met. Then determine how fast the bullets were traveling when they hit. If they were 100 yards away, you can go to a ballistic calculator based on bullet weight, ballistic coeffeciency, and original speed. This will give you the FPS speed they are traveling at a set distance. You can imitate those variables by adjusting the speed at the barrel.   You really need to use a bullet the same caliber and weight to give you the best chance to duplicate the original shot. I would love to collaborate with you to help you achieve your goal.

You anticipated my comments about velocity and lead composition but I have another, or two.  I have seen that display myself and wonder if caliber might also have something to do with fusing in this case.  The bullets in the display appear to about .56 caliber, normal for the era, which has a lot more sectional density than a .45, and it would have been propelled by black powder, which could possibly develop even less velocity.    The museum display states that the bullets are two Minie Balls which adds another factor to consider, the actual construction of the projectile itself (goes back to sectional density) with the Minie being a relatively long hollow base slug instead of a solid slug.  Looking at the videos it appears that most of the destruction of the bullets could be the result of the back part of the bullet retaining significant velocity and driving the nose to fragment, where a Minie with its "skirt" might just collapse into the resulting fusion.  So much fun.

I love watching these videos, not so much for the content, but for the fact that always get me thinking.  Having some inner monologue firing off a bunch of questions, potential problems, potential solutions to those problems, etc.  it just gets the grey matter sloshing around in the skull and it feels great,  it almost makes me feel a part of the process (even though obviously I'm not).  As to the fusion problem I believe the issue is in fact speed, as these bullets will not have been fired from the distance you're firing them so they're slowing down in flight,  now making them farther and farther apart most likely would be an exercise in futility to get them to hit at the same spot but maybe you could figure out what that speed is needed by slowing down the bullets manually,  maybe have one bullet be fixed in space so that the relative speed between the bullets would be half the speed of one bullet, or perhaps don't do gun powder to fire them instead maybe use high pressure air (baseball cannon miniaturized?) so you can more accurately control that speed without needing reloads.   Then once you have your rough speed required for fusion without destruction, then you can go about figuring out how to get that speed with gunpowder fired bullets, heck maybe you go back in time and don't use jacketed bullets but maybe external powder charges.

Lock time is part of the reason why Remmington made the model 700 EtronX which used an electronic ignition system and not a hammer. the theory is that the lock time drops to essentially the speed of light, has zero inertial impact on the barrel alignment with the target, and you are only dealing with the dwell time. in the end though, no human ever could make use of that improvement and it wasn't worth it. I believe stack projectile weapons like metal storm were the only other major use of electronic ignition, but those required it as hammers are not possible for stacked projectiles (not counting things like the AN-94)

I honestly think its a materials issue. It's very likely that Civil War era lead had quite a few impurities in it compared to modern lead used for bullets. Lead has a low melting point for a metal (600ish F), is soft, and dense. The sudden added heat on impact might make pure lead act almost like a fluid (rapid sliding apart of grains) which causes the breaking apart we see in the HSC footage. Lead with certain impurities might behave differently and stay more solid allowing the pieces to fuse instead of splatter. Been a long time since I studied any materials science, so I could be wrong but my gut tells me that is the issue. I also vaguely remember reading that as rifle velocities increased, jacketing lead became more necessary to keep it from breaking apart as it has a tendency to do at higher temperatures and muzzle velocities.

Good Job!  I do think a pure lead bullet would be more likely to fuse than what you're using.  It appears that your lead bullet is mostly lead, but almost all have a bit of tin, zink, or antimony to increase the hardness (Brinell value).  Pure lead bullets are not commercially available (I don't think) as they will foul your barrel after a dozen or less rounds.  Pure lead has a Brinell of 5 ---it may take an old time with the experience to cast some for you.  It can be done with great precision ----I have shot 1/2" 100 yard groups with hand cast 45-70 bullets ----they can be very consistent.  I don't have the knowledge base, but there are people who do.   You may be able to find a higher lead concentration in 45 Colt rounds commercially loaded with black powder or ones designed for Cowboy Action Shooting (as they are more traditional and designed to be fired at a lower velocity).  You could disassemble the black powder rounds and remake them with the smokeless powder you finally used (looked like Clays).    Asking a pro shooter who reloads EXCEEDINGLY accurate ammunition may be worth while --Erik Cortina is an absolute master.
